The British will never accept second-class membership, not to be allowed to choose, to pay money, to have to accept the ECJ and not to have a free hand for free trade agreements. That is why it is right – and we should support them – for another referendum to be held. And then this House and also the Council should say: you British, we are going into your conditions, we are discussing the principle. Mr President, you let someone talk for two minutes. Let me say one last sentence. We must tell the British that they are welcome. We must tell the British that they have a right to regulate the conditions that really affect them in such a way that they are satisfied. Then they come back.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the way in which the European Union is handling the issue of Brexit is indicative of its misguided policy of dealing with all the serious issues it has to deal with. Instead of reflecting and trying to correct the mistakes they have made and forced the British people to seek to leave the European Union, he wants to punish and humiliate the British people. In the same spirit, with the same philosophy it seeks to punish Hungary and Poland by applying the provisions of Article 7 against them, Mr Orbán's Fidesz party and also in this spirit for nine consecutive years punishes Greece and the Greek people, whom it has impoverished with the constant memoranda imposed on it, and does not wish to reduce the burdensome debt suffered by the Greek people. Punishment, then, and only punishment! This is the philosophy of the European Union and that is why, after two months, the ancient goddess of punishment, Nemesis, will appear in this European Parliament, in the presence of many patriotic parties in this area.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, as you know from your mother, the ancient Greeks said 'no evil pure good'. So what about the chaos that Brexit is about to create? We can see from there that the effects of populism are revealed. The absolute lies served by Mr Farage, the absolute illusions served by his like-minded people. So what happens through the chaos of Brexit? We see the risk of behaving punitively towards the citizens of the United Kingdom and we must not do so. We have to give them all the opportunities to choose. What's going on through the chaos of Brexit? We see the danger of hurting ourselves in a disorderly move, with an undrafted Brexit move. What do I think we should do? To show that we are the European Parliament. To give the citizens of the United Kingdom the opportunity to behave soberly. To judge and decide again for their own future. To support a second referendum.

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by President Weber has said here that, since Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union does not work like this, it does not produce the effects that the dominant states, the dominant political forces in the Union, would like, to circumvent this article, then it must be done in such a way that it has such effects: not as provided for in the Treaty, but as the likely future President of the European Commission wishes. Or would it simply be appropriate to respect the position of the Governments of the European Countries represented in the European Council? Since there is no majority that wants to continue these brawls against Poland and Hungary, it may be worth mentioning that the Treaty on Union did not want such easy decisions that would divide Europe. If the rule of law does not count for Mr Weber, if the pluralism of the position of all the Countries of the European Union does not count, if the most elementary rights of minorities do not count, that is, the rights of the opposition, those who have a minority position, then perhaps the unity of Europe will at least count for him, and that really does not deepen the divisions, of which there are really too many.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: chief Brexit negotiator. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at the end of this important debate, we have listened, together with President Juncker and Vice-President Katainen, to each and every one of you with great care. Let me say a few words, thanking you, Mr President. On Thursday, at the invitation of President Donald Tusk, whom I personally thank, I once again took part and attended the debates of the European Council, which is being discussed this morning, and I can testify once again on this extraordinary Brexit-related negotiation of the gravity and responsibility that is that of each and every European leader around this table. , and in the serious, responsible, objective way with which they decide and they are working on this negotiation. It is now almost two years since the task of conducting this negotiation was entrusted to me by President Juncker and President Tusk, with the confidence of Parliament. For the past two years, ladies and gentlemen, and I want to say this today, I have, like you - and this has been Parliament's main point of vigilance, considering that the issue of the security of citizens' rights should be our priority, as Guy Verhofstadt, Manfred Weber, Roberto Gualtieri, Udo Bullmann and Gabriele Zimmer have said in turn earlier. , and others.  As President Tusk has said, the priority will remain the security of citizens' rights, those some 4.5 million people, 3.5 million European citizens who live and work in the United Kingdom and who participate, Mr Farage, in the economy of your country, and 1.5 million British citizens who live and work in one of our countries. This security of citizens' rights will remain, Mr Verhofstadt, our priority, whether in the hope of an agreement that we expect, but also in the event of a no deal, which we do not want but to which we are preparing. And we will find a way to guarantee those rights. For the past two years, we have been working with the same respect for the United Kingdom. I have admiration for your country, ladies and gentlemen, as I have often said here. For its history, for its culture, for a number of men and women who have led it in history, but also for the solidarity that has been yours in the most serious hours, in the twentieth century, towards us. So it is with this respect that we work. And in this notion of respect, Mr Farage, I obviously include respect for the sovereign decision of a majority of British citizens. We respect this decision, even if we regret it, and we implement it patiently, rigorously, conscientiously, methodically for the past two years, that is what we have been doing. Mr Farage, no one in Brussels is trying to steal Brexit and want to hijack the vote of the British people. But it is not in Brussels that we make the choice to leave the European Union, it is you who make this choice and it is you who must take responsibility and face the consequences of these decisions, no one else. So, for the last two years, we have been implementing the decision, with this respect, and I want to say to Mr Legutko, who is not here to listen to me, that at no time in the last two years, at no second, there has been any trace of the will of humiliation or revenge on the United Kingdom, quite the contrary. For the past two years, I have been saying this to President McGuinness, who was president earlier, but also to Sean Kelly, to Mr Nicholson, whom I always listen to with attention, to Mrs Anderson or to Mrs Dodds, we have been patiently looking for concrete and operational solutions to the most serious problem created by Brexit, which is obviously in Ireland, and the risk to the peace and stability of this island, to which we have contributed for 20 years. , since the Good Friday agreement, this is what we are doing, nothing else. Mr Nicholson, just a few words in the case of a no deal. In all scenarios, the Good Friday Agreement will continue to apply. The United Kingdom will remain a co-guarantor of that agreement and is expected to uphold it in spirit and in letter. The Commission is ready to make additional resources available to Ireland - technical and financial - to address any additional challenges. Compliance with the Good Friday agreement will therefore remain the line to avoid a hard border, but of course there will have to be checks somewhere in one way or another, because it is the respect of the internal market, that is to say our internal market, but also respect for the British internal market, Mr Farage.  For the past two years, we have been working on this negotiation, which remains a negative negotiation. It there is no added value to Brexit. No one, not even Mr Farage, has been able to show me the added value of Brexit. No one! It's a negative, lose-lose negotiation! We must therefore intelligently find an agreement to limit the consequences of this negotiation. Then, somehow, end it as soon as possible because, as Mrs Rodriguez said earlier, there is a great deal to be done beyond and outside of Brexit on the positive agenda that President Tusk has mentioned and which President Katainen will discuss later. That's what counts! In this positive agenda, beyond the divorce that we want as orderly as possible, I attach an important place to building a strong and lasting relationship with the United Kingdom, a great country that will in any case remain a friend, an ally and a partner. I would conclude by saying that the decision of the European Council was taken in good conscience, in order to deal with this sometimes unpredictable situation in the House of Commons. You must understand this decision as the will for the Europeans that the United Kingdom can now, in full sovereignty, make its own decisions and face its own responsibilities. It is up to the United Kingdom to choose, one way or another. And what was decided by the European Council, with this double deadline decision in April and then in May, is precisely the possibility for the United Kingdom to take its responsibilities. It is now up to him, who wants to leave, to choose his future and finally to accept the consequences of his decisions.  Because this negotiation is not a trade negotiation, it is not a matter of haggling or making concessions on both sides. That has never been our mindset. This process is an exit process. The UK is leaving the European Union, wants to leave the single market, wants to leave the customs union, taking responsibility for it and assuming the consequences. Even if he can still stay, as President Tusk said, anything is possible until 11 April.  I mean that this choice has consequences and that the United Kingdom must assume them in full responsibility and sovereignty. It is this opportunity offered to him by the decision of the European Council.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, even though the debate has concentrated almost purely on the Brexit issue, I will not comment more on that, because our chief negotiator, Mr Barnier, has already explained everything relevant so elegantly.  I would like to comment on a couple of other points which were also part of the European Council agenda, namely industrial policy and especially the EU-China relations. Very briefly, on industrial policy, the Commission has already set up a working group. It’s kind of an expert group which has been working on the future of the industrial policy of Europe. The target is 2030 and this group has already been working more than a year. I am co-chairing it together with Commissioner Bieńkowska and we will come out with concrete proposals by the summer. So this paper is at the disposal of the next Commission and the next Parliament. The aim is to identify the most crucial points, how to modernise the European industry. Another very important topic is the EU-China relationship. We appreciate a lot that the Council paid attention to our proposals and endorsed many of our proposals because the EU and China are strategic partners and strategic partners usually do things together, not only speak together on the issues. This situation is currently a little bit problematic. We share many views with the Chinese authorities on various policy issues and we have also done some things together, but there are many issues which we have mostly been talking about, but not doing that much and this happens mostly in the field of economy.  China is a political superpower – a foreign policy superpower, a military superpower. It’s also a technological leader. It’s a business leader in many areas and that’s why there is no point to say that China is only a developing country. China for sure is a developing country in many respects, but taking into account its power in the world’s economy today we have all the reasons to expect reciprocity. This is what the EU is expecting from the Chinese side – a strategic partnership based on reciprocity, especially when we talk about market access policies.  The European Council also asked the Commission to come with concrete proposals on how to improve our business and economic relationship with China, and this is under our work at the moment. We are preparing, for instance, state aid rules to third country acquisitions. As everybody knows, we have very strict state aid rules when it comes to intra—EU acquisitions, but the same rules don’t apply with a third country, and this is problematic. We want to make sure that there is a level playing field, that there is hard competition, but not unfair competition. So we have to make sure that our single market is open for everybody, but is fair for everybody. We cannot allow unfair competition to happen or take place in Europe.  We also, like President Tusk said earlier, expect to finalise our investment agreement negotiations with China by 2020. This is of utmost importance. It will help Chinese and European investments to flourish. Also, we expect China to accept the geographical indications agreement, which has already been negotiated but unfortunately not approved yet. Honourable Members, as I said, we are strategic partners. We work very closely in many political areas, but economic cooperation is one of the particular areas where improvements are needed in order to maintain a level playing field and in order to allow European companies to do the same things in China as Chinese companies are doing in Europe.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, just two remarks. The first one for clarification, dear Maria, this was not the last European Council before the elections to the European Parliament. It is pretty likely that we will meet still in April to discuss Brexit, and for sure we will also meet on 9 May in Sibiu to discuss our long-term EU strategy. It will be in an informal meeting, but also dedicated to absolutely crucial topics. Mr Farage, you have presented passionate arguments against the second referendum. But the truth is that the second referendum took place in 2016, because the first one took place in 1975. Then, a vast majority of the British public decided that the place of the UK was in the European Communities. It was you who thought three years ago that it would be possible to organise a referendum in order to invalidate the previous one. Please be consistent today too.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – In the European Parliament we have been often critical of the European Council. Not this time. You've done the right thing by pointing to a certain date. No more extension — on 12 April – for the British Parliament to find an exit plan — an exit plan — but not from the European Union, but from the labyrinth from which they do not know how to leave. We have often shown all our sympathy for the millions of Britons marching to remain in the European Union, but never the enough demand for irresponsible demagogues that have caused so much harm to the British people by deceiting and manipulating them. And, of course, it must be said quite clearly that now is the time, there is no more extension. The bad news is they haven't let us talk about anything else. The good news is that the hourglass is already running against you. A message to the House of Commons: let them decide, to clarify. Or exit or revocation, without which there should be no European elections in the UK. But let them do it as soon as possible and respond to the damage caused.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – I wanted to speak only to remind you that in December, when you were in Romania, you publicly stated that Romania must be in Schengen.  What have you done to keep your word? How can you end your term without doing what you said?  I thank Mr Tajani, who passed on the position of parliament, which voted for Romania and Bulgaria to be admitted to the Schengen area. I also thank President Juncker, who has also submitted the Commission's request for admission.  Why are you ignoring the Schengen Regulation and the request of the two institutions, the European Parliament and the European Commission? I ask you, Mr Tusk, to decide until the end of the mandate the admission of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – This debate takes place amidst continuing chaos at Westminster, where the UK Government has lost control of its relentless pursuit of exiting the EU – against the wishes of the people of Scotland. The SNP has made the case – based on the clear opinion of 62% of Scottish voters representing each and every council area in the country – to remain a member of the European Union. Yet Westminster has treated the views of Scotland with contempt. The Scottish Government has continuously argued that the aggressive hard Brexit or bad deal position favoured by the UK Government has been wrong—headed, but the UK’s devolved administrations have been ignored throughout. Westminster today is debating various alternatives to Theresa May’s reckless strategy. May is in office but not in power. SNP MPs will support an amendment that will see a series of indicative votes on Brexit next steps, including the option to revoke the Article 50 application. The crisis highlights what the Westminster government really thinks about Scotland. They have continually ignored strong Scottish opinion on remaining an EU member, and put the narrow interests of the Tory Party first. Scotland deserves better and the argument for Scottish independence gets stronger every day.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – 12 April, the day the United Kingdom may leave our Union, is getting closer and closer. The British Government must now provide clarity in the shortest possible time and come up with a concrete plan on whether and how they want to leave the Union. No matter how the British want to leave the Union, the rights that people now have must be guaranteed in that situation. It cannot be the case that european data will be put on the streets if the UNITED Kingdom is no longer covered by European privacy law. I think it is important that the standards we have built up in the EU are guaranteed after Brexit. Incomes, workers' rights and social security in the UK must be protected in the final agreement. We do not want an island off the coast that violates the social standards that we have built together.  Together, the UK and the MEMBER States of the EU, we share a rich history. Time and time again it appears that we are moving forward through cooperation. Whether it's peace or prosperity. This cooperation must continue after Brexit, because that is the only way to prevent a divorce.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – To assert a meaningful role on the global stage, the European Union needs a strong economic base for prosperity and competitiveness. The Heads of State and Government say they stand for a long-term vision of the EU’s industrial policy, one that boosts investments in technology, research and innovation. However they fail to link this priority to the allocation of resources to research in the fundamental sciences. Their commitment places Europe midstream in the flow from fundamental science to applied research. So, our best graduates in fundamental science drift towards the US and Asia. Meanwhile, economic and social divergences within the Union continue to grow. The European Council remains elusive on this. Economic reform programmes must dedicate more efforts to correct existing regional and national imbalances and to bridge gaps between Member States in the area of social policy. The European Council fails to commit towards change on issues related to equal opportunities and access to the labour market, fair working conditions, social protection including the elimination of precarious employment of young people, and the need to counterbalance the growth of profits by an improvement in remuneration levels. Economic reforms only make sense if they imply social progress for the working and middle classes, for young people and pensioners.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – The so-called reforms imposed in the framework of the European semester invariably go through labour deregulation, the attack on the social functions of the state, liberalisation and privatisation. These conclusions also reaffirm the international trade deregulation agenda, which opens markets and business opportunities to big capital at the same rate as it increases the pressure on workers and peoples to lose social and labour rights. They reaffirm the intention to deepen the Single Market and economic and monetary union, which have promoted inequality and divergence within the European Union, harming countries such as Portugal. In Portugal, this agenda - advocated in the European Parliament by PS, PSD and CDS - finds in these same parties their defenders and executors. The results are in sight: in the lack of response to the country's structural problems and in the limited response, even in the current situation, to the fair anires and aspirations of vast sectors of the population. No more impositions!

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The European Council was correct in maintaining a coordinated and flexible attitude towards the process of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union (EU). The two timing scenarios proposed for the choice of the Government and the English Parliament show that the Union does not want to put pressure on the English people or their representatives, respects the decision taken in the referendum on the subject, but is not insensitive to the growing voices that speak out for a new referendum and express their desire to remain in the EU. I would also stress that, in addition to the key theme of the Brexit process, the Council discussed key issues to strengthen the European partnership and its global voice, including deepening the internal market, modernising and competitiveness of industry, developing the digital economy and fostering an ambitious trade agenda. The best response that the EU can give to the uncertainty posed by Brexit is to strengthen the strategic lines that make it possible to assert its values in the new global order.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for a joint discussion on: - the report by Merja Kylonen, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on control requirements and specific rules for the secondment of drivers in the road transport sector (COM(2017)0278 - C8-0170/2017 - 2017/0121 (COD) (A8-0206/2018)), - the report by Wim van de Camp, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on maximum daily and weekly driving times, maximum daily and weekly break times and rest times, and location using tachographs (COM(2017)0277 - C8-0167/2017 - 2017/0122 (COD) (A8-0205/2018)), and - ismail Ertug's report, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism , on adaptations to developments in the road transport sector (COM(2017)0281 - C8-0169/2017 - 2017/0123(COD) (A8-0204/2018)).

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a saga of its own has reached this point and we would be required to stand by the ideas that were opened less than a couple of years ago about fair rules of play in the transport sector and the fair and socially well-regulated position of drivers in the labour market. The common stage has taken place in very challenging circumstances. Compromises have been built. Some believe that the compromise is too much, that there is too much strong regulation, and for others there is too little regulation, that is, even tougher rules of the game are needed. The compromise rarely makes everyone come out victorious. Unfortunately, we are not children in the candy trade; It has been interesting to follow the debate on how it has been claimed that we do not have a compromise that can be voted on. Yes, we do, but obviously it seems that it is too difficult for many parties to swallow up, that the rules of the game in European transport would be such that drivers would no longer be exploited there and that we would not have these letterbox companies running a business that does not comply with the Business Code in accordance with European rules of the game. We had a big premise that we would stop nomading. Drivers have the right to be home to their family or to a place of their choice at regular intervals. This compromise, drawn up together, includes a genuine end to nomading and the right for drivers to return to their place of dom or to a place agreed with the company or employer. There was an idea of equal pay for equal work. To a very large extent, we have come to the common conclusion that equal pay is paid for equal work in the transport sector. That doesn't seem to be enough either. For the directives sent, some want a model in which everything is sent from day one. Of course, it has its own social aspects that can certainly be justified, but it also takes away the flexibility to operate according to the rules of the game, so that vehicles are not empty or half empty either when they are transported back and forth on Europe's roads. Letterbox companies – clear rules of the game for abolishing them and the shutdown of illegal cabotage, and then for crosstrade operations not to be used as a new form of illegal cabotage. For the first time, we would put the obligation in check and order: enforcement rules as a common entity for the whole package, as well as electric tachographs, and overall monitoring on the road afterwards would be possible with these plotters. There is a compromise. All sorts of work is being done here to prevent a vote on the compromise. I hope that we will have the backbone to make decisions and ensure that drivers have genuinely social fair rules of play in Europe and companies can compete honestly with genuine rules that work.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, in line with Mrs Kyllönen, I can confirm that the Mobility Package I is an integrated package of secondment, cabotage and driving and rest periods. We have all noticed in recent weeks and days that it is a politically difficult issue that goes to the heart of the European Union's internal market.  In my file driving and rest periods are about improving the working conditions of the drivers. This is not so much about the daily working hours and rest hours, which is arranged in another file. We're not going to get that. It is mainly about the rest periods at night and on weekends. The most important question is where does a driver spend that weekend rest. We have seen that there is currently illegal parking on many European roads. There's no sanitation there. There's no kitchen there. That is what we are trying to resolve with this dossier and the European Commission's proposal. In this respect, we are being controlled and obstructed by the European Court in Luxembourg. This has stipulated that the regular weekend rest may no longer be spent in the cabin. We have tried to find a solution to this by banning it, but with a decent transitional period.  Another element in this file is when the driver goes home. We don't want nomad drivers who have been away from home for more than four weeks. They must go home on time and their employer must guarantee this, up to four weeks at a time.  The short weekend rest remains: it can be spent in the secure and well-equipped parking spaces.  A special part of this file is the bus drivers. You know, Madam President, passengers are not containers. For the bus drivers we need a little more flexibility. Not 16 hours of work, as some members of the S&D Group claim, but a little more flexibility, especially when it comes to the so-called 12-day scheme.  Mr President, an important part of this dossier and the other two is enforcement. Mrs Kyllönen has already spoken about this and it is all about introducing the so-called smart tachograph second generation on 1 January 2024. In addition, the problem of post office companies is indeed at stake, a phenomenon that we must tackle and combat at all costs.  Mr President, finally, something about cabotage and secondment. We must be careful not to tackle or impede the flexibility of the internal market with too stringent legislation. We currently have a large driver shortage of more than 50 000 people in Europe and it is important that this driver shortage is resolved with flexibility and with good working conditions.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to take up what the two previous speakers have said, namely the fact that we do now have a situation on European motorways that is largely unsustainable. It is no longer acceptable for the countries and for the regions that can no longer cope with this in terms of infrastructure, but also for those who have to do their work on the streets every day – far from their homeland and away from their families.  This, of course, also contributes to the fact that this profession is no longer so lucrative, so interesting. It's not always about money. If you look at the average income of drivers in south-eastern Europe in particular, they are above average. But there is still a shortage of drivers there. So it cannot be down to money alone. This has to do with the fact that the conditions are bad, that the conditions are bad. If you're on the road for three months and then you're at home for a month and then you're on the road for almost three months, then at some point you don't feel like the job.  That is why it was right for the European Commission to put forward this mobility package I. And, as my two fellow rapporteurs have rightly said, we want to design this sector in Europe in such a way that, firstly, we continue to maintain this internal market, that access is possible, but at the same time that, at the end of the day, the basis and the basis are taken away from the few who have built up their business models only through social dumping.  We have the situation that we voted here in Parliament last July and all three dossiers were rejected. And since almost a year has passed since then, ladies and gentlemen, we have, of course, dealt with the issue together. We have had cross-party discussions and have finally put forward compromises here. Of course, compromises are decisions that do not satisfy everyone. Yes, but that is why it is a compromise.  That is why it was a good thing that, after 3 December, when there was a general approach in the Council, so to speak, with a majority decision, we had the opportunity once again to set up and formulate solutions on this basis. We have brought them in. The fact that various points of order – I call them tricks, I am sorry – are now trying to undermine them, that is just the way it is.  But the fact is that this legislation is needed. We have hundreds of thousands of drivers waiting for it. We have companies that ultimately deal properly with their people, who are serious entrepreneurs, and they are also waiting for this legislation. What would happen if this legislation did not take place? Then we still have this wild-west state with many grey areas on the roads. We have the danger – and this has already been announced – that various Member States will take unilateral action, which in turn will also be called on the agenda by the European Commission in retrospect. That is why we are once again calling for support for this compromise.  What is in my dossier "Access to the market and cabotage"? We have tried precisely to eliminate the weaknesses of the current legislation, which pretend to allow three operations within seven days. We tried to put this on a new footing because it was simply not feasible to control all this with the security authorities. We have found a solution which is also supported by the Eastern European states. All in all, the whole thing is a good approach, which ultimately deserves to be successfully decided.

name: Georges BACH
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, because we have worked well together and presented a decent opinion. Unfortunately, our report is being taken hostage to vote on the whole package. I do not want to go into the content any more, Mrs Merja Kyllönen, Wim van de Kamp and ismail Ertug have now done enough. I would just like to record the irresponsible situation that we now find. Do we want to duck that, duck away and let this package die? This is irresponsible. And it is irresponsible that these conditions, which have just been described, will continue on the roads, on the rest areas. That we continue to allow the rogue companies to continue to find loopholes in order to undermine, circumvent and compete unfairly with the current legislation. I also think that it is essential that we put an end to this mischief of light commercial vehicles. That is why I hope that next week we will be able to take responsibility in such a way that order and justice will be restored on the roads and that drivers will finally find decent conditions. (Applause)

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, today is a very disappointing day for me personally. Today, we have missed a great opportunity to take decisions that are crucial for the European economy. Today we have deprived us of the opportunity to act as responsible politicians.   Today should have been the day when we should have adopted the special rules that are necessary in view of the high mobility specific to the transport sector. We need these rules to protect our carriers and drivers from legislative uncertainty. After all, we do not want each Member State to bring its own rules and their own way of enforcing them into the common market.   Today we have missed this opportunity, ladies and gentlemen. Instead of facing the situation head on, we're going back. It is as if we have forgotten that the European internal market depends largely on transport. Goods must flow smoothly across borders, rules must be balanced and applicable.  Ladies and gentlemen, let us rise above politicking and return to the only possible solution, and that is compromise. There's going to be an opportunity next week. It's our duty and responsibility. That's why we were elected, and that's why we're here. It is up to us. (The speaker has agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". – (beginning of the speech when the micro is switched off) ... criticized today. We received 1 600 amendments on Monday and had two hours to respond, because then the deadline for new amendments had already expired. I have never seen such a procedure in 15 years in this Parliament. This is undemocratic to the core! What is the problem when we vote next week? We want to sit down and seek compromises, of course. But the other shadow rapporteurs were not involved at all. That is why it is right that we do not decide on this today. I do not want to read and respond to 1 600 requests in two hours. This is undemocratic and not worthy of a Parliament.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I am the first to imagine that the vote should be simple and absolutely clear to all of us. But we are now responsible for ensure that carriers and drivers are no longer prolonging this situation in legal uncertainty, we have to face up to it, whether we want to or not, even if we have to work all night on what our vote should look like. But it's our responsibility, that's why we were elected.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, Commissioner Bulc would like to apologise for not being here today. The Mobility Package remains of course a political priority for the Commission, and for Commissioner Bulc in particular. However, she must participate in the informal Transport Council, which is taking place in Bucharest. In May 2017, when the Commission adopted the first part of the Mobility Package, it aimed first of all at improving working conditions in the road transport sector; secondly, at ensuring fair competition and avoiding internal market fragmentation through uncoordinated national rules; and, thirdly, at reducing the administrative burden for operators and allowing more efficient and targeted controls through further digitalisation. Since then, we have come a long way, and I would like to thank you for your efforts, and in particular the three rapporteurs, Ms Kyllönen, Mr van de Camp and Mr Ertug, who have been major driving forces in this process. From the beginning, we knew that this was going to be a marathon rather than a sprint. The stakes are very high on these proposals. That is why a long maturation period was unavoidable for these proposals to sink in and be improved. With the general approach reached in Council on 3 December 2018, and the work of the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs in this House, we are now close to a good compromise on this major reform of road transport. The road sector needs a breakthrough now. The hauliers and the drivers need a fair and stable framework for the next years. The sector cannot wait any longer.  A swift agreement in Parliament will show that this House is committed to address the pressing challenges this sector faces. The intense work of the Parliament has allowed us to reach rather uncontroversial solutions on important issues, such as the fight against letterbox companies; enhanced cooperation between national authorities; the better use of digital tools, such as tachographs, electronic freight documents and the notification of posting declarations; and proportionate rules for light commercial vehicles. Progress on these issues allowed Parliament to focus the last discussions on the main outstanding issues, namely the rules on cabotage, the driving and rest times, and last, but certainly not least, the lex specialis on the application of the posting rules in road transport.  In our view, the compromise proposals tabled strike a good balance and meet the general objectives of the Commission’s proposals: better enforcement, better working conditions, less administrative burden on road transport undertakings, and reaping the benefits of digitalisation. At this stage, the Commission maintains a general reserve, but it will continue to support discussions with a view to reaching an agreement on these priority files. We can support all amendments which maintain the balance between the freedom to provide transport services, improve working conditions and reduce administrative burdens. Let me now make a few considerations on particular points. I will start with the lex specialis on posting of workers. When the general Posting of Workers Directive was revised, there was a clear commitment to adopt specific rules for road transport. The so—called split model for the posting of directives, while being different from the approach proposed by the Commission, strikes a good balance between the protection of the social rights of drivers and the freedom for operators to provide cross-border transport services. It is supported by the rapporteur and contained in the general approach adopted by Council. Moreover, we support posting requirements for the road transport sector that are as simple as possible to apply and to control with the use of digital tools. We believe that the approach promoted by Ms Kyllönen meets these objectives. I turn now to the rules on driving and rest times. This is a sensitive subject, which has a direct impact on working conditions and road safety. In the Commission’s view, the driver must be able to take his normal and long weekly rest either at home with his family, or in comfortable accommodation – not in the truck cabin. At the same time, drivers also need to be granted suitable, safe and secure resting facilities. Therefore, ensuring the availability of such facilities is crucial. The Commission supports and actively promotes the development of safe and secure parking areas, including through financial support from the EU budget. I can assure you that the Commission will intensify its efforts, including through EU funding under the next Connecting Europe Facility. For passenger transport, the sector has received a clear message over the last weeks. Certain driving and rest time rules are not adapted to the activity of a coach or bus driver. The message has been heard, and we are ready to start immediately a comprehensive assessment on specific rules for these drivers, if this House so requests. For sure, our objective will remain the same: improving the working conditions of drivers and road safety. Let me finish on the rules on access to the profession and to the market. On cabotage, I am pleased that the rapporteur maintains the concept of an unlimited number of operations over a certain period of time, which was proposed by the Commission. Cabotage, the cooling—off period and the regular return of the truck to the Member State of establishment have been the subject of intense debates. We have to reach a balance here. The obligation for the trucks to return to the Member State of establishment should be assessed together with the additional establishment criteria, and also the new rule requiring drivers to return home on a regular basis. I look forward to the debate. Please carefully reflect on the links between the different areas of the Mobility Package. I would appeal to all to be constructive and to focus on solutions that work for the road haulage sector and its workers, and of course, for the European Union economy. This vote will be crucial for the work ahead of us.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to express my sadness at the absence of an agreement after months of work and I must therefore make the following considerations. We must bear in mind the different realities that occur in road transport in the Union, both in distances and times, and avoid considering this package as a clash between countries and thinking about the common good of the sector. Of course it is important to defend workers and ensure their safety. We all want it and we have also made a lot of advances, but what we cannot do is generalize and use illegal practices — which have certainly occurred — as a pretext for protectionist purposes. We cannot give up the freedom of movement of persons and goods, freedom of establishment, freedom to provide services, which are basic parts of the internal market and the process of integration of the European Union. If we want a more economically, socially and territorially cohesive Europe, we cannot take steps back and erect barriers in the hard-won internal market.

name: Andor DELI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support For decades, the freedom to provide the single transport market and services has been a driver of the European economy. Unfortunately, some Member States have taken national measures to cause deep cracks in the single European transport market. The European Commission's proposals did not show any improvement, but completely divided the Member States between headquarters and periphery. They have proposed rules that, as it stands, are simply unenforceable. In the Council, against nine countries, the position was pushed through with one abstention. Now it's Parliament's turn. Everyone is talking about principles and European values, while one of the eu's cornerstones is the provision of free services and the single internal market can be damaged if we force decision-making. Without transport, there is no successful European economy, any disruption in transport will make production more expensive, and citizens will ultimately have to pay for it. We need to get back to the negotiating table and find a real compromise. And it takes time and composure, but both are missing. It is too late, we are at the end of our mandate, and there is complete division in every faction in Parliament, and it is impossible to negotiate calmly. I don't know if we can work miracles until next week and find a compromise out of 1,200 amendments. I don't think we're going to be able to negotiate in a week what we haven't had the chance to do in two years. Increasingly, it seems that the new Parliament should be left to it. It's better not to have a deal than a bad deal.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I am very sorry for Commissioner Bulc's absence from this debate which I think I should have heard. As shadow rapporteur for Mrs Kyll'nen's report, I must thank her for the spirit of good work and cooperation we have had with the rapporteur and with the rest of my colleagues in order to strengthen - because that was the basis — rigorous control. In fact, we are advancing the obligation of the digital tachograph by 2022. But in any case, we do not want such control to be discriminatory and to spray xenophobic protectionism.  We don't want the driver to be to blame. Companies and administrations must, in their charge, facilitate all possible control tasks, because in the 5G era it is aberrant to have drivers standing on the road to control stacks of paper documents. It's dangerous and also humiliating. We also want a proportional application, that is to say, that we agree with the rapporteur, with Mrs Kyll-nen, on the exclusion of transit and international transport, and we are against the return home of the truck, which we find to be absolutely aberrant. However, we need a flexible home trip for our Spanish and Portuguese drivers.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank President Tajani. He saved the image of the European Parliament last night with his decision, because you cannot legislate in the manner that was proposed until yesterday night. The European Parliament would be seen in that case as a subsidiary of qualified majority of the Council, or even as a subsidiary of the Commission. Politics also means compromise, always, and Trump did it a year ago, as we remember. Since the plenary voted against this compromise I think we lost any opportunity in this Parliament to get a real compromise, a professional and responsible compromise. And not only until next week, but also until the end of this legislature. How does our House look in the context of the Mobility Package I? The responsible committee cannot submit a report on two of the three dossiers. The groups, with some exceptions, are so divided that even the biggest political group doesn’t have any coherent group-wide position and so abstains from anything in relation to this package. Even if we continue next month in the same manner, merely outvoting proposals by one or two votes as on Monday in other parts of this House, then what does it mean for citizens in the run-up to the elections? They will think that politicians can sacrifice the single market in road transport for the purposes of using protectionism to meet some national and thus as a way to be re-elected, and we don’t want to see it.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the proper functioning of transport is key to the competitiveness of the Union. This mobility package is a key part of ending the fragmentation problems caused by domestic social dumping and inequalities in operator market access. That is why I bet on passing common rules that end state-to-state solutions that, with the intention of solving these problems, have actually made them grow. That is why I support the compromise positions that the rapporteurs presented to these three reports. The measures we propose improve the conditions of professionals, contribute to road safety and transport efficiency and pave the way for a near future in which digitization and decarbonization will change our lives for the better. Citizenship chooses us to try the best, but it knows that the best is an enemy of the good. In the transport sector, too. That is why those who block this European solution by pure electoralism are wrong. This mobility package is not the best of the possible, but it has enough work, conversations, participation and agreements to be much better than we have today.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been working for months to improve the working conditions of road transport workers, months of these employees being held hostage by some in the name of their country's interests.  We are talking about women and men who sometimes work extremely long, painful periods without seeing their families, sleeping in poorly maintained car parks and others would still like them to sleep in their cabins.  Social dumping organized by large groups in the sector exploits their workforce to the point of exhaustion, with terrible consequences for road safety. A tired driver on our roads is a threat to him, to his load, but also to all other road users.  The exploitation of employees in the sector, advocated by the European Commission, must be refused in this parliament. And there are a number of us in this room who refuse what is simply the legislation of a modern form of slavery on our roads.  Equal rights, and decent working conditions, must benefit everyone in the European Union. We do not want second-class workers, which is why we continue to fight for the detachment to apply to everyone and not to the card according to the trade. We don't want exhausted drivers on the road because it endangers the lives of others. That is why we refuse to waive the ban on weekly rest in the cabin. We no longer want a social jungle open to all winds, nor trucks that return empty to their base. That is why we will fight to keep cabotage regulated.  Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must keep its promises. Everyone wants a social Europe, let's go! We now ask that everyone take responsibility. Everyone has to do the job, not look at the interests of these countries or their own country. We are here to guarantee what? The proper application of the rules in force in Europe.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it cannot be that the dignification of the harsh working conditions of drivers is conditioned on us allowing social dumping when regulating the movement of drivers to other States of the Union.  Conservatives tell us: "If you want drivers to spend their weekly rest outside their vehicle, in decent conditions, then let a Spanish driver be paid less when driving outside Spain." What kind of blackmail is this?  We must establish a fair regulation that allows drivers to sleep in a decent bed during their breaks, that they do not have to work for more than two weeks straight out of their place of origin, that vehicles incorporate the smart tachograph so that fraud is a thing of the past, and we must abolish the unfair competition that involves moving drivers abroad by rewarding them less than they are entitled to. It is a question of dignity in labour rights and it is a matter of security.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the road haulage sector needs important and urgent responses to tackle many problems. We are witnessing on a daily basis what is real slavery, involving drivers from all over Europe: they are forced to spend their lives on means of transport, eating, sleeping there, without having the opportunity to go home and spend time with their loved ones. In addition to the problem of social dumping, there is the problem of unfair competition. We must allow companies to compete on the same basis; we must combat relocations, we must encourage unfairly tax and wage systems. We have to do this because this is happening. In recent years we have seen a trend that has increasingly lowered social standards and wage levels, a trend that needs to be rebalanced today. It is our responsibility, for this parliamentary term, for this Parliament! We cannot shirk: so let us try until the end, see you again next week in the TRAN committee. Let us try to give rules and social rights to our hauliers.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Please be honest with the people out there. The time is too short for us to pay lip service here. Be honest and say that mobility package I will no longer be adopted during this period. That is sad! This is sad for a great many drivers across Europe. Because where do we stand? In principle, not much has changed compared to where the package stood a year ago. And what do we achieve now? We are achieving exactly the opposite of what we actually wanted to achieve, namely the improvements in the working conditions of drivers.  The Austrian Presidency has presented something, it has presented a general approach. What has become of it? Nothing! And there are reasons why nothing has come of it. On the one hand, these are the diametrically opposed extreme situations of the Socialists and the PPE-DE here in this House, which do not allow a movement. On the other hand, it is a chaotic Green presidency that has not brought any leadership here from the outset and which has even held anti-democratic unofficial coordinator meetings without inviting other coordinators. That is the reason.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Karima DELLI
text: 'blue card' question. I do not accept in this Parliament that my competence in the Committee on Transport should be called into question. I am not sending you back the ball, not least because the fact is that your group really wants to damage the European project, and that, as committee chair, I will do everything to improve the working conditions of employees. I say this to you with my eyes in my eyes, I do not know who you stand for judging the quality, especially of my presidency, in any case I will not accept it.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Delli, you will have to accept this now. You are well aware that you have held unofficial coordinator meetings without inviting some of the group coordinators. And now you are not telling me who I am. Who do you think you're bypassing voters and holding such meetings? This is a naughty and anti-democratic.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: We are not in a debate with questions in the form of blue cards and we are resuming the speeches.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I wanted to appeal to the President of the European Parliament and to all political groups not to vote on the mobility package in this parliamentary term. It is election time, time too short. The 1500 amendments, the lack of compromises and the possibility to agree on them show that, in such a short period of time, we are not in a position to prepare the mobility package so that it is transparent and understandable, respects European freedoms, respects the single market, restricts competition and does not hit European consumers. We cannot act under political pressure and, as Mrs Delli said, look at the interests of our countries only. I hope we stick to that.  What is happening in the European Parliament is serious. We all want to fight abuse, but can we talk about fighting abuse when you want to go back to the country in an empty car? Is it the fight against abuse that allows cabotage to be delegated, i.e. the same rates apply to all drivers? And you still want to limit cabotage operations and ban drivers from returning to your country within five days. Is the fight against abuse that you want the driver to sleep in a hotel when there are no parking spaces and no hotels? As shadow rapporteur, I was open to any proposal, but I cannot agree to restrictions on freedoms and competition and protectionism. This is unsued.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I have two specific questions for my colleague. Firstly, if you speak so passionately in your speech about the freedom of the internal market, do you mean 'freedom of the internal market' that it should be an internal market free of social rules? Secondly, I would be interested to know that if you point out that the election is imminent, how long should we actually discuss such legislation until it is finally ready for decision? Another question: what else are we elected for, if not for improving working conditions? I have spoken to many Romanian and Polish drivers at German rest stops: working conditions are underground.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I believe that there are too many emotions and the inability to reach compromises in order to conclude this package in this term of office, including trialogami – this is the first.  If we are talking about social issues, I said: cabotage operations, that is, carried out in a country other than the country of residence, are delegated. We agreed to this – that is, the same hourly wage no matter which country the driver is from. Why, Sir, is there a desire to further limit these operations? Why do you want transit to be delegated? That is, a car that travels through several countries. You want to destroy small and medium-sized enterprises and reduce competition. These are facts.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say in advance that we should change the name of the package, because from the 'mobility package' we should perhaps move on to a 'immobility package'. For months now, we have been witnessing a constant balance between the TRAN Committee and the plenary and vice versa, and today, by the way, we should have voted and, unfortunately, we are still in the debate. I think that a good job has been done so far: compromises have been reached on cabotage, posting, driving times and rest periods. I have some misgivings about cross-border cabotage, because I think it lends itself to eluments. Overall, however, I think that we have made real progress and we absolutely must get ahead of the application of the intelligent trachygrapher, because that is the only way we can control these rules. I therefore ask, and I appeal, for a vote to be taken before the end of this term of office, because only then will we be able to say that we have worked well for the citizens and for businesses.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! What are we talking about here today? About the working conditions of drivers, the conditions of their rest, tachographs and God knows more about what. But we are well aware that this is not the point. Because if that were the case, truck drivers would not protest in front of Parliament today. The mobility package is not about getting better, especially for drivers, but about cutting off peripheral countries, especially from Eastern Europe, but also from Southern Europe, from the common transport market. The mobility package is not about working conditions and driving. It is just about sharing the common European market. The countries that joined the Union in 2004 took for granted that we have a common market, have developed their transport sector and today want to cut it. That is why I am in favour of talking about all the issues that we are talking about here – working conditions, etc. – but also to reach a compromise. Because what is a compromise if we have 1600 amendments to the vote in plenary? This is a compromise? There is no compromise here. Parliament should therefore no longer vote on this. Let us move this to the next term of office. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I just want to ask the question, because the debate now sounds as if the lords who have just spoken had not been there at all in recent weeks and months: you and Mrs Ouacijewska were my shadow rapporteurs! After all, we have jointly agreed this compromise with Mr Teli'ka and Mrs Kyllönen! So what is the point of this action? You were there! First you were in favour, then all of a time against it! That is the truth.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Honourable Member, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. We are not meeting today for the first time. Of course, I supported the compromises. These compromises were rejected by a majority in the European Parliament last year. Today, after all, we are not talking about any compromises, today we are talking about controversies, honourable Member, about controversies. The controversies that will divide this market, and we are talking about a common European market. That is what the European Union is for, so that the market is common.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, first of all, I very much regret the decision of the President of the Parliament, because what it will lead to is that next week we will have the same amount of amendments tabled again. This is what the procedure will enable. Secondly, I regret that the President has not taken the effort to respond to a joint letter from myself and colleagues from a number of EPP delegations proposing a concrete scenario and compromises. Yes, we have a large number of amendments, but those are intentional. Let’s be frank, let’s not fool ourselves. They are deliberately tabled so as to complicate the proceedings. This is what it is about, and many of you have confirmed it today because you say, ‘let’s postpone it’. So we have a set of compromises and the decision next week will be about whether we want an internal market – as imperfect as the proposal is – that can function, that will tackle a number of the issues, that will tackle social rights, or do we wish to see something that will lead to unilateral measures, which that we have faced already in the past and that will lead to fragmentation of the internal market, with your responsibility.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have seen the requests for blue cards but we are very late and we are continuing to speak.

name: Keith TAYLOR
text: – Madam President, I think it’s time to revisit our Charter of Fundamental Rights that says that every worker has the right to working conditions which respect his or her health, safety and dignity. We know that, in the case of long—distance, cross-border professional drivers, those conditions are overwhelmingly unhealthy, unsafe and undignified, with access to many of their social rights being deprived by shady employment and letterbox companies. Many drivers are expected to rest in their cabs, with no access to basic hygiene facilities, such as toilets and showers. But this isn’t just a question of rights; it’s a question road safety. When you look at the statistics, you’ll find the driver fatigue is a significant contributor to accidents in the majority of cases. So with that in mind, our party is wanting to see, as an absolute minimum, that we retain a two-week reference period that would not encourage an increase in nomadic driving. An extended weekly rest should be in a hotel. I’d like to add that this appalling mishmash of thousands, hundreds of amendments, is no way to discharge our responsibility, as some colleagues have said. Effectively we just end up with a stitch—up.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Madam President! I was here in the fall down to visit truck drivers from the Philippines who worked in Padborg. They had been brought to the EU via Poland, where they had been granted work permits, and then they would have been sent around Europe for an hourly wage of DKK 15! 15 kr. an hour, dear colleagues! At the same time, they could see their colleagues getting a much better wage - indeed a living wage. That's why, of course, these drivers wondered. Why were they left behind? Why did they get such poor pay and poor working conditions? The drivers told us about how they drove dead-tiredly around Europe's roads. They were able to drive 16 hours in a row in the truck because they could take turns driving, and they were monitored by their boss on the gps. Their lives and their experiences are the flip side of the EU's single market. Our choice in this House is quite clear: are we ready to protect workers or, above all, do we want to protect the internal market? My choice is quite clear - the workers first!

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Madam President, the reforms to the cabotage, the detachment of drivers and the working time of this mobility package show us one thing: the European Union is as social as the socialist republics of Eastern Europe were democrats.  Closing almost two years of deaf dialogue, the legislative obstruction of the last few hours once again demonstrates the Real Inability of the Union to improve the lot of its workers. It also proves how antagonistic the economic interests of member countries are. Having wanted to expand and impose at all costs, out of pure ideology and pride, a single market without prior ambition, the Union enriches only the profiteers, creating the conditions for the replacement of dignified employees by exploited employees. The beneficiaries, as we have just seen, are prepared to do anything to ensure that this system continues.  If the Union does not radically change its paradigm, the people will defeat it. Clearly, the British example was not enough. Let us bet that the next European elections will be a second and, no doubt, a final warning shot.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which If we arbitrarily interpret or abuse our rules of procedure, I will be frightened and anxious. But now to the subject. A few days ago I was again in one of the truck parking lots along the A4 motorway in Germany and got to know drivers from different countries, but especially from Poland and Romania. Their statements were almost identical. First, they feel exploited. They dare not ask their bosses for the fear of losing their jobs after minimum wages or weekends of home. Secondly, they spend their weekly rest periods in inhumane conditions. Thirdly, you are aware of the letterbox companies in their countries of origin and of illegal cabotage trips, which distort competition. Fourthly, you want unbureaucratic and controllable European regulations. Please, ladies and gentlemen, do not close your eyes to reality! After all, professional drivers on European roads deserve to be able to adopt constructive solutions to their problems. Listen to the base!

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We need to improve the catastrophic working conditions of lorry drivers, that is what it is all about. I too, Mr Koch, speak to the lorry drivers at the car parks on the Austrian border, and I hear something similar, more or less the same: for days they sit behind the wheel, driving time of 15 hours at a time, living in the car park and sleeping and working in a cabin that is often smaller than a dog kennel. And at night they are also supposed to guard the cargo – all at a starvation wage. I ask these drivers, "What do you want?" then they say: a decent wage, decent working hours, seeing the family regularly. We must therefore no longer allow this state of affairs. Let us finally vote together for fair working conditions on Europe's roads, for strictly controlled working hours, breaks and rest periods. This requires respect for the hard-working truck drivers.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, I think it is crucial in this debate that we ensure that our drivers can work under the best possible conditions. As far as I am concerned, this means, among other things, that we must ensure that there are enough good, safe parking facilities, but also that we do everything we can to prevent a battle around who earns the least – a race to the bottom – to avoid that fight. Because fair work comes with equal pay for the same work.  The way in which we can ensure fairness for drivers is mainly through proper enforcement. Unfortunately, enforcement is still a long way off in practice, but also in legislation. I don't think there are enough inspectors left. We don't have enough good databases yet. We need more cross-border controls and we certainly need enforcement that does not discriminate. Last but not least, we need to tackle perpetrators and their dubious bosses.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is a question of a large number of goods being transported every day in the internal market, and much of it on the road. And that is what it is all about now.  On the one hand, we want road safety for lorry drivers, which is why we must respect driving and rest periods. On the other hand, we also want reasonable working conditions, and there are the letterbox companies that have already been discussed a lot and which do not offer them. There are many companies that treat their drivers well, offer good conditions, even good cabs, but not all. And we want drivers all over Europe to be doing really well. That is what this case is all about.  At the same time, we also have in mind that we naturally have different ideas and different regions in Europe and that the same pay cannot be paid everywhere. But we want to try to improve conditions for everyone, precisely because we also have a shortage of truck drivers.  And then the last thing I think is a pity: the bus drivers threaten to jump over the blade a bit. We simply need different rules for buses than for lorry drivers, because it is not the same as transporting freight or people. And I hope that we will find a solution to this.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: Madam President, I too am angry because the debate has been obstructed in recent hours, as there has been irregularity in the debate in recent months and we have not had a shared construction between MEPs, the European Union and truck drivers. That is why today, on the mobility package, we have a compromise that is not at the level and we have vices and holes that make there is anger, a lot of anger. We are looking at the future of three million truck drivers and we have to find a solution because we have to frame social dumping, we have to go to the detachment on the first day, and we have to stop with the motorway areas, the truckers themselves ask for it. I have seen truck drivers, but I have also seen the trucking unions, which also require a mobility package. That is why I am in favour of a vote in this Parliament, because tomorrow the balance of power may be less favourable to them. I am also in for the vote to take place in complete transparency and for the irregularities to stop. Finally, I am in favour of the text on cabotage being considered first because it is the only text that has been voted on in committee. I am finally in for democracy to take place fully.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Madam President, I wish to have European regulation for one reason only: to get rid of national laws in Germany and France, which of course are to protect the relevant industry in these countries. But I want it to be fair, transparent and beneficial for all Member States, not just some. At the moment, as is the proposal made, it is a small attempt at protectionism for a particular area of the European Union. I would ask colleagues not to hide behind the social argument. Yes, and I want very good conditions for everyone who works in this industry, and we can introduce them into these regulations. But at the same time, we must eliminate things that are against the Treaty and not risk not respecting the freedom of movement of labour and services. And I ask the Commission as the best solution, to withdraw... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: Madam President! The Kyllönen, Telička and Ertug compromises are a good basis for finally having proper and balanced rules that improve the working conditions of European drivers, create not only free competition, but also fair competition for businesses, and improve road safety. I therefore hope that a majority will support the great and good work that has been put into the three compromises when, hopefully, we will vote on this package at some point.  It is quite obvious that we are dealing with very destructive forces in this House which will try by all means to prevent us from getting a sensible agreement. These are people who want to continue to compete on really bad terms for drivers. We should certainly not accept that, so let us vote in favour of these compromises so that we get a proper agreement.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, it is good that there is a debate on this topic because it shows the different points of view and the complexity of the subject.  The Mobility 1 package under consideration is at odds with fundamental European values and the idea of a single market. In no way does this approach to the problem help to build a single market, but, on the contrary, undermine it.  Of course, international drivers deserve good working conditions because the profession is heavy and responsible, but this cannot be done by destroying an entire business that has developed on a free market basis, and which in my country alone creates 17% of GDP and gives a livelihood to nearly 500 thousand people. People.  The European Union is not getting stronger by opposing the countries on its periphery with those of the centre. This is not the expectation of European citizens. The rejection of two of the three files in the Committee on Transport and Tourism is a clear signal of the lack of consensus on the package as such and we cannot afford its irresponsible acceptance. An act that will have a devastating socio-economic effect on millions of citizens engaged in the sector.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which On this extremely important dossier, we are witnessing the speed with which a Parliament becomes incapable of taking decisions if we retreat to the respective national positions. We should actually be more than the lowest common denominator of our constituencies at home. We should work out the best solutions together and then adopt them. We have not managed to do this across the political groups, and accordingly we have failed abruptly both in committee and here in plenary.  The Rules of Procedure have been stretched to the point of being unrecognisable, and each side has been prepared to go to the extreme. You can see how it ended and how toxic it is when only particular interests are defended, when some retreat to the fact that their own perspective is the decisive one and other opinions are only an obstacle. This hypocrisy, from the concerned left to the new protectionists in my own group, will do more harm to the idea of Europe than anything else. And there were no compromises in the TRAN committee, only on cabotage.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Mobility Package is a laborious piece of work carried out by the relevant committees to put some order into a sector characterised by unbridled competition, which not only creates living conditions that are unacceptable to drivers but also puts the lives of all European citizens on the roads at risk and which contributes powerfully to CO2 emissions. While we wait for the availability of strong and fast rail freight transport, thanks to TNT, to reduce CO2 emissions on our roads, I believe it is essential to reach a reasonable agreement to modernise the sector and ensure the safety and quality of work for conductors. In particular, the very early introduction of the intelligent tachograph will make it possible to carry out effective controls and ensure compliance with the rules. I therefore believe, ladies and gentlemen, that we must have the courage to come to the vote and see whether this Parliament is capable of taking a decision on such an important issue.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: – Madam President, the agreements reached in the Committee on Transport were a complicated balance which was broken by the rejection in the June 2018 plenary of the three negotiating mandates. The Commission's three proposals, in my view, and I say this with all due respect, to the clear interests of some countries at the centre of the Union of locking up companies in the most peripheral countries carrying out transport services in these countries. Your transport companies, whether they want to or not, are more competitive. The defence position is to accuse social dumping and even attempt to impose European minimum wages. This stark stance is against the free market, and arguments for protecting the worker have been used to hide national protectionism.  Yes to the protection of workers; not to be used for other less dignified objectives. Restriction on driver cabin breaks, conducting cabotage operations, administrative requirements to prove minimum wages and employment contracts, and the inclusion of smaller vehicles – vans – within the scope of the legislation will entail higher costs in the performance of transport work carried out by companies in peripheral countries. The time for negotiation is up. This needs to be done by the next Chamber. And I, after fifteen years in the field of transport, will regret it.  I wish you luck and success.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
