text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I regret that on Monday there were not yet at least three people in the room, because then we would have finally rejected it. I have the impression that this is not about tired drivers at all, but something completely different: restricting market access to that part of Europe that has simply proved to be competitive in the international transport of goods and passengers, and that is it. They want to tell us: you have no right to be competitive. But if you're too competitive, we'll find all the instruments to get it out of your head. When I hear that if we do not pass this, you will take unilateral action, it is blackmail for me. Thus, the driver who handles import/export services is not a posted worker and the end. I propose not to vote and postpone this until the new term of office.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This banter, to the extent that the mobility package is ready to vote, is a problem in the context of the prepared regulation on the coordination of social security systems, which includes in Article 14 criteria confirming legal posting. Criteria which, due to the high mobility of international transport companies, are not achis. Every employer is exposed to a retroactive change from day to day. This applies to any European company. Thus, a French transport company may at any time be forced to work retroactively under German or Luxembourg law, a German company – under Polish or Romanian law. In order to avoid the chaos that will arise after the implementation of the mobility package, in which there are no provisions relating to Article 14 solutions, we are obliged to re-examine the package and make changes that will enable transport companies to function normally on the European market. Here in Parliament, we are responsible for preparing solutions that will facilitate the life and performance of duties in the common market, reducing the costs and burdens on European society.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, here yesterday in Strasbourg and today in Brussels, transport workers are calling for a fair future. I think we can say that outside this room, no one understands what we are doing here. This gnaws at confidence in the decision-making process from Brussels.  But the drivers don't let them mess around. So whether we vote today or in April on their work schedules, their wages and working conditions, drivers deserve a fair payment and they deserve enough rest. That was my commitment, that is my commitment and that remains my commitment, because lorry drivers and bus drivers are now being played off against each other in a race for the lowest wages and the worst working conditions. We must stop the exploitation of drivers along the highway in my country. We need to close the letterbox companies and we need to give drivers the certainty of decent driving and rest periods.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, the work we are doing and the discussion we have this morning is about the free movement of services and the free movement of workers, but also, for everything outside international transport, the condition of seconded workers. We have a general directive on the supervision of seconded work. And, as Mrs Jongerius has just said, there cannot be two categories of seconded workers in road hauliers: those who receive quality wages and social protection and those who receive discounted benefits. It is the bedrock of social Europe. We need to regulate international transport and regulate cabotage. We must avoid the national retreat and the decisions that would break up Europe and we must lower the legislation of road transport to 2.5 tonnes.  This is the Europe of citizens, this is the Europe of workers, it is the bedrock of Europe on which we must work.

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: – Madam President, first, allow me to congratulate President Tajani, who has taken the only possible decision. It is not on the side of the supporters, nor the opponents of this mobile package, but simply the rule of law in this Parliament. We have been subjected to literal blackmail several times by saying that if this package were not adopted, Member States would adopt unilateral decisions. Tell me is this the European Union or the European Union of Nations, which may be located 4 groups to the right of the socialist one. The corporate dumping imposed by western European companies actually caused social dumping, as only Western companies started paying twice as much to Polish, Romanian and Bulgarian carriers, and they caused this social dumping.  We suggested that we avoid this battle and not discuss this package at the end of the term, and you thought it was a weakness. We are ready for this battle and we will lead it to the end of this Parliament as well as the next one.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, this, in fact, that we are talking about a mobility package here is obviously a difficult issue from a political point of view, but this has turned into a saga. We are disrespecting all the work that has been done by colleagues in the various committees, by the rapporteurs and, above all, by the Committee on Transport. The process that this Parliament is going through is not democratic and it is not worthy of the European Parliament to examine 1,700 amendments at the last minute. The proposals, it must be stressed, have come from the European Commission, which is indeed already skewed, and therefore we need to give this note because all the work that has been done here in the European Parliament has been to balance that proposal that comes from the European Commission, in fact already with some imbalances. We have made an effort to respect one of the basic principles of the single market, of the free movement of workers and goods and therefore we prefer a non-agreement than a bad agreement and, therefore, I hope that the next legislative session will have a better agreement than the one we are today.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I want you to realise that, unfortunately, the mobility package in the form proposed by the Commission and its fellow rapporteurs will lead to the bankruptcy of hundreds of companies in the countries of Central and Eastern Europe and the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs.  The current provisions in the package not only have negative consequences for eastern carriers, but also run counter to the principles of the functioning of the internal market, while at the same time risking protectionism and distortion in favour of eastern companies. Colleagues, it is unacceptable that this is the legacy left by the eighth legislature of the European Parliament. It is obvious that we want protection and the strengthening of social rights for drivers, but the same colleagues who support these things must also support a fair and fair tariff per kilometre at European level, enabling companies in central and eastern Europe to cover all their costs and, indeed, to provide better social conditions. It's time to take... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, I have heard that there are supporters of the Mobility Package who have said they are fighting for the transport sector. How? By proposing measures to bankrupt him? Is that right? It was said earlier that a compromise had been reached, which is a good basis for voting. That doesn't answer the truth. It takes two sides to compromise, and here one was missing. For the first time in the history of this Parliament, someone wrote a report on behalf of a rapporteur without his knowledge. It's not a compromise. To be fair, with two weeks to go until the end of this Parliament, there is no time to prepare a sensible and balanced solution. The only solution is to leave it to the next Parliament, which has a five-year horizon. It's not about transport anymore, it's about common sense. It was the fourth consecutive attempt this Package has been made to spend, a fourth consecutive failure. That should tell you something, it's not a solution. A lot of things were achieved, but five times as much was wrong. We must leave this Package for the next Parliament.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Dear President, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs for their work. However, I have to say another. Colleagues, we have not been able to reach a compromise. What has been achieved is not a compromise. One thousand six hundred amendments are just another proof that there is no consensus and, unfortunately, we do not have time to achieve it– there is less than a month left until the end of the term of office. In order to find a way out of the situation, we should follow several rules. Firstly, the whole package must be agreed, all three documents, as they are interlinked. If we cannot agree on at least one, no agreement has been agreed on the whole package. Secondly, the single market remains our foundation, a set of rules that must be respected by all. Yes, we are all striving for more road safety, we want better working conditions for drivers, we want to fix many other things, we all want it, but we cannot allow carriers in some countries, companies operating under the same rules, to be excluded from the single transport market.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Dear President, honourable colleagues, I have had a job as Transport Minister for several years, and I am quite well aware of this issue. I will not talk today about certain social guarantees for workers, this is a very important issue, but very straight, and here it has been named, that is, the redistribution of the market, and in this way peripheral and small countries lose any access to the market in larger countries, which are geographically located at the very centre. Therefore, if this decision is taken, I would certainly like to thank President Tajani for making a sensible decision today and not voting. However, if a decision is made, I would like to see if those drivers who are taken over from countries such as Lithuania, Estonia, Latvia, from small countries and employed by foreign companies in Germany, the Netherlands and so on, whether they are paid the same salary as nationals of those countries for the same work, whether they return to their families within a week, or whether they live in Germany , as well as hotels and the like. Also, Commissioner, we should be concerned ... (language aborted)

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for What is happening today is a great tragedy, with large parts of the transport industry in Europe waiting for us here in this House to take a decision on this matter. What we are doing now is letting the transport workers down. We are betraying them for the sake of capital. Because that's what it's all about. It is a question of very many in this House voting for other cars to operate in other countries. As a Swede, for example, I do not accept having 3,000-4,000 foreign-registered trucks in my home country that constantly use the capital regulations to drive domestic transport. It kills the domestic market and that cannot be the point of being a member of EU cooperation: giving up its domestic market, because in the end, all countries will be faced with this problem. We need to get the business in order.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Madam President, the chaotic approach in which the discussion of this mobility package has become reflects very well how the institutions of the European Union are only cheered by the idea of improving, however modest, the working and social conditions of workers.  But what can be foresaw from the proposals on the table and the Council guidelines does not bode well: exclusions from the posting of workers, preventing it from count from day one and excluding bilateral transport and cabotage, cabotage rules which, creating an apparent limitation, make unlimited the numbers of operations of the dubious framework and an approach to working time and rest , which at best extends from two to three weeks, if not even four, the period from which drivers are entitled to enjoy the regular weekly rest period, i.e. a full weekend. This is your social pillar of the exploitation of workers.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, if the European Parliament does not decide today on the mobility package, then we will prolong the great uncertainty that is in place in the transport sector. I am now sorry to my colleagues, but I am very ill-expressed because I do not hear myself.  Under the Austrian Presidency, a compromise was reached in the Council on this mobility package. I believe that the European Parliament should also be able to reach a compromise. We know, after all, that the Posting of Workers Directive provides for action to be taken to ensure that both drivers and hauliers know under what conditions they will broadcast and operate. We are already witnessing a number of infringement proceedings, for example against Germany, against France – 'loi Macron' – and the Commission is delaying its investigation into these cases in order to discuss the mobility package. I therefore call for a compromise.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the mobility package must be approved because it brings benefits and competitiveness to the sector. I am thinking, for example, of cooling off to avoid systematic cabotage, the posting on international transport and the switch to the second generation intelligent tachograph from 2022; all measures that will allow the free movement of services in the transport sector in Europe, while ensuring healthy competition and social protection for workers in all Member States. The alternative is to find ourselves in chaos, with different legislation in the individual Member States: more Europe, nothing but a single market! However, I think we need more flexibility in driving and rest periods in order to have more road safety. An unbalanced distribution of driving and rest periods means determining situations with direct consequences for working conditions; means more effort, less concentration, more difficulty in recovery; means less safety for workers and for all road users.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, all the experience so far with the Mobility Package clearly shows that it is not wise pursuing it in its current form, especially if it means rushing it through chaotically in this mandate. It was a bad proposal to start with. Instead of sanctioning some national measures going against the single market, the Commission seemed to elevate the very same restrictive practices to EU level.  This proposal fails several basic tests of any piece of EU legislation. Firstly, it goes against the principles of the single market, stifles competition, discriminates against a large number of Member States, throws environmental consideration into the dustbin, and in no way does it pursue the best interests of all Member States and citizens. If we took a step back from simplistic slogans, we could see that in the pursuit of protectionist interests we decrease the competitiveness of our industries, create monopolies and raise greenhouse gases and prices for consumers. At the same time, we split Europe into two. We should definitely leave this package for the new mandate.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, I welcome the decision of President Antonio Tajani to apply Article 175, to refer the controversial package back to the Commission.  I call for calm and wisdom, because this dossier successfully fuels the Eurosceptic current in eastern Europe on the eve of the European Parliament elections, where road transport in general is the main source of income for tens of thousands of families.  The agreement is by no means an ideal, it must be re-discussed, it divides the market between East and West. There must be a balance between ensuring conditions for drivers, between ensuring the protection of road safety, on the one hand, but we must also take into account the observance of the free movement of persons and services within the European Union.

name: Michael CRAMER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The fact that we are under pressure of time today is primarily due to the Commission, because Juncker and Timmermans have excluded the Commissioner for two years. She wanted to present it, then we would have had more time. My second point is: control, of course. A law without control – there is no need for a law. But we have the tachograph, which was already present 15 years ago. The Commission has proposed to make it mandatory in 2036. Thank God the Council said: no, that must be as early as 2024. So that has to happen quickly. Without control, the law is of no use. And we know that there is a lot of fraud on the roads, which puts safety at risk. That is why we need the tachograph as quickly as possible, preferably as early as 2022.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, I think we all forget that pensions in some of these small countries are so low: EUR 300. We would all love German wages. We don’t have them. Don’t kill the countries that support Europe the most with this horrible, horrible directive. This will put people out of business – hard working people who want better wages. Help us get better wages; take time. Take time and help us. Let’s all work together to make a Europe that gives us all a fair wage, but don’t close us down. (Applause)

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of Commissioner Bulc, I would like to thank you all for today’s debate. All the elements of the negotiations are on the table now and it is time to vote.  The Mobility Package I, as tabled today, will improve road transport in the European Union. It will provide a level playing field for companies by having uniform rules, improved working conditions for drivers and enhanced control possibilities. It addresses many of the known problems in the sector today and, what is more, absence of new European rules will likely lead to a further deterioration of the situation in road haulage with wage and social dumping, fragmentation and protectionism all rising.  Let me give you examples. For companies the package will bring: a stable and predictable legal framework avoiding uncoordinated national rules, which risk fragmenting the single market; clear lists of documents to be provided and carried in trucks; clear establishment criteria eradicating the growing phenomenon of letterbox companies; a new cooling-off period to avoid the so-called systematic cabotage practices; the professionalisation of van operations with light commercial vehicles, which will be submitted to similar rules in international transport; and an agreed increased use of digital tools, reducing the administrative burden, for example for posting declarations.  For drivers the package will also bring important benefits: posting rules will apply to them with minimum wage and employment conditions of the host country; the regular return home or to another private place after a maximum of four weeks will be guaranteed; the conditions for regular weekly rests and obligations of employers to pay accommodation will be clarified; and better resting conditions will be ensured to avoid fatigue and prevent endangering road safety.  The package will finally provide for better enforcement with much earlier deployment of smart tachographs with geo-localisation to control posting and driving time; with reinforced administrative cooperation between national authorities; with the use of electronic freight documents to check cabotage rules; and with the use of digital tools to facilitate roadside checks.  Actually, we note that many among those important measures are in principle, largely consensual within your house. On all other outstanding points we strongly recommend support for the reports of the rapporteurs, which are striking the right balance.  I cannot stress enough the urgency of securing a positive outcome on the Mobility Package I ahead of the European elections. The state of the road market in the Union, the working conditions of our drivers and the environment in which our companies are operating are far too serious matters to be left at an unsatisfactory status quo for an as yet unknown period of time. The situation in the road transport sector is extremely critical and needs to be addressed.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the marathon has indeed reached the final stage and hopefully the Bureau will have the courage to put this to the vote next week and not to continue the gimmick with different rules of procedure. I would like to say that, when colleagues here have mentioned that it has been difficult to study the amendments that have been tabled, these same amendments have been running in this House for more than a year and a half, so that they have already been studied here if they wanted to, as have the compromises, that is to say, no content has changed much. When a few groups commented that they have not been allowed to participate enough, I would say to the ENF team, for example, that if you do not attend the first shadow meeting in the first six months, then at least the undersigned believes that interest has not been very high. And at this point, when the team here is clearly having its own discussions, I thought I would put a little supporting song on the Bureau so that we could remember all the euros we have borrowed from the drivers and we could return them to them. "I will pay for the nickel euro that I have borrowed from the driver. I'm sure you've missed it for a long time. You always have to pay what you're in debt in this world, you always have to pay, don't you, which we drivers get into debt." (Applause)

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I will be very short, but I know many people say this. First of all, I think we have had a good debate, and this debate has shown that the European Parliament is divided on the Mobility Package I, and now we have to take care that we are not taking the wrong decisions at the wrong moment. And when my colleagues Ertug, Pavel Telička and even the European Commission say that we have compromises, that is not the facts.  (Applause) We have only compromises on the cabotage, the file of Ismail Ertug. Why are we now in a difficult situation in this plenary? Because the Committee on Transport and Tourism – and that’s also my fault – was not successful in compromises. If we go on like this, it’s a very bad thing for the European Union and the European Parliament. (Sustained applause)

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I think the debate in the last one—and—a—half hours has showed us, once again, the necessity of a European-wide solution. I can assure all my colleagues within this House that I will use the next days once again to find a solution. I invite all my colleagues to come together and to be open to my proposals. Once again, we have found proper compromises which may not be acceptable for some colleagues, but we will try once again. I can assure you, as rapporteur and as coordinator for the Socialist Group, that I will try to find a compromise in the end. But what we have to do and what we have to deliver is that we have to guarantee that the legislation will be fixed within this term. We have to deliver a proper legislation that the drivers, and in particular the honest companies, deserve. This is our duty, and we have to do that. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place in the next session. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. It is high time that we finally stopped social dumping on our roads. Drivers should be paid the same for the same work, regardless of their nationality. And we must tackle unfair competition by restricting and more effectively controlling nomadic trucks, the so-called cabotage rides. All new and existing trucks should therefore be accelerated by smart, GPS-controlled tachographs by 2024. Road transport is by definition cross-border, especially in a small transit country such as Belgium. A level playing field is therefore essential. The proposal for a European ban on weekend cabin rest is also a good thing. This is important not only from a social point of view, but also for road safety. In Belgium and France this is rightly already prohibited. A cabin of 2 meters by 2 is far from the ideal place to relax, let alone spend weekend after weekend in. And the current driving and rest periods must be preserved. The proposals on the table to keep truck or bus drivers at the wheel for up to three weeks in a row with only two days' rest are unacceptable from a safety point of view.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. - I believe that the vote on the legislative package of mobility measures should be postponed for the new European Parliament and prepared in such a way that it is acceptable to all Member States, which it is not at the moment. The legislative proposal must be improved with a view to achieving equality between our road hauliers on the European market. In this proposal, central and eastern European carriers are marginalised and classified as 'second class citizens'. The biggest problem for Croatian carriers is their classification among posted workers, which is why they have a problem with accounting for and showing working hours spent outside Croatia, for which they have already started to be penalized in some Member States, and that this is a serious problem is also said by the fact that almost 90% of active transport companies registered in Croatia work abroad.  The proposed acts do not bring the necessary changes according to the situation and needs on the ground, nor do they correspond to the transport sector, let alone the economy in general.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. This package we are working on will have a lasting impact on the daily lives of millions of truck drivers. This is a sensitive issue that we must deal with seriously. We have been debating for two years now. This is the last chance of this Parliament to update the standards that govern the road transport market and especially the rights of drivers. Millions of workers are all too often considered second-class workers. Some in this house want to further degrade their working conditions. Weekly 45-hour rest in the cabin should be totally prohibited in the EU. The Court of Justice has ruled this practice contrary to our European standards. We have a historic opportunity, perhaps the only one, to build a social Europe. I call on this Parliament to adopt these three texts once and for all and, finally, to lay the groundwork for a Europe that protects; the one I have been calling for for years. This is the condition for the accession of our peoples to the European project.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. – The free movement of people, goods, services and capital is one of the EU's most important fundamental principles. International transport plays a key role in this. The European road transport sector directly employs five million Europeans. Traffic volumes are only projected to increase in the future. The social and market part of the mobility package at hand is a necessary clarification of the rules for the mobility sector and its workers. It is important to strike a balance between the proper working conditions of drivers and the freedom of carriers to provide cross-border services. However, the administrative burden on transport undertakings should not be increased. A great deal can be achieved through cooperation between authorities, increased supervision and the introduction of new technologies. The transport sector must gradually move towards a fully integrated market, but the sector must be clarified and the different national interpretations of the rules must be stopped. We need clear uniform rules of the game. I hope that agreement will be reached on the package in the course of this parliamentary term.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – This is a very important debate, because transport is the EU's nerve. The efficiency of transport determines the realisation of Union values such as the freedom of movement of persons and goods. International transport plays a major role in Polish. It is carried out by 35 000 companies with more than 250 000 people. International transport generates more than 6% of Polish GDP. The declared objective of the mobility package is noble. No one doubts that the working and living conditions of drivers should be improved, as it is very hard work, away from home, exposing you to various difficulties. The proposed solutions do not take into account the realities at all, such as the lack of parking spaces and hotels on the routes. As a result, the proposed package would not significantly improve the working conditions of drivers and would weaken transport companies from central and eastern European countries. Many of these companies would lose the chance to operate in the common European market. The situation of drivers would not improve, and the situation of many companies could deteriorate dramatically. I cannot therefore support the proposed mobility package, as the effects of the proposed legal solutions count, not even the purest intentions.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Mr President, thank you for the floor. I would like to present an oral amendment to one of my own amendment No 123 concerning Article 7(5)(g). I would like to replace the words ‘the fight against climate change’ with the words ‘tackling climate change’, in agreement with the two co-rapporteurs. Thank you for the consideration.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, this discharge of the European Commission. I would like to add that, as a Member for the Czech Republic, I am sorry that this report had to give such great scope to the cases of Prime Minister Babiš. This confirms that, unfortunately, the Czech Prime Minister has serious cases and is in a conflict of interest in terms of the money he draws from the European Union for companies he previously owned and has now placed in a trust fund. I will be very happy for the Commission to hear the clear provisions of this report and to complete the vetting of Prime Minister Babiš's conflict over the use of European money, so that it is clear and clear to what extent Prime Minister Babiš is in breach or not of European law. It is so serious that the five points of this report are devoted to his business, conflicts of interest and his person.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, it’s always about the money, isn’t it? The European Union has become a very good mechanism for taking wealth from the general population and redistributing it to people who are lucky enough – directly or indirectly – to be part of the system. To be fair, it isn’t unique in that regard; every system of government has that aspect to it. But what is unique is the way in which, by extending the difference between the people contributing and the people spending, it maximises the inefficiency that comes from a remote government. The fundamental role of any legislature is to hold the executive to account, but that dynamic doesn’t apply in this assembly, because for the sake of greater European integration this Parliament ends up always lining up with the Commission against the taxpayer in the cause of greater and greater integration. That has been the problem from the beginning.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, the GBP 500 million bill because the European Medicines Agency (EMA) could not get out of the 25—year lease on a building in Canary Wharf is deeply regrettable. What a waste. And, to my mind, what a waste to lose highly skilled jobs and research capacity from Britain. The EMA is a jewel in the crown, precisely because it attracts businesses and experts. Over the past two decades, it has been invaluable, simplifying and streamlining medicines regulation, allowing companies to get a medicine authorised in every EU country in one go. Alas for Britain, no more. A medicines manufacturer in my constituency has already set up a new parallel testing facility within the EU to enable it to sell into European Union countries in the future. More cost, meaning less investment in research and development, and for Britain more delays in getting medicines and a rising bill for medicines, and so less money for our NHS – the opposite of what people thought that they were voting for.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the ECR I would like to thank the co-rapporteurs and my fellow shadows for the positive and productive way in which we have worked together to agree on a compromise text on this very wide-ranging and challenging file. I very much welcome the consolidated instrument now as proposed by the Commission and believe that it will contribute to allowing the EU to act in a more effective, cohesive and cost-efficient manner in the areas concerned. At a time when political transition continues to destabilise the south as Russia seeks to undermine those countries in the Eastern Partnership and as the enlargement agenda faces challenges in moving forward, the Neighbourhood has never been so important as it is today to the European Union. Whilst I personally welcome the fully-consolidated instrument, I note that there are significant misgivings in this Chamber, including within my own Group, concerning certain aspects, and these discussions will now need to continue into the next parliament. Given the very strict geographic ring-fencing included within the instrument, however, I do not believe the consolidation will see funds diverted to one part of the Neighbourhood to the detriment of others.  As to the concerns that some had regarding the bringing together of development funds with more explicit foreign-policy tools, the requirement for 95% of funding to meet OECD official development aid benchmarks should reassure all of us. This is an increase on the 92% as proposed originally by the Commission. I also welcome the development of EFSD into the much more ambitious EFSD+ and a renewed external action guarantee. These proposals will see changes to the current relationship between the Commission and the European Investment Bank, but I am reassured by the commitment to a minimum level of allocation to the EIB, as is provided for in Amendment 52. Ultimately, as an outgoing British MEP due to Brexit, I’m sorry that I will not be here to be part of the ultimate negotiations for this instrument in the next parliament. Most of all, I’m sad that the UK will not be able to participate in something that is yet another reminder of the way that Europe’s voice and economy of scale is magnified when we are all working together.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Mr President, the fact that the European Union is devoting a part of its external budget to stabilisation and development of neighbouring countries, particularly the Balkans, is perfectly legitimate. However, our French delegation abstained on this report in expressing its reservations on two points on the so-called IPA III proposal. On the one hand, the funds for Turkey, which is a non-European regional power, seem to us to be too important even though the subjects of common concerns, such as migration, are the subject of specific financial agreements. On the other hand, the very name of this budget, "pre-accession instrument", introduces a very damaging confusion. Enlargement is a political process for which there is no unanimity, it is not a mechanical and financial process. Some of the countries receiving the so-called pre-accession funds are not even candidate countries. It would therefore be much more relevant to re-qualify this financial instrument and clearly disconnect it from the issue of enlargement.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Mrs Frédérique Ries, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing the environmental impact of certain plastic products (COM(2018)0340 - C8-0218/2018 - 2018/0172(COD)) (A8-0317/2018).

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, Commissioner Vella, I want to start this evening with a flashback and go back in time with all those in this Chamber who were with me that evening, the night of 18-19 December last year. This trilogue - and I have led a few here in the twenty years I have been in the European Parliament - where the European Union has said no to single-use plastics. Twelve and a half hours of marathon negotiations with the Council to bring to light the most ambitious legislation. We had no choice but to be exemplary and take the lead in leading the battle.  I have had to speak dozens of times already in committee, in groups, in plenary, in hearings. I recalled the figures, the images, the tragic situation of our oceans in the world, but also at home in Europe. Plastic poisons our seas, kills their inhabitants and threatens us at the end of the chain. Urgent action was urgently needed, starting with the 10 single-use plastics and fishing equipment, which account for 70% of all marine waste.  We have every reason to be satisfied with this agreement reached that night with the Austrian Presidency. Several victories are to be noted. First, the extension of the list of single-use plastics that will be banned in two years (2021, it's tomorrow) to the original list of known prohibitions, namely plastic cutlery, plastic plates, cotton rods, sticks for balloons, touillettes. We convinced the Council to add oxdegradable plastics and food cups and containers made of expanded Polystyrene, the refrigerant. This addition represents 30% of plastic waste.  We also maintained, and it was not easy in the face of a reluctant Council, the producer's expanded liability regime. This polluter pays principle is now at the heart of our legislation. We have secured an obligation for tobacco manufacturers to fund the collection, clean-up and recycling of cigarette butts as early as January 2023. That's a year earlier than the other producers.  One more point and not least, we got to add a 25% recycled content target for plastic bottles. Bottles, I remind you, are the number one item on the podium in number of objects that pollute our beaches and oceans. 25% recycled content by 2025, 30% by 2030. It is a fuel for the circular economy.  For cigarette filters, cellulose acetate, plastic, therefore, the Council and the Commission have not taken up our reduction targets and I regret that. On the other hand, we have obtained mandatory marking on packages to warn about their environmental impact. Few citizens know this too: a single cigarette butt thrown into the ocean pollutes between 500 and 1,000 litres of water. For food cups and packaging, the text now specifies an ambitious and sustainable reduction for 2026. We wanted numerical targets, we did not achieve them at European level. This task is referred to the responsibility of the Member States. Therefore, I urge the Member States here, of course, and in this regard, to move faster on Article 4, as a whole series of Member States such as France and Austria are doing, through the very recent and very ambitious statements of Chancellor Kurz, but also certain regions such as Wallonia. Our legislation will save consumers 6.5 billion euros and create between 30,000 and 50,000 jobs in sectors where there is real know-how in Europe. It is considerable and everyone is aware of it. It is more, so much more, than the 'straws' directive to which we are sometimes reduced. But that is not enough, we will move forward again, and on three axes at least. An ambitious review of EU packaging legislation, with an numerical target on packaging reduction; a major action plan against microplastics, because these are the macroplastics that we have targeted here; and then a real shift from Europe to the circular economy with quality recycling channels. One last very important word for me: the result I present to you is very clearly a team effort. Parliament, Commission, Council, we have worked together, a sacred union in the service of an ambition. So thank you Mr Timmermans for your commitment, thank you Mr Vella for your enthusiasm, thank you also to Daniel Calleja, from the DG Environment, to Minister Kostinger for the Austrian Presidency, and above all, my warmest thanks to my shadow rapporteurs, Mrs Auken and Mrs Boylan, Mrs Paolucci and Mr Demesmaeker, Mr Pedicini, Mrs. And in my crew, I add, it's essential, the citizens, those millions of Mobilized Europeans who have pressed us, encouraged us to place the cursor very high for the oceans, of course, for the environment, but above all and first and foremost for us and for our children.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the decision this House will take later today will put Europe’s plastics economy on a sustainable path and put Europe at the forefront of global action. It is also a concrete demonstration of the EU’s broader commitment to the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Never before has a natural environment that sustains humankind been under such strain. Never before has it been so important to put sustainable development at the very heart of everything we do in Europe and globally. The new Directive on single-use plastics will help change the way we design, consume and manage plastic products and waste. It will significantly reduce the negative impact of plastic pollution on the environment, in particular the marine environment. If we don’t change our ways now, we will choke our oceans with plastic. Scientific evidence is undeniable. So are the gravity and urgency of the problem. Europeans care about this and want Europe to show leadership in finding solutions and raising the standards across the globe. It was just as Ms Ries said just over a year ago when we announced in the European Plastics Strategy that we would come forward with a legislative proposal on single-use plastics. Today this House is about to take a final decision. The prospect of this new legislation has already boosted more sustainable business solutions, changed consumer behaviour and become a leading example in the world, even before its entry into force. A positive vote by the European Parliament will deliver a positive change in line with our shared circular economy in plastics strategy goals. It will stimulate innovation and investment in new products and promote new circular business models. The measures will also significantly reduce littering and plastic pollution in our marine waters. I really want to do a big shout out to Frédérique Ries and all her shadow rapporteurs for an incredible job. As she said just now, we worked on this together: three institutions, people on three sides, who all believed this could be done when people outside were saying it was almost impossible. So Frédérique and all the others, thank you very much for a great job. I now hand the floor to my colleague Karmenu Vella.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this legislation is one of the most called for and also one of the most supported EU initiatives among European citizens. Our main task now is to ensure that the ambitious measures enshrined in it are also quickly implemented in practice.  Prevention of plastic litter is a common task for public authorities, producers and consumers alike. All actors across the plastic value chain will have to work together. The agreed measures should improve the design of products, raise consumer awareness by labelling, and also reduce consumption by banning certain products for which more sustainable alternatives are available. The European Parliament also pushed for very strong measures to ensure that the bill for proper waste management and clean—up of litter is picked up by the producers, who have the greatest influence on improving collection of on—the—go consumption waste.  We will also have mandatory targets for recycled content in plastic bottles. This will truly change the very fundamentals of the plastics economy by giving a strong push for the secondary raw materials market. I should also mention that, while fully supporting the agreement reached in the interinstitutional negotiations, the Commission would like to make three declarations. Specifically, the no opinion clause as the rule of principle is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered, and this right should not be withheld without justification. Secondly, on the very short timeframes envisaged for the adoption of Commission implementing acts, as the Commission is concerned about the feasibility to comply with these deadlines in time. Lastly, on the unnecessary inclusion of a definition of biodegradable plastic, because it does not have a direct impact on the directive implementation.  Clearly, we should all be very proud of these new rules because they tackle pollution from single—use plastics and fishing gear in such a comprehensive manner. Once implemented, it will not only prevent plastic pollution, but also make the European Union the world leader when it comes to the most sustainable plastic policy. The European Parliament has played a very major and essential role in laying the foundation for this transformation, and I sincerely hope that you will all give your support to make it happen.  Once again, I would like to join my colleague, First Vice—President, Frans Timmermans, and I would like to thank, first of all, the rapporteur, Frédérique Ries, the shadow rapporteurs and all MEPs involved, as well as our DGs.  Statements by the Commission (in writing) Proposal of Directive on the reduction of the impact of certain plastic products on the environment COM(2018) 340 final; 2018/0172 (COD) Commission statements in the context of the inter-institutional negotiations The Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of Regulation 182/2011 to invoke Article 5 § 4, second subparagraph, point b) in a systematic manner. Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered. Given that it is an exception to the general rule established by Article 5 (4) recourse to second subparagraph, point b), cannot be simply seen as a "discretionary power" of the legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified. While the Commission notes the agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council on the recourse to this provision it regrets that such justification is not reflected in a recital. __________________________________ The Commission regrets the short deadlines for the adoption of implementing acts and guidelines referred to in Articles 4(2), 7(2), 9(2), 13(4) and 11a and expresses concern about the feasibility to comply with these deadlines in time. __________________________________ With regard to the notion of biodegradability, the Commission will carry out the task referred to in Article 15(3)(d) of the Directive based on the specific mandate included in that article.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. – Thank you, Honourable President, honourable Commissioners, colleagues. Indeed, this issue is extremely important and is already, in my opinion, very late. But, as they say, it's better late than never. But, first of all, I would like to congratulate the Commission, the rapporteur responsible, and the Council on a really balanced agreement on solutions to reduce the use of single use of plastic products. As the responsible rapporteur for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, I am pleased that, in principle, the proposals I have submitted have been supported by both the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on the Environment, and I regret that my proposal to set specific targets and targets for plastic reductions remained unsecured. And it was left to the sleek and low-binding phrases – ambitious, sustainable, significant. The issue of microplastics and proper plastic collection from farmers remains unresolved.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Rapporteur: Mr PECH. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Commissioner, Deputy Commissioner, plastic has a negative impact on marine biological resources and their host environments, because it also harms fishing activities and carries a risk to human health, given that this fragmented waste ends up in the food chain again and therefore also on our tables. A recent report by The Ocean Cleanup has highlighted that the plastic island in the Pacific, and unfortunately it is not the only one, is getting bigger and bigger, covering an area of three times France with 80 000 tonnes. Yet there are still those who deny the evidence. I believe that fishermen must play a key role in tackling the problem of plastic, both as a prevention and as potential guardians of the sea, as demonstrated by numerous initiatives by the Fishing for Litter Commission. I will end with the words of Greta, who says "we need hope, but even more than hope we need action. When we start acting we will find reasons to hope everywhere." It is therefore from immediate action that we must start, because there is not much time left.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Plastic pollution of the world's oceans is a huge problem. There is this plastic vortex in the Pacific, which is already five times larger than my own country, Germany, and that is why we urgently need to act.  Wherever an equivalent replacement is possible, we need a ban. This is the case, for example, with plastic plates, where there are, of course, paper plates as a substitute, preferably washable plates that can be used several times. And where the replacement option is not yet so mature, there is the reduction strategy. I would also have argued for us to make the reduction targets a little clearer, but we must now appeal to the Member States to make this as strict as possible.  I would like to thank all those who have helped: Frédérique Ries, of course, but in the GROUP, above all, Karl-Heinz Florenz and the President-in-Office of the Council, Elisabeth Köstinger, who also helped us to have this result through skilful negotiations.  At one point, I am glad that we did not go over the top: there were amendments from the Greens to ban the rise of balloons, and I believe that this would have been disproportionate. Here, too, we should focus on innovation, on new products, but not on people spoiling the fun.  Elsewhere, I agree with Frédérique Ries, who will need new, further steps in the next period: on packaging waste and on the subject of microplastics, we expect legislative proposals and we must act so that we can tackle the problem actively here too. For today, however, this is a very, very important first step: we are strengthening the circular economy, we are doing something to prevent marine littering, and I have rarely seen environmental legislation being viewed so freely by the citizens, and that is why we should adopt this by a very large majority.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask if Mr Liese is really happy that he and others successfully removed the very onerous task of marking a packet of balloons – not the balloons themselves, but the packaging of the balloons – asking people to dispose of them responsibly. We know that balloons are in the top 10 list of items found, and now – thanks to Mr Liese and his colleagues – children are spared the horror of such a labelling requirement and instead will continue to witness the horror of poisoned wildlife.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for the question! I can make that clear again. I believe that we should indeed focus on alternatives and technology. And this warning would also have meant that we do not want balloons to go up in the air at weddings, at children's birthdays and so on. And I think it just goes too far. The European Union is not concerned about this. We should focus on innovation, not bans. And we should not send out the signal from this Parliament: we want to spoil the fun of the people.

name: Massimo PAOLUCCI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I too would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for the excellent work we have done together.  I believe, ladies and gentlemen, that with our vote in a few hours' time, by adopting a directive on single-use plastics, we are taking an important step forward: reduction of consumption, new rules for design, more information for consumers, more separate collection, greater responsibility for producers. I believe that we must be proud of a vote that takes us two important steps forward: firstly, to counter a wrong culture of waste – waste of raw materials, unbridled consumerism; secondly, to defend the oceans, one of the earth's fundamental lungs. In short, affirm new production and consumption models based on reuse and recycling. I am well aware that it depends not only on Europe, but I believe that Europe's ambition is a foreman, it is an example, that it is already being imitated and that it can take us further forward. I have heard the wrong things in recent hours: ours is not a battle against the chemical industry, which is a strategic sector of our industry. On the contrary, we believe that we can take a step forward to stimulate technological innovation and change consumption habits. In short, the way to produce more, better and have new jobs.  Vice-President Timmermans said this, and I agree: it seemed to be an impossible objective and we succeeded in a short time and with a very large majority in Parliament and in European society. Well, I think that is the purpose of this vote: with our vote, at the end of the parliamentary term, we are giving a clear signal that the transition to the circular economy is not only urgent but possible.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last Sunday, for the tenth time, a major clean-up operation was held on our Flemish coast: 7 500 volunteers collected no less than 11.5 tonnes of waste, twice as much plastic waste as last year. Nice action with a concrete result, but above all also an action that puts us on the facts and on the problem. Indeed, more than 80% of litter found on our beaches is plastic, and about half of it comes from disposable products. Without action, by 2050, more plastic will swim in the sea than fish. With an ambitious package of tailor-made measures, we want to turn the tide and keep litter out of our seas and oceans.  Plastic is a valuable material, but we handle it very carelessly. We must make full commitment to sustainable and responsible management of plastic across the entire value chain. This is not only good for the environment, but also for the economy and for the climate, because we prevent CO2 emissions. With every ton of plastic we recycle, we take a car off the road. It is also essential that producers now contribute to the clean-up of litter. 90% of plastic drink bottles have to be collected separately and we are also resolutely fighting with the plastic cigarette filters. I would like to thank Mr Ries and the other members of our negotiating team, including the Commissioners for their appreciated support and for the good result.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: My impression is that we have already been eating plastic for a long time now.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Over the next ten years, we will have major challenges ahead of us, the challenges of plastics. I am convinced that part of the discussion in relation to these challenges will be based on what we could call the 'Sergio Leone logic' – The good, the bad and the ugly, Il buono, il gross e il cattivo. There is very good plastic. Anyone affected by cataracts – and this will happen for most of us – can replace the cloudy lens with a plastic lens, and see clearly into the future. It may be needed especially in the Commission, but it may not be completely wasted in this House either. There is of course a lot of evil plastic, plastico gross, one would say according to Sergio Leone. In order to meet the challenges, we will need an investigation into all the plastics around us. Technically, we have 18 different plastics in the world, and if we manage to classify them in any way, we may also meet these challenges. Getting this investigation into is, of course, the Commission's task for the forthcoming parliamentary term. We also have what you might call fake plastic, plastico cattivo. During the discussion of this issue, I was visited by the Norwegian Minister for the Environment. He was previously responsible for sports facilities in Oslo and he found out that he had achieved a terrible amount of microplastics and nanoplastics by building plastic fields for football. So he came to what you can say "Ångermanland". This is an example of evil. But we also have good examples of good plastic. This whole discussion has led to the production of paper coffee cups in Finland, without plastic, and we also have water-soluble plastic, so we may be able to rise to this challenge of investing a little more in teaching and research.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Mr President! First of all, thank you to Frédérique Ries for an excellent job. Thanks also to Frans Timmermans - it has been a pleasure this time. This is the second time we have had a lot to reduce plastic. Last time it was about plastic bags, and then it was a minor war. Now I have to say that we have a whole different tone. It is the repentant sinner who has found the way, the truth, and the light, and I am so grateful for that. Of course, it has also become easier now that it has become a popular issue at the same time - without, however, accusing Frans Timmermans of populism. I've had a real commitment.  We have a good law here, but we must remember that this is only the first step. Hopefully it is a safe step that will take us forward - initially to stop the supply of pollution. Every minute, the equivalent of a truck full of plastic waste is poured into the oceans - so much more needs to be done. In this context, I would like to warn against all the smart solutions with biodegradable plastics. It is all as problematic as the ordinary plastic. It was great that we got banned oxo-plastic, which is really bad: the fake degradable plastic that just falls apart and turns into microplastics. So we need to be vigilant, because there is a huge interest in coming up with smart alternatives. Thank you so much for this: we continue the good fight and we have a chance to win it!

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, today we will approve the Single-Use Plastics Directive, one of the highest profile pieces of legislation in the EU, and we have a good outcome thanks to the rapporteur, despite the Council dragging down the ambition. But I would caution and say hold off from popping the champagne corks just yet, because the truth is that the linear plastics economy will be continuing business as usual.  We have some very positive measures in this directive, but we should all acknowledge that we are still just scratching the surface here. Banning cotton buds and plastic plates is a good move, but where is the systemic change that we need to achieve? How do we stop the 13 million tonnes of plastic from entering the ocean every year? The plastic spoon, we know, is thanks to the fracking boom and the fossil-fuel industry’s desperate attempts to secure its future. So plastic will remain cheap and ubiquitous, unless we take on the fossil-fuel industry and strongly regulate the plastic manufacturers. We need to stop talking about the circular economy in just fancy words, and we really need to think about how we put this principle into action.  So what’s great is that this directive has raised awareness about plastics, but we absolutely need to hit home that the answer to the plastics crisis is not about individuals rejecting straws or even campaigning for a straw ban – it’s about radically changing our production lines.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, at last something good about this European Union, which is very often unseated and opposed by its citizens. Finally, in short, something that meets the needs and demands of citizens, a directive that will allow us to clean up our seas and also to prevent, for example, in 2050 there being more plastic than fish in our seas. Finally, those plastic containers in supermarkets for food, plastic plates, plastic glasses, cutlery, all those products that already have a single-use alternative without plastic will disappear. That's a big goal. Cigarette butts will also disappear from our beaches, because we have finally managed to force the tobacco industry to bear the costs of collecting, transporting and treating cigarette butts. However, I think it is scandalous that in this directive we have not succeeded in imposing a binding target for the definitive reduction of plastic bottles as well. I would like to remind you here that the European Union produces 50 billion plastic bottles every year and this plastic does not dissolve over time, so it is easy to make an account: in 20 years, a trillion plastic bottles are accumulated. This has a terrible impact on our environment and our seas. It is also scandalous that some Members have obstructed those innovative solutions based on biodegradable and compostable plastic simply because they come from an all-Italian innovation. I believe that these Members, and the political forces that have supported these positions, must take a great responsibility, because they have prevented us from taking a step forward for a better future and for a more protected environment.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the industrial revolution of the 19th century and the omnipotence of chemists over the next two centuries brought real progress in our daily lives. Unfortunately, this progress has suffered greatly from the crazy productivity imposed by globalization. The situation is critical with regard to the plastic waste of single-use objects, most often food, that overwhelm the planet, both at sea and on land. Always less household chores to go faster and faster, which is obviously a consumerist societal evolution. So, yes, this complex subject must be tackled head-on at all levels by ensuring that the manufacturers support Member States for increased research on the possibilities of material substitution, by driving consumers and distributors to more responsibility, and by strongly encouraging the Member States themselves to commit themselves to preventing the creation of the sixth plastic continent.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thought I had a minute and a half. It seems clear to me that there is a misunderstanding here because if, as Pedicini said, we have eliminated single-use plastic products but there will be single-use products of any other material, I would like to understand what the environment gains. I will not argue that 95% of the plastics found in the oceans – United Nations studies – come from eight Asian and two African rivers. We must set an example: but too much has been done here! On a subject that had to be done calmly, there was an electoral 'spottone', dear Vice-President Timmermans – you who will be the Socialist Spitzenkandidat – an electoral spotton that I wish you would bring you badly, because you cannot put a flag on the skin of the Italians, because you have eliminated – and I would like to know what it has to do with the circular economy – and only products manufactured in Italy are banned. And of course, all the other countries said: "How nice, we make a free commercial and italy pays the bill!" But I don't think it's just Italy that's going to pay for it, because we're kidding each other here! I repeat: some good things are there but some major mistakes have been made! Nor have studies by the University of California and Ulster been taken into account, according to which removing these single-use products will increase contamination, even serious ones, with related hospitalizations. So, I say, a missed opportunity! But you don't marry dried figs.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I see this very differently from Mrs Gardini. Vice-President Timmermans and Commissioner Vella, congratulations on this European directive against disposable plastics. You have seen that there is a great deal of popular support for what we are doing here. And there is also something visible in the European Union's environmental policy.  In fact, we should also be promoting this in the European elections. This is not populism, but a visible contribution to the fact that we are trying to eliminate litter and pollution of the environment. Even though the majority of this plastic waste in the seas comes from other continents, it is nevertheless right that we, as Europe, as the European Union, set a good example. It is never forbidden to go ahead with this. Large quantities of these disposable products also end up in the North Sea, including in the Baltic Sea.  I believe that the directive is also a contribution to a better awareness that the rapid discarding must simply be stopped. We need more durable products and not these disposable products, which have also been thrown away after single use. I also see that we need to do a lot for the design of packaging. We need recyclable plastic materials and not this mixed pickles, which makes these big problems in recycling afterwards. I also think that it is right for manufacturers to assume their responsibilities. So a good deal of environmental policy in the European Union during this parliamentary term.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, plastic is absurdly widely used in our daily lives because it is cheap. So plastic is used in a pass and the plastic waste mountain grows. Our beaches, seas, fish and marine animals do not benefit from all this waste. By banning and restricting the ten disposable plastic products that contribute to the plastic soup, we are taking a first step today to make our seas and beaches cleaner. In addition, this reduces plastic consumption and therefore production.  Plastic is made from oil, among other things, so today we are doing a double blow: we are abolishing cotton buds and all those other products and we are reducing our dependence on oil countries like Salafist Saudi Arabia.  I'm very supportive of that.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: Mr President, it is very nice that we are standing united on the shoulder to celebrate the banning of disposable plastic in Europe. And rightly so, because I honestly believe that this is a very good result. But we must also remain self-critical, because this measure was already announced in 2010 in the roadmap for efficient resource use in Europe. So it seems that it has taken eight years for this bill to find the exit of the Berlaymont building.  It shows once again that the sense of urgency is still far too low. The sense of urgency that business as usual simply can't do anymore. The sense of urgency that agricultural policy, cohesion policy, transport policy, economic policy, etc. and so on must really be radically changed. But let us use the unity we are showing today to accelerate this transition to a truly clean economy, together with much more urgency.  (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, sir, for the good-spirited acceptance of the question. My question is this: we all agree that we need to make changes and improve the environment, and this is a particularly important issue. However, manufacturing and production always need time to change. You stressed several times in your remarks: urgency, urgency, urgency. Would you not accept that the speed of the motion that we have before us will actually lead to job losses? And, if it does lead to job losses, how many are acceptable? 500? 1 000? 10 000? Where does it stop? Where do we take into account the needs of manufacturers, as opposed to the prerogative for change?

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: blue-card answer. – This is the difference between a conservative and a liberal. I believe in a progressive future. This is a story of the past. We’ve always heard that new technology was going to cost us jobs and whatever, but in reality it only brought us a brighter future. The same will happen with a cleaner economy. It will bring us new jobs, additional jobs, and, as a bonus, you will get a clean planet. What else would you like to wish for?

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Ries, for the great work on reducing single—use plastic, which is indeed a great step forward. As my colleague, Margrete Auken, already said, she has been fighting with the Commission for a while on plastic action, and it is great that we are taking this action now. But it is important also to look ahead because we are not there yet. Commissioner Frans Timmermans said that we are on a path for a sustainable future. That might be a bit too much for this step. Because, yes, it is absolutely great to really reduce single—use plastic, but we all know that the big amounts of plastic are in the packaging. For example, the Commission floated the idea too two years ago –last year even – about a tax on plastics, but we haven’t heard any more about that. If I read the plastics strategy, there are still some things that need to happen. So I think what would be very important now is, not only to celebrate this moment, but also to hear from the Commission which next steps we can expect to reduce our plastic addiction.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Mr President, by 2050 there will be more plastic in the ocean than fish. And plastic is becoming the first threat to marine life. Today, five billion tons of plastic lie in the oceans and in nature and by 2050, if nothing changes, 30 billion tons of plastic will be produced, that is three times more than all the plastic produced to date. In reality, our land has become the plastic planet and the ecological catastrophe is major. The plastic directive could have been a turning point, but in reality it is only a small step in the right direction when everything should have been revolutionized and a new model invented, free of plastic at all. I think we should be ashamed of what we have done with the planet and we should be ashamed of the species that suffocate our culture at all waste.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I believe the single-use plastics directive is unfairly treating expanded polystyrene packaging, known as EPS, and used for takeaway food and drinks. By banning it all of the other items on the list of banned items included in Annex, Part B, of the proposal for a directive – plastic straws, cutlery, stirrers, cotton buds, etc. – are specific product items and not a whole category of products made from a particular material. EPS is the only specific material that has been singled out on the banned list, yet the statistics upon which this Commission based its proposal do not show that EPS food service packaging is a significant problem on EU beaches. All types of food and beverage service packaging and other items combined, including EPS products, account for just 4%-6% of beach litter. A ban on EPS food and drinks containers was included in a last-minute amendment announced just before the plenary vote. That set up the European Parliament’s negotiating mandate ahead of the informal trilogue. There was no opportunity to counter the misinformation circulated at the time. It was incorrectly stated as justification for banning EPS packs that 31% of beach litter is polystyrene. This is entirely untrue. In fact the Commission’s figures show that 31% of beach plastics is a make-up of mixed plastic fragments of varying sizes, including some expanded polystyrene. Some of the EPS pieces in this fraction derive from sources other than packaging e.g. fish boxes and construction products. Therefore, banning these products is both unjustified and disproportionate. The benefit to the environment will be virtually nil. This measure, rushed through without adequate research, will result in companies being put out of business and hundreds of people losing their jobs. This is not speculation. This is fact. In my own constituency 250 jobs will be lost by 2021 if this goes unchallenged. Extrapolate that across the EU – and there are 29 businesses directly affected by this – and thousands of European citizens will lose their livelihood. The EPS ban should, and will, be challenged. The correct source of action is to remove EPS from the banned list. I would just like to display to you the flag of the area where the jobs will be lost. Please take notice. This is the Black Country. Two hundred people will lose their jobs because of this.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we really want to tackle the problem of single-use plastic pollution in the oceans and seas, we must act where we can achieve a positive and virtuous leverage effect. The only important and lasting solution is to impose separate collection of that waste in Asian and African countries, which are really responsible for marine pollution.  What is the point for Europe, as is happening, of conceding free trade agreements with countries that do not share our environmental policy? Almost as if we did not know that geographical borders do not stop pollution of the seas, air and land. Paradoxically, these trade agreements encourage low-cost production, which is not environmentally sustainable, and unfair competition from our companies. I mean, cuckolds and decks. The ideological thrust of directives such as this, which are apparently environmental and with at least doubtful legislative procedure, will affect the workers and companies in our countries who will pay the price for these myopic choices. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Peter LIESE
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Ladies and gentlemen, you have told the fairy tale that we have unfortunately heard over the last few days and weeks: only Europe is acting. I ask you: are you aware of the world map of plastic bans, and do you know, for example, that India, a country with more inhabitants than the European Union, has long since adopted legislation similar to the one that we are probably adopting today?

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: answer to a "blue card" question. European Community data show that 95% of the pollution of the seas and oceans by plastic comes from Asian and African countries, the same countries with which we are concluding trade agreements, without thinking in the slightest about what the environmental aspect is, in addition to human rights, in addition to women's rights, as well as the prohibition of child labour. This seems to me to be a great inconsistency on the part of this European Community. This was the thing that had to be emphasized: it was not against the environment but it is the way of working of this community that does not work.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, this is a very good first proper step in banning these single—use plastics, but do not get overly excited that we can solve the problem. I do hope that the Commission can ensure the next steps concerning the circular economy and that the plastics would then follow when the new Commission is in charge.  What I mean is that plastics – and the microplastics and nanoplastics which are actually the most severe problem – do come from other sources also. They are used in detergents, cosmetics, packaging and fertilisers, and so we eat them because they get into a very tiny format. There are also many other forms, and we have to remember that a significant part comes from textiles and tyres as well.  I do hope that the Commission will take charge and make separate programmes on textiles and tyres, and start by banning the plastic in food packaging, because there is the endocrine disrupter problem there also, and that we can have used—carbon—based safe packaging.  There’s a lot to be done in the future also.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Sur President, nirringrazzja lir-rapporteur Frédérique Ries, u anki lix-shadow rapporteur min-naħa tal-S&D, Massimo Paolucci, li flimkien miegħu ħdimna biexħna naħeraw ruħna li jkollna liġi li tkun qed tindirizza l-issues ewlenin. Ninsabu f'sitwazzjoni fejn hawk without me, trakk mimli skart tal-plastic qed jispi大a fl-ibħra tagħna. Dan l-ammont ser jirdoppja sas-sena elfejn u tletin.  Il-ftehim milħuq dwar is-"single use plastics" huwa pass importanti għaliex din il-liġi hija eżempju ikear ta' "policy" li qed tgħin biex tinbidel il-mentalità. Qed tgħin biex tidħol kuxjenza akbar fost i大-ikeittadini, partikolarment iż-żgħażagħ u t-tfal tagħna li saru ħafna aktar konxji dwar l-alternattivi li jeżistu. Jiena nemmen li hemm 3 issues li issa rridu nindirizzaw. L-ewwel - nin大entivaw l-użu mill-ġdid tal-plastic li ntellgħu mill-baħar kif qed tagħmel kumpanija magħrufa billi pereżempju tagħmel slippers minn plastic li jitla' mill-baħar.  It-tieni - li na大大ertaw ruħna li l-plastiks i jispi大大awx fl-ibħra tagħna fl-ewwel lok. Sistema fejn fliexken tal-plastic jerġgħu jsiru fliexken tal-plastic hija importanti, l-istess kif inhi importanti sistema ta' "upcylcing" fejn għandek fliexken tal-plastic li qegħd isiru material aktar ta' livell għoli, inkluż ukoll-ħwejjeġ. It-tielet - li nippromwovu aktar alternattivi bħall-każ ta' kumpaniji li qegħdin jipproduu "cutlery" minn material differenti, inkluż ukoll material li jista' jittiekel.  U dan huwa l-pass li jmiss biex fuckmplimentaw ix-xogħol li qed jagħmlu kumpaniji privati, diversi organizzazzjonijiet, żgħażagħ u tfal bix-xogħol tagħhom ta' kuljum biex ineħħu l-plastiks mill-ibħra u l-nji kampa tagħna.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Well, where are the times when we all wanted to wear a nylon shirt? That was in the early 60s.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
