text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to thank Mrs Ries for the wonderful result. As a negotiator for the Liberals on the ECON Committee, the issue is also close to my heart. From the outset, opinions were divided on how to tackle the problem of plastics. Personally, I am still firmly convinced that plastics themselves are not the cause of the problem, but the way we deal with it. Stopping single use, encouraging reuse and recycling must ensure that no more plastics enter our environment.  But the real solution, of course, lies in research and innovation, the search for materials that are truly environmentally friendly. Whatever my view or yours, one thing is certain: the European citizen is calling for urgent action and this directive is in response to it. I therefore call on my colleagues to adopt this directive and to clean up the plastic soup together.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time to put an end to the invasion of disposable plastic, we no longer have the luxury of waiting. Not a week goes by without a massive stranding of dolphins or starving whales, their stomachs filled with kilos of plastic. Not a week, either, without an alarming study on micro-plastics, these plastic confetti suspended in the oceans, but also in the air. We don't want any more fragmented plastics or Styrofoam food packaging. This report, Frédérique, on behalf of Parliament, you led it masterfully. Member States no longer have the moral right to procrastinate, they must implement the measures adopted as soon as possible, without delay, and without giving in to the sirens of the industry, always quick to draw blackmail on employment. The plastics industry has a strong interest in evolving and getting out of disposable cultivation. Changing the model will open up new markets, the expanded responsibility of the producers we have obtained extends the principle of polluter pays. Profit at all costs is over.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Mr President, as with the climate, it is our youth who call us to order with the plastic soup and who put it on the map. Just think of the young heroes like Boyan Slat, the creator of the Ocean Cleanup, and the ten-year-old Lilly with her Plastic Pickup mission. Worldwide, young people take the lead in protecting our planet and their initiatives fill me with pride, but also with deep shame. They clean up our waste, waste that destroys our oceans and biodiversity.  The new rules for disposable plastics are a good start, but not nearly enough. Worldwide, waste from Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Nestlé, Marlboro, McDonald's, Red Bull, Unilever, Mars and Procter & Gamble is the most commonly found in cleanup operations. When are we going to take them? We cannot leave the health of the environment and of people and animals to the profit of these multinationals.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, I am concerned that the EU is fraudulently harassing British innovation in degradable plastics. Parliament has not yet been made aware that, if we accept the reference to oxo-biodegradable plastics in Article 5, we would be evading the European Union’s own rules for banning substances. Please refer to Articles 68 to 73 of the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) legislation. Surely you won’t ignore your own legislation.  The Commission has acted under Article 69, requesting the European Chemicals Agency (ECHA) to study oxo-degradable plastics, because the Commission thought that they created microplastics. ECHA has not yet completed its study, but did advise – after ten months of work last October – that they were not convinced that microplastics were formed. If, and only if, ECHA were to recommend a restriction, this would need to be considered by two committees, according to Articles 70 and 71 of REACH, and put out to public consultation before any restriction could be implemented. None of this has been done. You’re breaking your own rules. Therefore, the reference to oxo-degradable plastic must be removed from Article 5 before the Directive is published in the Official Journal.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: blue-card question. – To put it briefly, will you deny that oxo just makes plastics fall apart? Will you insist that oxo turns into nature again after hundreds of years? Oxo is probably the worst of these crazy degradable products. I know that Symphony, which produces plastics, and you will accept that, is very close to tyres. That’s why we are having all these battles in this House on oxo. Will you deny that oxo just makes plastic degrade into small pieces? Do you really think it’s not the case?

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card answer. – I absolutely deny it, because you’re confusing oxo-degradable with oxo-biodegradable, and the system that Symphony uses actually destroys the plastic. It is no longer plastic by the time their system is finished. I have proved that in my own home. They gave me a blue card, effectively. I put it in a box and five years later, there was nothing there.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Well now, that’s settled. Thank you very much.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, plastic pollution of the oceans is a major issue, so it is our duty to be ambitious and I believe that the agreement reached between the institutions is a good agreement. It takes into account the real possibilities of replacing plastics and commits us to a path of progress. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Ries, and the shadow rapporteurs for their work. I will not go back to the proposals in this text. I support the general direction and welcome in particular the pollution they represent, on land and in the oceans, the ban on oxodegradable plastics. I welcome the fact that, in the final text, we find the idea that I have advocated, the establishment, in the coming years, of a standard clearly defining the biodegradability of plastics in the marine environment, based on research and innovation, in order to guarantee their safety. I am pleased to be able to testify here that in my various travels in plastics companies, the logic of circular economy and the reuse of plastics are already well integrated. And the use of biodegradable plastics is bio-based. Companies are investing in innovative solutions to enable the recovery of plastics in bioplastics, recycled raw materials. Nevertheless, we can and must do better, and that is what we are asking for in this text. It is therefore our duty to ensure that we will support our ambitions with the necessary means.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the young people who have taken to the streets of the world in recent weeks have asked us to act urgently, to do something quickly for sustainable development. Well, Europe is acting and is scoring another point in favour of the environment and the fight against plastic pollution, especially in our seas, not only in the oceans but also in the Mediterranean Sea, where entire waste islands have been created. With this new directive we are banning single-use plastic products such as cotton buds, dishes and dishes, which are among the main causes of marine pollution, for which alternatives are already available on the market, recyclable and with the possibility of lasting longer. At the same time, we also encourage the use of recycled plastic in products, setting a minimum content, for example, for beverage bottles. In short, today we are taking an important step towards the transition to a circular economy, the importance of which we in Europe immediately understood and first ly understood in order to maintain a high level of growth and well-being of our citizens, protect the environment and continue to be competitive in the world. It will be a long process, because we should change our production and consumption patterns, but I believe that this is the only way ahead.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Ries, and Mr Florenz, who has been our head of Circular Economy, for all the work done in this dossier, which is part of the main corpus of the 2018 Circular Economy Package, together with other dossiers such as port facilities for receiving waste from ships. This dossier is especially important. European citizens are very aware of the waste that plastic generates; some even advocate a total ban on this material, but we must be both pragmatic and understand that there are still fields where there are no alternatives. That is why, from our parliamentary group, we want to encourage investment for greater innovation by industry that makes alternatives to plastics viable and replaces them with new, more sustainable materials. A transition in the use of these materials must be ensured to reduce our footprint on the environment in which we live. We owe it to the generations that come.  Moreover, this transition to a fully circular economy is an opportunity for the generation of new jobs with great added value and economic growth for the re-industrialization of the European Union. And it is the responsibility of all Europeans who are called to the polls on 26 May to support with our vote parties that are working to ensure an orderly transition for a more economically, socially and environmentally sustainable world.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, there is no need to theorize more about plastic pollution, just look at the images of a whale in Thailand, who died suffocated by plastic bags. She had ingested eighty-five of them. You also observe the Mediterranean Sea, which has become a garbage can, with a concentration of 250 billion micro-plastics, the highest concentration in the world. So I welcome all these single-use plastics that will be banned from 2021, because they account for 70% of marine pollution. Plastic residues threaten biodiversity and are insinuated everywhere, and also in the fish we eat. This legislation is, in my view, the first step in a new production model, that of the circular economy. Better consume and recycle all these plastic products with respect for the environment. Finally, I want to emphasize the plastics industry that should pay and fund a grand Marshall Plan for the oceans. It is simply the application of the polluter-pay principle. Industries have for too long regarded our land as their landfill. Colleagues, it is no longer even a question of the survival of future generations, but of ours. It is now or the pollution will be irreversible.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Reducing the amount of plastic, especially in our seas, is very important: 80-85% of the litter we find in the sea is, after all, plastic. However, I think it is important to have realistic expectations of what this proposal will actually mean. We will not stop seeing terrible images of how islands of plastic are created in the oceans or beaches are being filled around the world. The reason for this is that Europe accounts for only a few per cent of the plastic produced and for an even smaller proportion of the plastic that actually ends up in our seas. Most of it is spread and created in Asia. Only five countries in Asia account for 60% of all plastics. I am sure there are some people in here who say that this means that Europe does not have a responsibility. I would say the opposite. We have a great responsibility, a very great responsibility, to lead the way. But then we have to do the right thing. Then we must ensure that the right type of products are banned. Now I was afraid that we would ban cardboard cups by mistake, because they contained little, a little plastic. That would be wrong. To focus on what is really replaceable and what has no reasonable alternatives, that is what we have to do.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs Frédérique Ries on this excellent report. There's an emergency, our planet is in danger, and we all know it here. We have created a seventh continent of 80,000 tonnes of plastic waste, three times the surface of France. We need to rethink our entire business model. It is about the future of our ecosystems, our biodiversity and the very existence of the human species. We must drastically reduce the use of plastic in Europe and apply the principles of the circular economy. That has just been said. We need to get out of this neoliberal logic that pushes for ever more consumption and which is killing our planet, and with it, to intervene on the future of our children.  Finally, we must be consistent with ourselves. Today we are voting on a text warning about the impact of plastic products on the environment and, at the same time, we are still using straws and plastic bottles in this Parliament. We must set an example here and stop using these objects in the same institution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, the fact is that we live in an age of plastic and no one can deny it. The data is fractious. If in 65 years we have produced 8 billion tons of plastic, and if we have produced 6 billion tons of waste, then we really need to imagine ourselves over that fact. I want to welcome this trilogue, who I believe will end up voting here in Parliament today. Likewise, data on 85% of marine plastic pollution, one half of which comes from single-use products and one quarter from fishing gear, is also a matter for reflection and I hope we will find alternative solutions.  So the alternative is very important and where there is an alternative we need to replace it. Where it does not exist, we need to invest in research, development and innovation, create new jobs and enable new products to come to market. In any case, I fully support this initiative, I fully support this Directive and I believe that we will implement it as quickly as possible in our national legislation.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Coffee-to-go and plastic cutlery have become a matter of course in our fast-paced consumer society. But sometimes you just need bans to give up bad habits. It is therefore right that in future disposable products such as plastic cutlery, for which there are alternatives, should be banned.  As far as the responsibility of the Member States is concerned, however, I would have liked to have been more ambitious. Unfortunately, a mandatory reduction rate for plastic waste, as I have called for – including packaging – has not prevailed. This is a missed opportunity.  I became a father for the first time less than a month ago. I want to look my son in the eye and say with a clear conscience that we have tackled to keep the planet livable for them. That is why this package of measures can and must only be a first step in the right direction against plastic waste.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Sinjura President, aħna l-ewwel ġenerazzjoni ta' politi大i li bdejna nifhmu sew il-ħsara li qiegħda ssir lill-ambjent bi plastic li jintuża darba biss. Aħna wkoll diġà l-aħħar ġenerazzjoni li nistgħu nagħmlu xi ħaġa dwar dan. 75% tal-iskart li jmur fl-ibħra u fl-oikeeani huwa plastic. Jiena ġejja minn Malta u Għawdex, gżejjer f'nofs il-Mediterran, fejn kuljum naraw munzelli ta plastic fil-widien, mal-bajjiet u b'konsegwenza fil-ħut tagħna. I nistgħux nibqgħu sejrin b'din ir-rata. Id-De大iżjoni biex inwaqqfu l-użu ta' dan it-tip ta' plastic fl-aħħar ser tidħol fis-seħħħ fis-sena 2021. Pass kbir 'il quddiem imma mhux biżżejjed. Jista' jkollna l-aqwa liġijiet fid-dinja, imma l-bidla trid issir fuq livell individwali. Differenzi żgħar, li kważi lanqas tinduna bihom, f'ħajjitna jistgħu jagħmlu differenza enormi. Ma nistgħux naħlu aktar ħin, hemm bżonn li naġixxu issa.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the overall quantity of waste is increasing rapidly on a worldwide scale. Here in the EU, around 3.5 tonnes per capita of waste is produced annually, including more than 400 kilograms per person, per year, of domestic waste. All the projections available today show that this increase at worldwide level will continue at least until 2030, and in Europe no real decoupling between waste and economic growth is expected before 2020. Single-use plastic items represent about half of all marine litter items found on European beaches. We come from 28 countries, here in the European Parliament, but we share one home, one planet Earth. Young people know this. They’ve had enough, and they are demanding that we change. I want to ask all of you to support their climate strikes, their Friday’s for future, because if we don’t listen to them, then they will not elect us in the future.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, this is an area that the European Union should really concentrate on. This is an area where countries cannot do it on their own. I hear this phrase ‘throw it away’, and it’s a phrase that has to be tackled. When we say ‘throw it away’, in many cases we think ‘it’s in the bin, it’s brought away by the rubbish truck and then it’s gone away’. The reality is that it has not gone away, and we’ve got to look at absolutely every item we use and ask ourselves the question: when I throw it away, where does it end up? But we shouldn’t just have to ask that question. The companies who produce this stuff should also have to ask that question, and they should be forced to ask the question. I hear a lot of praise for young people and the work that they’re doing. We should also praise our grandmothers and our great-grandmothers, who knew about recycling and knew about the environment before the words were invented, because they lived it. We’ve got to copy them.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I also support this trilogue agreement and I am glad that it has a great deal of broad support across the political spectrum. We must conserve the environment and we must also conserve natural resources that are not inexhaustible. Of course, I also try when I choose what I buy, so I try to choose the goods that are not in these plastic packaging.  We must, I think, contribute to change on our own, which is why I am glad that the European Parliament has also backed away from the massive use of small plastic bottles. I think that a solution can be found everywhere, and the important thing is that this directive also brings an obligation for manufacturers. I consider this very important. I am proud that the Czech Republic is one of the countries that recycles a lot. In the European Union, 42% of plastic is recycled and the Czech Republic recycles 60%, and I wish it were even more so in the future.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Madam President, I apologize for this moment, Mr Vice-President, in advance of this proposal for a directive, we have already had reports in this Parliament which have focused on international ocean governance and the plastics strategy. In these two dossiers we realize both the importance of plastic material and the problem that arises when these products do not have an adequate end and end up floating in the ocean, with a negative impact on the biosphere and I remember that 80% of the ocean waste originates on land. What we will need to change our behaviors and the way we relate to these products, promoting a more responsible, smarter consumption that can favor greener alternatives. I would like to point out that my proposal in the ENVI Committee to include very light plastic bags in the prohibition list has not passed, but I would like to reiterate here, ladies and gentlemen, that these bags are so light that they easily escape collection and are carried away by the wind to end up inexorably in the ocean. The same is true for balloon drops so unnecessary and I add that even if they are biodegradable and computable materials, these characteristics do not apply in the water. But wanting to move from role to action requires targets to be set to allow Member States to take action and measure their effectiveness. That is why I welcome all the ambitious targets that are included in the follow-up to this process.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to point out at the outset that I am not an eco-terrorist, but I am undoubtedly in favour of such an orthodox concern for the state of the Earth, for the state of ecology. I must say that the work here itself is satisfactory, and the debate is, in my opinion, less so. In my opinion, we lose what is extremely crucial, namely, first of all, the value of individual projects. That is, we do not have such a thing as a road map, in which we would determine what is the first – the most important, the second, the third, the fourth – that is, a certain order, the value of individual activities. What worries me? Of course, the lack of complexity of our various activities – they do not make up a whole. Secondly, there is a lack of support for good practices. Thirdly, there is a lack of consistency between legal solutions in individual countries in order for us to be more effective. We have shortcomings in education, and unfortunately we are erratic in terms of criminal ity, that is, sanctions for those who pollute the Earth.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, having been involved in discussions on this topic for the Fisheries Committee for some time, I’m very pleased that we have this debate with a resolution here this afternoon.  Of course, the Fisheries Committee are central to what is going on in the plastics world, because an awful lot of plastic – as has been said – finishes up in the seas, finishes up in the bellies of fish, killing them and polluting. We also have the phenomenon of ghost fishing, caused by fishing gear lost at sea. So all these things need to be tackled, and I’m delighted that we’re particularly honing in on things we can do pretty quickly – getting rid of single—use plastics that can be replaced with some other product. I think that’s a very sensible way to go about it.  Over a period of time we will be sending a signal to the industry that plastics pollution has to end, and that a lot of plastics being used are either to be collected and reused or whatever. Definitely we have to do everything we can to bring about an end to plastics pollution of the environment as soon as we can.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, just listening to the contributions from the Honourable Members, I was reflecting on how unique it is that the opinion about this proposal is shared across the political spectrum. There are a few exceptions, but, by and large, it applies from left to right. I was wondering how we got here so fast, because we did reach this point quite rapidly. If you think back three or four years, I don’t think we were there yet. That is why, after the thanks we gave to the rapporteur and to the co-legislators, I think it’s only right that I should mention also those who have contributed to creating a sense of urgency in broader society, because that’s what’s driving us. There is a huge sense of urgency in European society that this needs to be done and it needs to be done now.  You have Boyan Slat, who was mentioned before; you have the Plastic Soup Surfer; and you have Ellen MacArthur, who was one of the first sailing the seas, discovering the extent of the problem. You have the wonderful Blue Planet series by David Attenborough, who had a huge impact on public opinion. You have the wide-ranging media, who have taken up responsibility to create public awareness. You have the educational system that takes responsibility here. You’ve also seen the force of the NGO community across the European Union creating the sense of urgency. Academia has played a wonderful role in finding new solutions. If we are to say today that it’s quite remarkable that we got here, we have also to be grateful to all those outside the political sphere who got us to this point. I do agree with those of you who said it’s only a first step. With all the self-congratulation here today, we should also remember that we have a long, long way to go until we actually have a circular economy. This is an important step. It’s also a unique step because it takes the full circle of plastic into account. It’s a unique step that is recognised at the global level. The United Nations always give questions about this. Asian countries are very much interested in what we are doing. Latin American countries as well. Even though our share of the pollution is relatively limited, our change of economic model has a global impact, and it will also change economic models elsewhere.  So don’t let anybody discourage you by saying that Europe only has such a small part. The size of our economy is such that, if we change our economy and create a more sustainable economy, it will have an impact on the economies of other parts of the world. It is already having an impact. Plastic pollution is something that is felt across the board and by many countries and many regions. I also want to add that – to be very, very clear on this – it will also affect packaging. We have put plastic packaging in the proposal. It should be recyclable or no longer used by 2030. That’s something that’s in the proposal. We also want to go further. Microplastics are a huge challenge to our health, and we need to come up with proposals: firstly, removing it from products where it’s not even needed. We don’t need microplastics in detergents. We don’t need microplastics in cosmetics. Then we need to look at products where we still need them and look for alternatives: in tyres, for instance. Tyres are one of the worst polluters in that area.  Just to give you my sense of urgency, this is something we will still have to do, whatever the composition of the next Commission. I am confident, because since this is something that is shared by the full political spectrum of this House, it will also be something that will be shared by the next Commission, the next European Parliament and the Council.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, indeed, 'together'. That is the key word for this debate in order to thank all my colleagues who have all supported the impetus of this report with two exceptions, my Brexit colleagues who, it seems to me, would do better to be sorry here for the jobs lost because of their initiative, but this is another debate. To conclude this one, I would like to quote John Fitzgerald Kennedy in our Chamber. In 1963, in Washington, he said, "Our problems were created by man and so we can solve them. Our possibilities know no limits, no human problem goes beyond our capabilities." So, yes, of course, 'Europe is not the main culprit for pollution', and here I quote you, Vice-President Timmermans, it is up to us to be the driving force behind the solution. This is a first step, but we are on the move. I was in the blink of an eye.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. The proposal aims to reduce plastic waste and fishing nets, which account for as much as 70 % of the waste deposited on our beaches. I welcome the elimination of the use of oxodegradable plastic compounds and food and beverage containers made of expanded polystyrene, as well as plastic plates and cutlery, cotton sticks, straws. It is a question of taking a first step towards a momentous change that will gradually allow us to abolish plastic and put an end to the contamination of our territory. More could have been dared on the short-term targets for reducing cigarette butts and fishing nets, which are highly polluting. It is also important and appropriate to increase consumer awareness by indicating in the labelling of dangerous chemicals present in the various products. Finally, I welcome the intention to increase the recycling and separate collection of plastic bottles by setting targets and deadlines.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – We live in an age of plastic and this is extremely worrying! More than eight billion tonnes of plastic and more than six billion tonnes of waste have been produced in just 65 years. Plastic represents 85% of marine pollution, half of which is single-use plastics, and therefore I believe that we need to take the first step, as discussed by this report that I voted for.  This is a global challenge that requires ambitious and gradual measures such as a ban on single-use plastics at EU level where there are alternatives such as for forks, knives, spoons, chopsticks, plates, ear sticks, straws, drink mixers, etc. the EC wants to guarantee that by 2025 at least 90% of beverage bottles will be collected and the manufacturer's accountability system will be extended to all product categories covered , except sanitary pads, tampons and tampon applicators. This extended responsibility will cover the costs of collection and cleaning and measures to raise public awareness.  This directive will bring great benefits for the environment and the economy and is estimated to avoid environmental damage, which could cost €22 billion by 2030.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – In the European Parliament, we are working towards a cleaner environment, cleaner parks, streets, beaches and mountains. Eighty percent of the waste on the beach is made of plastic. To protect our beautiful nature from 2021, we ban single-use plastic items such as cups, plates, utensils, straws and more. We also foresee measures for the use and recycling of already accumulated plastic waste - by 2025 25% of bottles must be made from recycled material.  Pure nature is the responsibility of each of us, but manufacturers need to be transparent to their consumers about the consequences of plastic products, and too often citizens do not have comprehensive information about it. With the new legislation, we want to spell out in clear language on labels what the negative environmental effects of throwing plastic cigarette filters on the street are, as well as other items such as plastic cups, wet wipes and hygiene products.  I believe that on the old continent we can all together be drivers of change, set global trends and fight environmental pollution for the sake of our children and ourselves.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the laying down of rules for the marketing of CE-labelled fertilising products prepared by Mihai Ţurcanu on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, and the debate on the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulations (EC) No 1069/2009 and (EC) No 1107/2009 (COM(201) 6)0157 - C8-0123/2016 - 2016/0084(COD)) (A8-0270/2017)

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, dear colleagues, dear shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs for opinion, we have done an extraordinary job. Together we were able to conclude this report in this legislature. The result of this report reflects the work of you, mine, the farmers, the profile associations, the fertiliser producers. We have all taken heart and made our contribution, so that this report has a fair, coherent form and helps all sectors involved.  For two years we fought to support our ideas and to defend our consumers, industry, farmers and agricultural future. And today we reap the rewards. The roads of our work and ideas are in front of you and waiting for the vote of confidence. We negotiated intensively with three Presidencies: the Estonian Presidency, we negotiated with the Bulgarian Presidency, where we were very close to concluding, and finally, under the Austrian Presidency, in the fourth trilogue, last November, we showed that we are able to compromise in order to reach a consensus. And I want to thank, on this path, the Austrian Presidency. There were tense moments and meetings and many emotions during the negotiations. Whoever says it was a simple file is wrong. I want to assure everyone present that, following the adoption today and the entry into force of the report on fertilising products, all actors in the agricultural industry benefit, but also consumers. The new regulation, which will replace the regulation 15 years ago, concerns the opening up of the internal market for fertilisers of all types, is part of the circular economy package and concerns the opening up of the internal market for fertilisers of all types and the harmonisation of limits for all contaminants. At present, half of the fertilisers on the European Union market are not covered by the current legislation. Currently, only 5% of organic waste is recycled and used as fertiliser. This new regulation aims to replace up to 30 % of the volume of non-organic fertilisers. Today, the European Union imports more than six million tonnes of phosphate per year, but could recover up to two million tonnes of phosphorus from sewage sludge, biodegradable waste and ash resulting from the neutralisation of animal waste. The agreed text introduces limits for all contaminants, such as cadmium in phosphate fertilisers, to reduce risks to consumer health and the environment. Limits on cadmium content in EU-labelled phosphate fertilisers will be 60 mg/kg from the date of application of the Regulation, i.e. three years after its entry into force. So, to sum up, European consumers will have healthier food, by imposing reduced heavy metal limits on fertilisers, European farmers will have access to a wide variety of safer fertilisers, will have access to organic fertilisers that will circulate freely in the single market, thus encouraging the use of recycled materials for the production of fertilisers. The industry will have a greater selection area from which it can choose its raw material suppliers, thus avoiding the potential monopoly or artificial price of the finished product and saving thousands of jobs. With regard to the placing on the market of fertilisers, I would like to make a point: Member States will still have the possibility of laying down national rules for national marketing. Mutual recognition of products between States is also possible.  I would like to mention that - another very important thing for me - I have also argued, and that sufficient incentives must be given for the development of fall-growing technologies and for the management of hazardous waste rich in cadmium through relevant financial resources. I want to tell you that, personally, I am extremely pleased with the final form of this regulation.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I really must express my satisfaction, because here we have worked with the necessary time, we have taken as much time as we needed and we have arrived at a good result. I believe that this is an example of how patience brings good advice and good results, because we have done something very important here: we have opened up the single market to so many very small and very small enterprises, which were previously excluded from the single market, as has been said organic, organomineral, biostimulating, specialties, etc., and we have done so with great attention to the environment. , going so far as to set limits, especially on cadmium – how difficult it was – that was not there before! I would like to stress this: first it was not there and the approved value is by far the lowest in the world, because the lowest value is twice ours, at 60 milligrams, then we find one at 120. I would like to thank all my fellow Members for their passion and commitment, including Bas Eickhout, and this time I thank him, and I think we have done an excellent job. As an Italian, allow me to pay particular attention to the Italian small and medium-sized enterprises, which are truly an excellence and which have also somewhat pre-evolved the circular economy before you in the Commission thought about it.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Mr President, Dear Commissioner, as a co-negotiator, I have worked this renewed legislation. This makes it finally possible for farmers and gardeners to use more organic fertilizers, such as animal manure and compost, instead of fertilizer. Until now, farmers have only been allowed to use a limited amount of their own valuable manure to meet the fertilisation needs of crops. What they had left, they had to dispose of for a fee, but at the same time they were allowed to feed fertilizer. That's the world upside down, and I think it's also undesirable for the environment.  The fertilizer industry is the largest emitter of CO2 in the European Union. It is the largest user of natural gas in the Netherlands. Moreover, I believe that organic fertilisers are important for a healthy soil life, and a healthy soil life is again the basis for a profitable farm. It is important for good water management, for healthy crops, for biodiversity and above all, it also reduces the leaching of nutrients to the ground and surface water. In other words, a win-win situation. The farmers knew this for a long time. I am glad that this is possible and that the European Parliament has used its common sense.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I heard Mr Huitema saying that he’s worked very hard and Ms Gardini saying she worked very consistently, and the result is here. It’s a great result for improving the regulation on fertilising products. I would like to thank the rapporteurs Mr Ţurcanu, Ms Gardini and Mr Huitema, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for all their valuable input to this file.  This regulation contributes to the implementation of circular economy principles as far as nutrients for agricultural production are concerned. The current EU regulation on fertiliser only covers fertilisers from mineral materials, as you have said. The new regulation will introduce a new legislative framework and therefore considerably simplify the current legislative framework for inorganic fertilisers. The new regulation will be a huge step towards opening the single market to innovative products, made out of organic by—products and recoverable waste. Of course these products must be produced under strict conditions to ensure they are safe for our health and the environment. I’m also very glad this really seems to affect small and medium—sized enterprises a lot, which is a good thing and something we want to improve. Organic fertilisers represent half of the fertilisers’ market in the EU. They have an enormous potential to make European agriculture more efficient and sustainable and help create jobs and opportunities for emerging businesses in the EU. With your vote today, we will bring these products within our European regulation and hence allow them access to the single market. At the same time this regulation provides safeguards to protect public health and the environment. It would also set mandatory limits for contaminants in fertilising products such as mercury, arsenic, nickel and in particular cadmium. It is good that we will now have a common limit with regard to cadmium, and after four years of its application we will assess whether this limit can be reduced.  So we’re moving in the right direction. The compromise reflects a fair balance of all the diverging interests. We strongly believe that it will be a win—win—win: a win for the EU fertilisers industry, which will benefit from easier access to the single market for innovative products and a more diverse range of cost—competitive raw materials; a win for farmers, who can choose from an increased diversity of fertilisers, who can supply their own raw material to fertiliser manufacturers and who will be in a much better position to protect their soil from toxic contaminants; and, most importantly, a win for the health and well—being of EU citizens and our natural environment, as the risk of food and water contamination with toxic substances will decrease.  Finally, I know the importance that this House attaches to the question of defining safe criteria for replacing chemical fertilisers with processed manure. The fertilising products regulation is part of the circular economy action plan, as it substantially contributes to the implementation of circular economy principles in the sector of nutrients for agricultural production. In parallel, under a different work stream, the Commission is working to ensure an integrated and more sustainable management of nutrients to reduce inefficiencies and avoid nutrients pollution, which can affect human health and the environment.  The processing of manure offers possibilities for more efficient use of nutrients, from the agricultural as well as from the environmental point of view. This is why, via its Joint Research Centre, the Commission launched a project in 2017. It includes literature review, modelling and experimental work to define the conditions under which replacing chemical nitrogen containing chemical fertilisers by processed manure in agriculture applications does not entail additional environmental risks. As an aside, I really admire the translators here today.  This work is ongoing and a draft study report should be presented in principle by the end of 2019. As these criteria concern the use of fertilisers, and not their placement on the market, they are not affected by the Fertilising Products Regulation and not expected to affect the implementation of that regulation. However, they certainly constitute an additional and complementary action to foster an efficient and environmentally safe circular economy. To conclude, allow me to reaffirm our full support for the compromise found. We count on you today to take an important step in building a circular economy for the EU fertilising products industry and ensuring that these products are safe for our health and the environment. This is also another important concrete step towards implementing the UN sustainable development goals and building a sustainable European future, which has become more urgent than ever.  (Applause)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – Madam President. Thanks for the word. I, too, share the joy that after three years of negotiations, even after a challenging trialogue, we have managed to complete this process.  The process in which we add organic fertilisers in the rules, which have so far been mainly regulated by mineral fertilisers, and as we know, this is also one of the first packages also from the circular economy that we have got on the tables. For the aim is to increase the proportion of organic fertilisers and not to discard the much-needed nutrients that are hidden in these organic things.  As has already been said here today, it is absurd that compost has now been treated as something that had to be removed correctly, rather than used as fertiliser.  However, in order to do so and to apply the rule to the whole of Europe, this regulation was needed, which sets out the parameters in which we also ensure that the situation in terms of environmental pollution is of sound quality.  We've also arranged the area around heavy metals. Even a very difficult area, which in the end found an acceptable compromise, which, as we have heard, is still the most ambitious in the whole world.  I am also very happy to support the part that is here dedicated to innovation and opportunities for small businesses, which have really now been eliminated from this single European market.  And on the basis of this regulation, which will be carried out within three years and will apply in the legal order, progress will continue here.  So we have taken a good step for the environment, for agriculture, for the circular economy, so this proposal will receive my support.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, fertilisers are essential for agriculture, but their use can also have a negative impact on the environment and on food security, especially when contaminants are present in these products. Their proper and safe use is therefore essential for sustainable agriculture, food security and environmental protection. The modernisation of the regulation on fertiliser products is part of the "circular economy" package, as this legislation aims to put on the same footing conventional inorganic fertilizers, which generally follow the linear economy model, and organic fertilizers by promoting the reuse of raw materials currently disposed of as waste. Sustainability, food safety and environmental protection objectives go hand in hand with ensuring that our farmers can afford to buy high quality products across Europe. These new rules maintain this balance and encourage the development of innovative products that could help farmers achieve better yields. This is therefore a crucial step in the transition to the circular economy within the European Union. However, I am not entirely satisfied, of course, with the result, especially on cadmium, even if efforts have been made. Indeed, the results of the trilogues are much less ambitious than the negotiating position we voted for here in plenary.  Finally, I would like to point out that, because of a blocking minority in the Council, it was not possible to maintain the limits that we had voted for, even in the time, of 40 and 20 milligrams per kilo. However, we have been able to obtain some elements that allow us to accept this agreement as progress on cadmium, including voluntary low-grade labelling, the review clause triggered four years after the date of application, the introduction of national exemptions for Member States that already apply the lower cadmium limit and support measures for decadence. Finally, I would like to thank my colleague Urcanu, even if our cooperation has not always been easy, it must be admitted, as well as the other fellow shadow rapporteurs and the other rapporteurs, Mrs Gardini, Mrs Thomas and Mr Wasa, for the excellent cooperation that has prevailed on this issue.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab First there were drastic limits on the content of cadmium per kilogram of phosphorous fertilizer. It was so strange that these strict regulations primarily hit the chemical industry, Polish the Grupa Azoty Group, the second largest fertilizer producer in Europe, and the Russian deposits lobbied. And the stakes were high, because the fertilizer industry in the Union is worth €25 billion. However, during two years and turbulent negotiations, such drastic cadmium content standards were abandoned and 60 milligrams per kilogram of fertiliser and a three-year transitional period with a revision clause have now been proposed. This is the most far-reaching compromise below which it is in no way possible to go down. After all, no clear scientific evidence has been provided for such a stringent cadmium limit.  We must remember that phosphate fertilizers are very expensive at present. More expensive fertilisers and the concentration of the fertiliser market are destabilising not only the chemical industry, but also agriculture in many EU countries. Further, Poland has the lowest cadmium content in the soil and due to the beneficial parameters of the soil there is no risk of its accumulation. Furthermore, the proposal to mix mineral fertilisers with organic matter is a risky solution, if only because of the possibility of microbial contamination and antibiotics, and some eu competitors could invest in production in regions of the world where there are no such cost-effective regulations.  However, given the above and the awareness of the risks that cadmium can have to human health, let us vote in favour of this difficult compromise.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to give my support to this fertiliser regulation. As a result, farmers will have a wider and much better environmental product range in a more sustainable way in the future. In this way, we will ensure better protection for humans and animals and we will be one step closer to a cleaner environment, cleaner water and cleaner food. But it is also a question of the circular economy. The new fertiliser regulation will enable more efficient nutrient recycling, which is an important step forward in the protection of the Baltic Sea, for example. Of course, there is also room for improvement in the regulation. Limit values for cadmium, which is hazardous to human health, could be stricter than at present. Some countries, including Finland, have opted for stricter rules for the use of cadmium, because the protection of soil and, by way, human health, really cannot be compromised, and that is, of course, what I would like all Member States to follow.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I have to pour a little water into the wine, because we can accept the compromise, but we cannot be proud of it. We now have a limit value for cadmium - 60 milligrams. But if we then think about what we in Parliament were expecting: we wanted 40 and then 20. There has been a blockade in the Council, partly because of massive economic interests, and that is why we now have a weak compromise in which 60 milligrams are now set as the limit value. This cannot satisfy us, because we have to realise that what comes into the soil as a fertiliser will eventually end up in food in the long term. That is why we cannot be satisfied with this compromise. We are therefore pleased that the Commission will have to review this in a few years' time and that we will hopefully achieve more ambitious targets. Nevertheless, we agree with this, because we are simply saying that we have been discussing it for thirty years, and now we finally have a result in our hands – that is, after all, something – and we have a limit value. But we must also be clear: the Council's obstructionism was far from a good thing here. That is why it is up to the Council that we have not made more ambitious progress. I would also like to remind you that the cooperation between the IMCO Committee and the ENVI Committee was not always straightforward at this point. It took us three years to conclude a debate, which we can now conclude. But I repeat: this can only be the beginning, because in the end we really have to get to the 20 milligram limit and we must not stop at 60 now.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Demand for healthy food from organic farms is constantly increasing, and there is a good reason for this: people are afraid of being poisoned by contaminated food. Cadmium in fertilizers can lead to serious illnesses and even death. The current exposure to cadmium in the EU is higher than the human body can tolerate. That must be noted!  Anything above the 20 mg limit per kilogram for cadmium must be rejected for health reasons. EFSA's recommendations, which identify the application of phosphate fertilisers as the main cause of soil cadmium pollution, can no longer be ignored.  All this information has not prevented certain circles in this House from once again following the wishes of the chemical and agricultural lobby. It is a missed opportunity to do something about soil contamination and to make consumers more safe. I am therefore not so satisfied with this report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, 50% of the fertilisers currently on the market still do not have access to the internal market. This report therefore brings to an end this distortion of competition, which handicaps an entire sector, yet it holds significant promises for the future of agriculture in Europe. It aims to establish a competitive environment for organic fertilizers that is equal to that of mineral fertilizers.  This report, an integral part of the circular economy package, has succeeded in overcoming many and various collateral issues that have even touched on thorny geopolitical issues. Nevertheless, we can regret the lack of pragmatism of some, who have had difficulty giving economic actors reasonable objectives and time frames to adapt to the new compliance criteria. The outcome of the inter-institutional negotiations, however, proposes a suitable agreement, which will need to be completed quickly to foster innovation in the fertiliser sector. I am thinking in particular of the French players in the sector, to whom this agreement will benefit.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card question. – Would my colleague agree that, where cadmium is naturally found incorporated in tiny quantities into rock phosphate, it is safe, but if extracted to satisfy EU legislation, it immediately becomes a highly concentrated toxic hazard with no easy disposal solution?

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: answer 'blue card'. "You are right, dear colleague. In any case, when the European Union meddles in something, in general, everything becomes toxic. But in this particular case, as with many other things, indeed, all the consequences of this new legislation have not yet been drawn, we hope that this will be resolved later.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The purpose of the Fertiliser Regulation is to open up the European market to new products, in particular organic and organic-mineral fertilisers. I particularly welcome the decision to waive unrealistic, low and completely unjustified allowable levels of cadmium in phosphorous fertilisers. We opposed these proposals in order to ensure the long-term competitiveness of the fertiliser sector in Europe, as well as the viability of agriculture and the food industry. However, the 60 mg limits adopted, for which I wanted to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ţurcanu, are still high, restrictive and will result in a marked increase in production costs. Moreover, this applies not only to the level of heavy metal content, but also to other technical requirements which are imposed on the production of fertilisers. This will have far-reaching adverse effects on the cost-effectiveness of both this sector and agricultural and food production.  I would point out that the rules for the placing on the market of organic fertilisers and waste from agricultural crops and animal husbandry as raw materials for the production of fertilisers are still unclear. It is also doubtful whether a number of agronomicly unproven induers, the use of which does not necessarily involve greater efficiency and may increase production costs, are also questionable.  Poland is not only a large producer of fertilizers, but also one of the largest consumers. We are, of course, committed to regulating the European market for fertilisers and consumer safety, but without undermining the long-term viability of production throughout the fertilising and agri-food chain.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I would like to join this debate on a number of issues. We are talking about a Regulation within the total Regulations on the circular economy; Regulation which will enter into force in the twenty years of the current Regulation. Therefore, there are important changes and updates required. I would like to show that these current fertilizers are crucial for agriculture, but without a doubt, misuse can have significant risks and a negative impact on the environment and public health. And this is what is intended to correct, among other things. Many have welcomed the inclusion of organic fertilizers; it's certainly a value. But I do want to say something about organic fertilizers: it is important to continue to innovate, improve their efficiency and effectiveness and, of course, to respect the requirements of the Nitrates Directive, also in organic fertilizers, which are important. And finally, I would like to say that I am in favour of the cadmium agreement. The position has been balanced by fixing those sixty milligrams. This is an agreement: it is not the position of a party, but is an agreement between all parties. And I believe that this reduction is an appropriate reduction for current needs.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, quality fertilizer products are and will increasingly be important for the development of more productive and at the same time sustainable agricultural models, which in the future will have to respond to the pressing challenge of access to food, producing more but using less input and polluting less. I would therefore like to thank my colleague Marc Tarabella for the excellent work he has done, together with the rapporteur, Mr Țurcanu, in harmonising the rules for the production and labelling of fertilizers at European level, setting ambitious limits on contaminants and encouraging research for a further reduction in fertilisers, in the interests of our farmers but, above all, of all our European citizens. The outcome of the negotiations shows that the Union remains the leader globally in sustainable development, creating the necessary conditions for the increasing spread of innovative, effective and low environmental impact products, in total coherence with the circular economy model.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, much has been achieved, but there has also been a missed opportunity in circular agriculture. I have been recognising processed animal manure and mineral concentrate as a green fertilizer substitute for 30 years. There is nothing in the draft legislative text, despite clear demands from Parliament. We must settle for an oral statement from the European Commission.  According to Commissioner Timmermans, is there a strong guarantee that there will be a delegated act for the recognition of mineral concentrate as a green fertilizer substitute? I demand an answer to this. An oral statement by the European Commission does not bind the new Commissioners. I therefore appeal to Minister Schouten in the Netherlands, and to Flanders and Germany in the Council: work on the delegated acts to exclude green fertilizer substitutes from the Nitrates Directive. And I will keep my fingers on the pulse for the next few years and I hope to be able to work with others on this.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the compromise reached. It seems that in the end it will be acceptable both for farmers and for those who want healthy food, a healthy environment.  I appreciate the increase in safety standards of fertilising products and the lowering of limits for heavy metals, especially for cadmium. This tightening will lead to increased food quality and safety and greater protection of the environment, in particular soil. There is increasingly talk of the problem of groundwater contamination with chemicals contained in the fertilisers used. This measure will also help to remedy this problem. I believe that the voluntary harmonisation mechanism could reduce the administrative burden, as there will be no need to register individual products according to different national arrangements. Overall, I therefore consider the text of the report to be balanced and I support it.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I had one concrete question from Ms Schreijer-Pierik and let me answer directly. The study report will be ready before the end of this year, so not so much time will elapse before you will know this. Given the broadness of the study, we have enough guarantees to assume it will go in the direction she assumes as well. So I would just encourage her to keep watching this and then to take it from there when the draft study is ready.  For the rest, I just want to say that this is good for farmers, this is good for small- and medium-sized enterprises, this is good for the environment, and, most of all, this is good for our health. So this is one more step forward, and we will keep following the issue so that we can take further steps in the future, but the vote today already takes us in the right direction.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Thank you very much, Vice—President, for your work and your team’s work.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Vice-President Frans Timmermans, I would like to thank my colleagues for their interventions today. I would like to note and mention Mr Marc Tarabella, Mr Czesak, Mr Iwaszkiewicz, Mrs Troszczynski, Mr Kallas, Mr Durand, Mr Maštálka, Mr Hietima and, last but not least, Mrs Gardini, because I have worked extraordinarily well on this dossier. From the interventions of my colleagues, I have noticed that the interinstitutional negotiations have been good, balanced and I can only ask them to vote on this report unanimously.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday 28/03/2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The majority of participants and observers on the new fertiliser regulations focused primarily on the issue of the permissible cadmium limit and the possible economic and geopolitical implications. However, this work has also highlighted the very high dependence of the Union on imports of raw materials for the production of fertilisers, which are, after all, important for our agriculture and, consequently, for food security. More than 6 million tonnes of phosphorus are imported into the EU every year, which is a hard-to-reach raw material. Their large resources are located in Russia. For this reason, trade in them has not only economic but also political conditions. It is estimated that biological waste, such as sewage sludge, manure, slurry, meat-and-bone meal, could replace up to a third of these imports. The possibilities for recycling organic waste should be used more widely to obtain valuable fertilising ingredients.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I would like to raise a point of order. Pursuant to Rule 182a of the Rules of Procedure, I raise a point of order concerning the validity of the vote on the Voss (JURI) report A8-0245/2018 on copyright in the Digital Single Market.  When voting on the requirement to vote on the amendments tabled, 312 Members were in favour and 317 against. In retro time, however, the vote changed the 13 Members who wanted to vote in favour of the possibility of a separate vote on the amendments.  I am asking you, Mr President, and I would like to ask the President of the European Parliament about the decision to vote on this request again tomorrow, because it was clear that a number of MEPs who had changed their vote were misled in the vote.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Thank you for your comment. Unfortunately, however, I have to inform you that, according to the Rules of Procedure, the explanations of vote do not change the result of the vote itself.  Therefore, post-vote corrections are possible, as you know, and are then recorded and published, but they cannot change the final result of the vote.  I shall therefore pass on your request to the President; However, I would like to tell you right now that the Rules of Procedure are unfortunately very clear on this point.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I’ll be very brief. The shadows and myself, and the co-rapporteur, have brought this file back today for a final vote because the interinstitutional negotiations envisaged by this House nearly a year ago have not even begun. It is of great concern that the Council have decided not to prioritise this technical file, which is essential for the future financial stability of the EU financial market infrastructure. This regulation was designed to address the risk of concentration in EU central counterparties and put in place the safeguards needed to deal with the most extreme scenarios in ensuring the recovery and/or the resolution of central counterparties. The financial crisis led to the use of financial derivatives being better regulated, and this is the final piece in that post-trade regulatory framework. I urge the Council and Commission to ensure that this crucial piece of legislation has top priority in the next mandate to better protect EU investors and the financial system as a whole. I would like to thank my colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, both past and present, for their work on this file, especially Jakob von Weizsäcker, who has now left, and their cooperation over the past decade on all the markets files I’ve worked on. Many thanks to all of you. (Applause)

name: Laura AGEA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, with the final vote on this directive, we are establishing that the European Parliament has had a very great ambition to protect workers in the European Union. By including more than thirty new cases of carcinogens, we have protected more than a million workers between now and the next few years. My thanks go to my colleagues in the EMPL Committee, in particular Marita Ulvskog and Claude Rolin, who were rapporteurs with me in the two previous directives, but also to all the shadow rapporteurs and all the members of the committee, who showed that this Parliament has great zeal and ambition when it decides to protect its citizens.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the shadow rapporteurs from the various groups, who have always been very cooperative during the long gestation of this directive.  The text, which was widely approved in the TRAN Committee, is a key step in the Mobility package, in order to decongest Europe's roads from goods and to encourage them to move to other, more environmentally sustainable modes of transport. Faced with the citizens of Europe, who are now more than ever calling for protection and respect for the environment, this Parliament's commitment to more sustainable mobility is definitely necessary and desirable. I therefore hope that you will support the text again today, as approved in the committee responsible.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: Mr President, just a gesture of courtesy to say that, since you triggered the Olympic Games with speed, we must really congratulate the interpreters who have a hard time following you but who do it very well. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: That concludes voting time. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Tanja Fajon, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 adopting the list of third countries whose nationals must be in possession of the visa the act of crossing the external borders and the list of third countries whose nationals are exempt from this obligation (Kosovo*) (COM(2016)0277 - C8-0177/2016 - 2016/0139(COD)) (A8-0261/2016).

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, today in this House we are once again discussing visa liberalisation for Kosovo. It is a very sensitive and very difficult topic because Kosovo is the last country of the Western Balkans that still hasn’t seen visas abolished for free travel to the European Union. I would like to remind us all that Kosovo met all the requirements for a visa-free regime a long time ago, and this House, the European Parliament, also gave the green light for Kosovo’s visa-free regime a while ago. The European Commission recognised that Kosovo has met all the criteria, and I would like to remind you that Kosovo had more conditions than any other countries of the Western Balkans. Kosovo met the last two remaining sensitive issues some months ago – one was to ratify the demarcation of the border agreement with Montenegro – which were highly sensitive and political issues. But they managed to achieve it, including with a fight against corruption in high political elites. That’s why I strongly recommend that tomorrow we reconfirm visa liberalisation for this country. To be very frank, today all the other countries of the Western Balkans have visa—free regimes. It is a very important message for the citizens of the accession countries because it is not only important for political and economic contacts, but it is important for people—to-people contacts. Today Kosovo is the most isolated country in the Western Balkans. We are just talking about visa liberalisation. I don’t want to discuss other issues that Kosovo is dealing with today because, with intention, we have to focus on what Kosovo has delivered. So today I will, with all my criticism, point to the European governments and say that didn’t deliver their promise. Their promise was that, once Kosovo meets the criteria, we will deliver a visa-free regime. I would like to ask the Council – and no one is present here – why they didn’t put it on the agenda, and when they are planning to put it on the agenda. We are losing our credibility. To be very frank, politicians, businessmen or potential criminals don’t wait for visas. They travel freely. What we are discussing is visa-free travel for those who are in need, with certain limitations of course. Visa-free travel has certain limitations and people in Kosovo are aware of that. The campaign is ongoing and we have to deliver what we promised. I would remind you that, in other cases – when we delivered visa liberalisation to Ukraine or to other countries overnight – it was an easy political decision, and now the European governments are blocking a little country in the Western Balkans without real reasons. So I would encourage us all, because we are finishing our term in office, to reconfirm tomorrow the mandate you already gave me and this is that we support visa—free for Kosovo. Once again, the country has met all the conditions. The European Commission recognised that, but today it is the European governments that aren’t acting. We have too many cases today where the European governments are blocking our credible European policies and visa policy is something that is really at the heart of Europeans. It is something that is very tangible. I understand the frustration of citizens in Kosovo when they feel that we asked them to deliver something and they did deliver, but now we aren’t acting. Not the European Parliament. We did our task, but the task is now in the hands of the European governments. So my message to you tomorrow, when we vote for the mandate and reconfirm it and conclude the first reading, is: please support it because people in Kosovo are watching us and they are watching us with great expectations and hopes.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome this debate on visa liberalisation for the people of Kosovo, and I would like to express once again my thanks to our rapporteur, Ms Fajon, for her continued work, personal engagement and efforts to support this proposal. Since launching the visa liberalisation dialogue in 2012, the Commission has closely worked with Kosovo to support the authorities in fulfilling all the benchmarks of the visa roadmap. We acknowledged, in our final report of 4 May 2016, that Kosovo had taken important steps towards the visa-free regime. This is why we proposed, as you remember, to lift the visa requirements for the people of Kosovo on the understanding that, by the day of adoption of the proposal by Parliament and Council, Kosovo would have ratified the border demarcation agreement with Montenegro and strengthened its track record in the fight against organised crime and corruption. Two years later, on 18 July 2018, following the necessary efforts and progress, the Commission confirmed that Kosovo has fulfilled all benchmarks of the visa liberalisation roadmap, including the two previously outstanding requirements. Subsequently, we called on the Council and the Parliament to move forward with our proposal. I would like to thank this House for the swift support it has given to our proposal.  Let me recall that the conclusion of the border demarcation agreement with Montenegro is a huge step forward, and it was not easy, even though this is politically sensitive, and we should say so. A number of Member States voiced concerns about the migratory risks posed by the citizens of Kosovo and the need to learn from the past. I am aware of these concerns, and I can understand them. Kosovo is also aware of them and is cooperating and in touch with several Member States directly to mitigate the risk. We have encouraged, and will continue to encourage, the Kosovo authorities to continue, first of all, to implement all the benchmarks; second, to strengthen their anti-corruption and rule of law framework; and third, to keep up the work on migration and security, as well as the need to clearly communicate with citizens about their rights and obligations under a visa-free regime. Dear colleagues, let me recall that Kosovo is the only western Balkan partner that does not benefit from a visa facilitation agreement, and its citizens are the only ones in the region who need a visa to travel to the European Union.  I have said plenty of times that the visa-free regime comes with rights and obligations, and the Kosovo authorities are well aware of this. They have done their part of the work, and I trust they will continue doing so. I count on the Members of this House to help encourage the Council to also come to the negotiating table soon and agree on the proposal swiftly.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, as permanent rapporteur for Kosovo at AFET, I could say that kosovo is a wide-fledd period full of challenges. And despite the fact that a year ago they managed to ratify the border with Montenegro, which represented a particular effort to achieve an internal consensus, and that the European Union claimed that this was the last missing criterion in the process of obtaining visa liberalisation, and when Kosovo fulfilled this condition of progress in the fight against crime and, of course, corruption, the European Union once again argued that this is the last missing criterion in the process of obtaining visa liberalisation.  But in the meantime, to this day, it hasn't happened in this area what it should have. And although it is the European Commission, and we have given the green light to visa liberalisation, this item has still not been placed on the Council's agenda. And you know, when we have two partners and one fulfills their part of the obligation and the other doesn't, the other loses its credibility.  And I think we have a responsibility before the people of Kosovo to do so.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, since the start of the visa liberalisation dialogue between the Commission and Kosovo until 2016, the Commission has adopted 4 progress reports. In May 2016, the Commission presented its latest two proposals, namely kosovo to ratify the agreement on the border with Montenegro and to continue the fight against organised crime.  To date, these two criteria have already been met, as the Commission's report found in 2018. In addition to these last two criteria, Kosovo was subject to a further 95 criteria, which were met. Due to kosovo's commitment, it is high time that the diligent negotiations and efforts made by the Kosovo Government were rewarded with clear results. It is time to show the citizens of Kosovo that the European Union is reliable not only for its own citizens, but also for its friends outside the borders of the Union.  I think it is time to show European and Kosovo citizens that when we set clear criteria and a clear result is achieved, we in the European Union fulfil our commitment, and this commitment is to allow kosovo citizens to travel freely within the European Union.  Let us not forget that Kosovo is the last country in the Western Balkans for which visa liberalisation is not a fact. Let us not justify international crime, because visa liberalisation is not the barrier that will stop this crime.  I would like to recall some facts, namely that the number of asylum applications from Kosovo has decreased dramatically, that Kosovo has signed 20 readmission agreements with European Union countries, that Kosovo has launched a campaign to inform citizens about the right and obligations of the visa-free regime, that Kosovo has increased the number of border police as a preventive measure, and that Kosovo has a legal framework , which covers all aspects of terrorism and is in line with the acquis communautaire and international counter-terrorism instruments.  Finally, I would like to stress that Kosovo continues to fulfil all other criteria set out in the visa liberalisation roadmap relating to readmission and reintegration, document security, migration and border management, public policy and security.  I therefore propose that we vote in favour of kosovo's visa liberalisation.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Almost three years ago, the Commission proposed to exempt Kosovo from the visa requirement, because even then the Commission was convinced that Kosovo would also fulfil the final conditions for visa liberalisation in good time. And the Commission confirmed last July that this has indeed happened. And yet today we are not voting on a trialogue result. The visa liberalisation roadmap was presented to Kosovo four years after the other states in the region, and some Member States are still delaying and blocking the negotiations. This isolates Kosovo and slows down European integration. How are we to explain to the people there that the EU is suddenly taking further conditions out of its hat, after the country has already met all the criteria for visa liberalisation? This attitude not only contributes to the EU losing its credibility in the Kosovar population – and possibly beyond. The promises we make to Kosovo must be kept. Yes, some EU Member States have not recognised Kosovo as a state. However, visa liberalisation does not require recognition of the state, only the travel documents must be recognised, which, incidentally, are already very safe. We must not hold Kosovo any longer. The conditions for visa liberalisation have been met, Parliament has a clear position, and it is high time that the Council, which is once again not here, gave up its blocking stance so that the EU as a whole can keep its word.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
