text: for the ECR Group. Mr President! There are many good both concrete and general reasons for being sceptical about visa liberalisation in relation to Kosovo. First of all, there is the low-practical argument that there are a number of EU Member States that, even to this day, do not recognise Kosovo as an independent state. This makes it difficult for the Council to break the deadlock that has surrounded the whole process. In general, however, I would say that what concerns me and my colleagues in the ECR Group is very much the focus of unilateral visa liberalisation rather than the opposing considerations that remain. If we look at areas such as organised crime, we have seen major problems in the Western Balkans in general in relation to the impact that has been on eu countries. That is why it is a perfect precaution to apply for visas. That is why we can only regret that liberalisation has gone too far.  In addition, I personally am very concerned about the increasing radicalisation we have seen in certain parts of the Western Balkans, and therefore our general attitude towards the whole issue of europeans' security is that prudence should be the guiding principle. In this context, visas are a very good instrument for filtering people who gain access to the European Union. In general, we feel that the Commission should be more focused on making repatriation agreements compared to the many rejected migrants that exist in Europe, rather than further visa liberalisation.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking our rapporteur, Tanja Fajon, and all the shadow rapporteurs, for all the efforts made on this file. The file has been a work in progress in the European Parliament since 2016, when already at that time, the Commission proposed lifting the visa requirements for the people of Kosovo by transferring Kosovo to the visa—free list of short stays in the Schengen area. As mentioned before by Commissioner Avramopoulos, the Commission announced last July that the two most important requirements for the visa waiver had been fulfilled. Firstly, Kosovo had ratified the border demarcation agreement with Montenegro and, secondly, Kosovo has strengthened its track record in the fight against organised crime and corruption. In September, Parliament voted in favour of entering into interinstitutional negotiations, and tomorrow we will vote to keep the position positive, so the visa waiver can be finalised during the next legislature.  Kosovo has been isolated on the Balkans visa liberalisation map for far too long. Visa liberalisation would be a fair and natural next step for this country. The benefits of a liberalised visa regime are considerable. This decision will further facilitate people—to—people contacts, improve professional and educational exchange, boost economic partnerships and strengthen social and cultural ties between the EU and Kosovo. This agreement would also help the EU to promote reforms in third countries in relation to strengthening respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law. The visa waiver can even help to discourage people smugglers whose services would no longer be required. I call on the Member States and on the Council to adopt a position as soon as possible so that negotiations can finally begin. There is no room for prejudice preventing the people of Kosovo from travelling freely into the Schengen area.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Since Kosovo declared its independence in February 2008, more than 100 countries have recognised it, and the International Court of Justice in The Hague considers that independence is not contrary to international law. The Stabilisation and Association Agreements with the EU have entered into force in all western Balkan countries, including Kosovo. Yet five of our Member States have chosen not to recognise the country: Spain, Greece, Cyprus, Romania and Slovakia. Kosovo is today the only country in the region that does not have visa facilitation to the EU. The road map launched with no less than 95 criteria is now ready. They've done their part of the work. Now it's up to us. I fully agree with the rapporteur that it must be a fair and merit-based approach – and not a political horse-trading – that forms the basis of our position. There is nothing to prevent Members even from those countries that have not yet recognised Kosovo from voting in favour of visa facilitation. I say this, because it happened in committee. I and the Green Group, we welcome the proposal.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, Kosovo is a country of less than two million people. The war, which bloodied the country, left more than 13,000 people dead. It is the only Balkan state that has not benefited from the liberalisation of short-stay visas, of course, since these are the only visas that are under the union's jurisdiction. Northern Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia have had it since 2008, Albania and Bosnia since 2010.  As our rapporteur has written, Kosovo is now isolated on the map of visa liberalisation in the Balkans. It was asked to fill out a more detailed list of criteria than any other country, which was done. The Commission came up with a legislative proposal in 2016.  We are used to moving very quickly in this area, to ratify liberalisation agreements, including already in force, especially for charming Oceanic islands, such as the Tonga Islands, Tuvalu, Nauru, Kiribati, Vanuatu and a few others, for which there is indeed little chance of nationals arriving in our territories, but they are designed for a few privileged European tourists.  The post-liberalisation massive arrivals syndrome is always contradicted by the facts, especially in the Balkans, not to mention the future role of ES and ETIAS.  Even if not everything is perfect, Kosovo has made a lot of effort, far beyond what has been asked of its neighbours. Issues of corruption and the justice system are often highlighted, but its neighbours do not do better. The European Parliament has done its job, the European Commission's proposal was adopted in September 2016 and the negotiating mandate given by our LIBE committee has been confirmed in plenary in 2018. However, the Council has not yet adopted a negotiating mandate. The real point, as has already been said, is that five Member States have still not recognised Kosovo.  Our group is largely in favour of visa liberalisation and freedom of movement, and for our many, we do not wish to make an exception for Kosovo. That is why I support the rapporteur's proposal, which I thank in particular for her tenacity.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, for unclear reasons, the European Commission wants to lift the visa requirement for the European Union for as many countries as possible. So now it is kosovo, too. Kosovo is an area whose inhabitants have declared independence, but not all member states of the Union have recognised it. There are also problems with criminal gangs from Kosovo in the EU. I would like to stop it at the border, but apparently not the European Commission.  The EU mission to build the rule of law in Kosovo has failed, according to the Dutch participants in that mission. The border is full of smuggling routes where heroin and weapons and prostitutes are transported daily, with western Europe as its final destination. The local police and customs know about it, but turn a blind eye and even Colombian drug cartels use the routes. The Dutch team in Kosovo described it as follows last year and I quote: "A lifeboat can be 99% whole, but if there is one leak in it, it sinks. We are looking right into the leak of Europe." End quote.  Mr President, these are all reasons to maintain this visa requirement, right? How a majority of the European Parliament can be in favour of this is beyond me. We will vote against it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the advantages for citizens of an acceding country such as Kosovo of the exemption of the passport visa obligation are obvious. But securing and maintaining this advantage must be a key concern of the country's government. To this end, the Kosovo Government, despite some efforts, has not succeeded in fulfilling most of the necessary conditions. In addition to the fact that it has not fought organized crime, it has allowed the country to become a haven for ISIS terrorists and murderers. Moreover, its behaviour provokes neighbouring countries. For example, we see ongoing border incidents with Serbia. In addition, it imposes duties on products coming from Serbia. It also methodologies the confederation with Albania, which is known to raise expansionary aspirations and territorial claims over the Epirus department of Greece. Under these conditions it is inconceivable – I believe – at the moment to discuss both the recognition of Kosovo and the removal of the obstacle resulting from the need to consider the passports of its citizens.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, as some of you know, I have been the rapporteur of the report on Regulation (EC) No 539/2001, which regulates the Union's visa policy. I have also been so from the suspension mechanism, which derives from the Reference Regulation. And I have been involved on many occasions in the inclusion in the negative list of the Regulations of several countries such as Colombia, Peru, Taiwan, Georgia, Ukraine, etc. All these countries have a common characteristic: they are sovereign states.  The first sentence of Article 1(1) of Regulation (EC) No 539/2001 begins by saying: 'Third-country nationals ...'. In today's debate we are not talking about any country. For us, Kosovo is a Serbian province that, like Vojdine, is part of its territorial integrity.  We cannot provide political instruments that facilitate the dismemberment of a sovereign state such as Serbia. Our position as a Spanish People's Party is well known. The Union is made up of twenty-eight states. The Regulation is for twenty-eight States, not twenty-three. How would partial application be possible? We would be faced with an instrument of very dubious legality.  The legislative initiative to be approved cannot be in application eer in Spain, Slovakia, Cyprus, Romania or Greece. If this proposal succeeds, the Court of the European Union will surely encounter resources from the five sovereign states mentioned above. None of these five States will allow visa waiver for citizens of a Serbian province.  The Union does not grant visa waiver to provinces, only to sovereign States. What I'm saying is legally and legally indisputable. Even less so through Regulation (EC) No 539/2001. (He agreed to answer two questions posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure) ).

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: 'blue card' question. Mr Diaz De Mera, we know each other well, we are used to working together and I know you are an excellent lawyer. So can I ask you if you know that the five states you have quoted have agreed to visa liberalisation, regardless of the issue of Kosovo recognition? I would also like to know what value you place on the United Nations and on the recognition of states and on the right to self-determination of peoples.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: "blue card" response. – Thank you very much, Mrs Vergiat. I also have the best opinion about you and your work. But no, no; she's not well-informed. The five Member States have not consented to what they cannot give it to. The five Member States may not partially grant visa exemption to a province that is part of a sovereign State.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: blue-card question. – Dear Agustín, I also have had very good cooperation with you and I know you are a good legal expert. I have a question for you and it’s along the same lines. I have had contact with the representatives of all the five states that do not recognise Kosovo, and in fact, my colleague is right. It’s about recognising travel documents, and not statehood. They are willing to agree on visa liberalisation for Kosovo. Just to remind you – and maybe you can answer this too – do you know that in 2009 we agreed on a visa—free regime for Taiwan, despite there being no recognition on the EU side of Taiwan’s statehood?

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Fajon, I too recognise your work and I very much appreciate the cooperation we have had for a long time.  You see, the answer is very similar to the one I gave Mrs Vergiat. No, it is one thing to provide a travel document and another thing is how a travel document can be given to what, in the field of international relations, is not a sovereign state. I would like to say that, legally, regardless of whether I have had the recognition of many countries of the international community, the Regulation before us is for the Union. It is for twenty-eight States of the Union. It is not for twenty-three States of the Union. So, legally, it will be impossible for the European Union to apply. That is why there will be resources, I clearly announce, there will be resources from five States that are not subject to this Regulation because they do not recognise a Serbian province as Kosovo is.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, Kosovo was excluded from the European visa liberalisation map from the last decade, while other Western Balkan countries could benefit from this privilege. We can all think of Kosovoʼs history in a different way, but we cannot afford to make this country a geopolitical hostage of our disagreements. Among the neighbouring countries, Kosovo, more than most, needed a visa-free regime from the beginning of the process at the Thessaloniki Council. All four Commission reports demonstrated Kosovoʼs rapid progress and its readiness to be a part of the club. We expected Kosovo to fulfil its 95 benchmarks and it did so. So by what legitimate criteria can we deprive our partners of this right? If the EU aims to promote the principle of justice and openness with Kosovo, why don’t we deliver on our promises? 84% of Kosovars are in favour of EU membership, and in my opinion, we must consider Kosovo as a future member as of now. It is unacceptable for us to undermine the regional role of the most pro-EU country in the Western Balkans. One day our children will share their EU citizenship with Kosovars, and I really wish that we could minimise this experience of unfair treatment of Kosovo and the feeling of injustice, especially since the West already has a lot to apologise for to Kosovo. On a separate note, I would like to praise the effort and perseverance of our colleague Tanja Fajon in this important matter. Thank you very much.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, visa liberalisation is a clear message to third-country citizens that the Union sees their country as a close partner. Talking about Kosovo's European perspective, while insisting on visas to join the EU, is utterly hypocritical.   It is especially hypocritical if political motives are hidden behind it, while selling the story of criteria that are important to meet. If the criteria are so important to us, and I really think they should be, then when a third country meets those criteria, there must be no more obstacles.   As it is Kosovo, the country's international status is again being problematised. We also have member states that have not yet recognised Kosovo. Like it or not, Kosovo is a state. It is up to us to help her become a stable and successful state, partnering and friendly, rather than sabotaging her out of selfishness, hypocrisy and politics. (The Representative agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I believe it is important to see whether the criteria for the visa are met. And I think that is the case at the moment. What does this mean in relation to the residence permit? I believe that a clean separation is necessary here, and visaism is therefore an important instrument for enabling the introduction to the European Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. My colleague, I think this is about politics. Countries that had many more criminals, where it was much worse, we allowed them to enter the European Union, therefore, we abolished their visa regime and did not allow Kosovo. I call it pure politics.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, there is one thing I don’t understand here in this discussion, we are often criticising some countries for not fulfilling their obligations, for saying one thing and doing the other, and rightly so. But in the case of Kosovo, we are behaving like these countries and how can we do that? I don’t really understand. We have set certain conditions and requirements for Kosovo to fulfil. These requirements were set by all countries, including countries that do not recognise Kosovo. Kosovo has fulfilled them. The Commission evaluated this and said they are indeed fulfilled. And now the answer from our side is nothing. This is degrading our credibility. We could have imagined every possible condition to put in front of Kosovo. We could have waited. We set some conditions and they have fulfilled them. Now it is time for us to deliver our part. I strongly urge the Council to end this circus and allow visa liberalisation for Kosovo’s citizens because this is degrading be credibility of the EU.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, 'sewing an open wound' in her call for the lifting of visas for Kosovo, the rapporteur has definitely not skimped on hyperbole. But how can one seriously argue for a decision based on merit when, in recent times, Kosovo has seemed to take a clever pleasure in playing with fire? What about, for example, 100% tariffs on Serbian imports, in defiance of the Central European Free Trade Agreement, or the transformation of Kosovo's security force into an army, in violation of its fundamental texts? But the most unacceptable is to tear over the isolation of Kosovo, by obscuring that experienced by the Serb minority. We no longer count unfulfilled commitments, such as the one on Serbian municipalities, which has remained a dead letter since the Brussels agreement in 2013. From provocation to provocation, Kosovo is moving further and further away from a European perspective and confirms that it has never ceased to be a failed state in the heart of the continent.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: – Mr President, when I speak in favour of visa liberalisation for Kosovo, I speak on behalf of the majority in this Parliament, since we have already voted in favour of visa liberalisation. Now it’s up to the Council to fulfil the promise of the European Union, which came along with the criteria that Kosovo had to fulfil; and Kosovo fulfilled the criteria.  We all know that there are six different states in south-eastern Europe. There are 18 million inhabitants, and only 10% of them, 1.8 million inhabitants, don’t have the opportunity to travel freely. The people of Kosovo should have this opportunity too. By the way, we all have to fight against corruption and for the rule of law in these countries; we have to help the citizens of these countries to fight and to have opportunities for jobs and education at home. It’s not about going to work somewhere else in Europe or settling somewhere else in Europe. It is only about travelling without fees for families, without waiting times, which are annoying for families. It is about visa liberalisation, and I guess that the majority in this European Parliament stands behind the people of Kosovo, who deserve visa liberalisation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, the visa liberalisation plan for Kosovo was presented back in 2012, four years later than other countries in the region. Kosovo has met as many as 95 criteria by 2016 and has met two additional on progress in respecting the rule of law and, most politically challengingly, ratifying the border agreement with Montenegro exactly one year ago.  But it has made no difference, and the frustrations and feelings of isolation of the citizens of Kosovo, the state with the youngest population in Europe, are justifiably growing. That is why they should not surprise unilateral measures such as the tariffs imposed by Kosovo on products from Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Such decisions, let's be clear, are certainly not good, but they should also be understood in the context of dissatisfaction with an unacceptable situation.  The European Union must be consistent and respect the rules it has set itself. This issue needs to stop politicising and linking it to other legislative and negotiating processes. The people of Kosovo must finally become equal with all other citizens of the Western Balkans when they enter the European Union, they certainly deserve it.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: Mr President, today still five Member States of the European Union rightly refuse to recognise Kosovo as a state. Kosovo's independence, it should be remembered, is only the result of the barbaric bombings suffered by the Serbian people twenty years ago, and with depleted uranium, moreover. The visa exemption for Kosovo nationals would be a fortiori one more step towards EU membership, which we formally reject. You speak, for many of you, my dear colleagues, of criteria. Personally, I see one: it is the unacceptable treatment of human rights by the Kosovar government. We do not need, in this deliquescent European Union, a pseudo-state, mafia and Islamized which, according to a report by the US State Department, subjects kosovo Serbs to a number of institutional, social and professional discriminations, even intimidation to prevent them from practising their Christian religion and even aggression. Addressing the author of this report in particular, I would like to say to him that his approach does not go in the desired direction of reconciliation for all the peoples of the former Yugoslavia, who are friendly peoples for all of us.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Ladies and gentlemen, please keep to the timetable. 20 seconds more is a lot. I try never to cut the speeches, but please do not force me to do so.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, it is high time that the EU, and in particular its Member States, stand by the commitment to allow Kosovan citizens to travel without a visa to the European Union. Kosovo is a young country that has made significant efforts, after the most appalling ethnic violence, to get in line with the requirements of the European Union to obtain visa liberalisation. May I say that it was not a level playing field with Ukrainians gaining liberalisation quickly because it suited us for political purposes. I don’t begrudge that, but I think it is unfair for the Kosovans. Through regular contacts with numerous members of Kosovan civil society, particularly with women and youth and with entrepreneurs, I’ve seen that citizens aspire to be part of the European project. By blocking the visa liberalisation process, the Council is sending the wrong message. Many young Kosovans are disappointed and they feel let down by the EU. Hope of ever being a part of this European peace project is fading for them and we need them to be part of our peace project. Where will they turn? Well, I abhor some of the language that I have heard from some Members in this House this evening. As a British MEP, I have Kosovan constituents living in Manchester, and there is a peace park in Kosovo that is called the Manchester Peace Park. These Kosovans are war refugees and they contribute to our society. When you slander them, you slander all Kosovans. Shame on you. (The speaker declined to answer a blue-card question from Dobromir Sośnierz) Mr President, I refuse to debate with misogynists and racists in this House, so I will refuse the question from this gentleman.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I just wanted to ask for compliance, because Mrs Ward recently supported sanctions against me, so I would like to ask if it is acceptable to call other Members in this way and call them racists and homophobes for no reason.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: I will pass on your report to the Bureau and we will of course let you know in response to what you have said. Catch the eye procedure

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, I agree with those who have said it is high time to allow visa liberalisation for Kosovo. I am sorry that some here call Kosovo a province, it is clear that Kosovo is a recognized state and I am sorry that for their narrowly national reasons they reject this idea.  The fact is that the citizens of Kosovo and the Kosovo authorities met the requirements that we asked them to do, which was a demarcation of the border with Kosovo, they also worked on anti-corruption laws and I am sorry that today this session serves in fact, from my perspective, as pressure on some states in the European Council to allow Kosovo to liberalise visas.  I think this is very important for this young nation, for this young country because they want to travel as easily as all other citizens of southeast Europe and in this direction I would like the Commission, and I see that the Commission confirms, Parliament confirms, and there is a need to put additional pressure on the European Council so that the citizens of Kosovo can travel undisturbed.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to express my thanks for this interesting debate. I’m really glad that the European Parliament recognises the importance of making progress on this file. As I said earlier, this is not only about being fair towards Kosovo, its authorities and its citizens for recognising their efforts. This is equally about stability and security in this region. We cannot ignore the larger picture that is at stake here and the European perspectives of the entire region. It is by bringing them all closer that we also ensure stronger cooperation. One cannot keep moving or pushing the finishing line; otherwise, we risk Kosovo and, most importantly, its European minded citizens turning their backs and running in the other direction.  I very much regret that it was not possible for an agreement to be found under this legislature. I hope that it will be completed as soon as possible during the next term.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you for all the support to shadow rapporteurs and other colleagues that believe Kosovo today deserves visa liberalisation, and thank you to the Commissioner. To others that still have some doubts, I say that for visa liberalisation the recognition of statehood is not a condition. There is only a need to recognise the travel documents. Increased radicalisation has nothing to do with limited visa-free travel for – mostly – young people and for tourist purposes. But, yes, increased radicalisation can be a result of Kosovo’s isolation and the growing despair that the EU has failed to deliver on its promise.  Once again, Kosovo has met all the benchmarks set by the European Commission – even more than the other countries of the Western Balkans. The European Commission has recognised that, the European Parliament has that, and if you today say Kosovo is not fulfilling the conditions, you are simply lying. You are simply behaving irresponsibly. I urge the EU governments to respect the Treaties, to take a decision on visa waiver for Kosovo, with a qualified majority. The Council does not need unanimity. Stop these games and shameful political purposes, and act now.  Tomorrow we will vote in order to secure a first reading procedure in Parliament. This is not the final vote, but it is an important vote to point a finger at EU governments, showing we in the European Parliament are ready. This is our message again tomorrow. We are keeping our promise, now it is up to you to show your credibility, to show that you care for young people, that you care for young families and for a young country that for far too long has been isolated. (Applause)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, March 28, 2019.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Vladimír Maňka, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2020 - Section I - European Parliament (2019/2003(BUD)) (A8-0182/2019).

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I am very pleased that we have the debate on the European Parliament's budget today. We have a lot of uncertainty because Brexit has not yet been resolved. We do not know what will happen in the next 48 hours. But we assume that our budget should be prepared in any case for a hard Brexit, a chaotic Brexit or, of course, for the British to remain in the European Parliament, which would of course be our first priority. We have therefore negotiated with the Bureau of the European Parliament. We have insisted on savings, we have cut a total of 18 million. We have reached an agreement with the Secretary-General. That is why it is important that we want to fight fake news and fake news first and foremost in the forthcoming election campaign. Here I believe that the European Parliament, through the European Science Media Hub, has found a new group that can take active action here. We want facts, we want good justifications. And I believe that a peer review of what the European Parliament decides should be the basis for honest and transparent reporting. We also have the point that the Statute for Members should be respected. We have the voluntary pension fund. I believe that we have the right here to ensure that what has been promised by the legislation and by the three institutions is respected. Personally, I cannot be friended of the Bureau's decision to take appropriate steps in this. Ultimately, however, it is also a question of continuing to regard the office lump sum as a flat rate. I believe that it is important for Members not to be suffocated in the paperwork. Bureaucracy in the House is definitely too much. We see that there is a great deal of staff tied up here, and the purpose of lump sums is to relieve us of the problems of bureaucracy. Ultimately, it is up to the member or Members to decide what expenditure is made here. That is why I also believe that, of course, if a hard Brexit actually comes now – that is, 6.1% of MEPs – we will have to push through the corresponding changes in the autumn. One of my major problems is also the gender pay gap that we have, because it is about the assistants, the group staff and the civil servants being paid on different bases. All work seriously and well. I therefore believe that they also have a right to equal pay. The European Parliament should also be a model here. I also believe that the medical service should play a leading role in the field of harassment in the future and that trainees need adequate remuneration in the future, which should of course also be taken into account in the secretarial allowance. The final point is that the delegations to official missions are sometimes very lavishly equipped. I believe that Members should decide who to take with them: a group staff member, assistant or translator. This would save us enormous costs. I believe that the European Parliament is perfectly capable of saving a lot of money.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: I don't know what I' – Mr President, when drawing up the European Parliament's budget, we must focus on our main mission and make optimal use of resources to improve legislative work. Things that are not related to our mission must be excluded from the budget to the maximum extent possible. Exactly 10 years ago, as chief rapporteur for the budget of all the European institutions, I was in the same role as today. Back then, the lack of planning, the lack of communication on the available translation capacities prevented their effective use. The institution that was supposed to provide translation often automatically placed an order to freelance translators without figuring out whether internal capacities were available within the other European institutions. In the area of translations within the institutions alone, we have found reserves of more than EUR 10 million per year. Since then, many things have improved in this area. But even today, it is necessary to look at how cooperation between the institutions works. The spare capacities of each institution must be made available to the other institutions. We can certainly find millions more reserves and savings here too. Colleagues, together we are fighting for higher growth, employment, a better standard of living for the population. Sometimes we put obstacles in the way of this effort ourselves. Some parliamentary assistants, instead of meaningful work, have recently literally produced written questions for their Members for the Commission. The main reason? Because post-social websites and then some media rated MPs as active accordingly. In 2015, the number of questions to the Commission approached 1 700 per month. Together, the answers to these questions employed more than 100 people in the Commission and in the European Parliament. The cost amounted to almost EUR 13 million per year.  It's hard for me to say, but there are cases where for those who ask, the answer isn't what they need. Then let us not be anoyed that the Commission will evaluate some of the questions as questions asked in numbers. And then the Commission will underestimate the answer and may not answer the question honestly asked responsibly.  Over the last three years, we have managed to substantially address this problem and reduce the number of questions to the Commission by 9 000 a year, and we have reduced costs by more than EUR 7 million per year. I would like to thank you, honourable Members of the Budget Committee, for supporting the proposal on Monday by a large majority to complete the process of the so-called oral explanation of vote. Because that's another bureaucracy. This will bring further savings of a million euros a year. Interpreters will not have to interpret unnecessarily in all languages of speech intended only for listeners in a Member's home country. After all, we have other tools to explain to our constituents how and why we voted. It will be a further reduction in bureaucracy. We want to further reduce the travel costs of staff between Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg. For example, instead of traveling more use videoconferencing. We are also solving other problems. This is to help accredited assistants who work two terms and sometimes miss literally a few days or weeks to meet the criteria for resolving their social and pension rights. We want trainees, without increasing the European Parliament's budget, to have the cost of living covered during the traineeship and guaranteed income. Sometimes in the European Parliament, but also in any other institution, psychological or sexual harassment can occur, causing severe psychological and physical trauma to victims. We can't do without a professional mediator or psychologist and other experts in this area. I'm glad we found a deal here, too. We have been working for many months to simplify the procedure for approving the European Parliament's budget. We're almost at the finish line. I trust that, after the Elections in May, new Members will bring this process to a successful conclusion. If this succeeds, we will save the entire spring part, save human resources and funds. The budget is built on the assumption that Britain will leave the European Union by agreement. If there is a hard Brexit or if Britain does not leave in the end, we will have to adjust the budget through the budgetary procedure. The decision of the people of Great Britain to leave the European Union fell under the influence of fake news and misinformation. We therefore need to be able to explain the European Union project, its positives and achievements to our citizens. One of the tools to bring the European Union closer to the people without everyone having to travel to the European Parliament is to come to their regions. We are starting to build mobile exhibition and presentation devices, so-called " Parliamentarians that come directly to your region. They will bring you the work and real results of European cooperation in a fun way. This will be of great benefit, especially for young people from schools.  Thank you, shadow rapporteurs from all political factions. We searched and found the best solutions. I also thank my co-workers and advisers. Due to the forthcoming Elections to the European Parliament, everything took place in a shortened mode and often deep into the night. Sometimes on weekends. My coworkers voluntarily and on their own initiative. You would not believe how dedicated some people can work, even though they know that they are also ending up after the European Elections in May. I want to thank them sincerely for that. They're great people who don't get lost in life. This is, after 15 years, my last report in the European Parliament and my last speech.  It has been a great honour to be involved with you in building a better Europe.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Maaka on the work he has done to approve the budget estimates in a timely way, but also for his fifteen years in this Parliament. And, given that this legislature is over, I also believe that we can take advantage to take stock of the legislature. In these five years prudent management has been done, with moderate increases linked to inflation and we have adapted to the new circumstances, from the need, for example, to increase security in our buildings to combating fake news, to adapting to the likely possibility of a new reality of a Europe to twenty-seven. And when we talk about budgeting, we are talking about an administration budget, which aims to effectively use the resources available to achieve its ultimate goal, which is to legislate. And an institution that intends to legislate from outside doors has to set an example of doors inside. And we've made progress, but it's cost us a lot. Because, for example, it was in 2013 that from the Youth Intergroup we launched the campaign in which we asked this House to force its fellows to pay a living wage, and we have made it, but it has taken us five years. And we also have to be an example in the fight against sexual and work harassment, and here we have enough to be. But thanks to parliament's 'Me Too' movement and the efforts of some Members, a catalogue of measures to lead the fight for equality has been put on the table. And if we are talking about equality and example, it cannot be that in this House we are forced to choose between the right to vote and the right to enjoy maternity or paternity leave. So we call on the Bureau to urgently launch a system that allows telematics voting, and that we finally take this Parliament into the 21st century.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Speaking on behalf of the ECR Group in this debate on the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for 2020, I would like to stress that next year is the last year of the Multiannual Financial Perspective and that financial decisions and commitments should therefore be taken with caution, respecting financial discipline.  I am therefore concerned about the proposal to increase administrative expenditure by more than 4.3% and, after taking inflation into account, by more than 2.3% compared to 2019, to more than two billion euros. Proposals to expand Parliament's activities and diplomatic presence in Indonesia, Ethiopia and the US look very unconvincing, while the relevant EU institutions are already in place in these countries. I am pleased that the Committee on Budgets has voted on a proposal for a single seat of the European Parliament, which could save a hundred and fourteen billion euros a year.  Particular attention should be paid to the rapporteur's emphasis on the need for Parliament to respect the social and pension rights of accredited parliamentary assistants, including ensuring that they have access to the pension system after two terms of office. It is also noteworthy that your rapporteur requests that the European Court of Auditors examine the voluntary pension scheme for Members in view of the major change in the conditions of benefit recently made by parliament's Bureau in this system.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Parliament should set an example in spending money.  If we demand transparency and savings from others, Parliament itself should be able to do so. Unfortunately, this level of Parliament's budget is still too high, even though some savings were made in committee. My group is therefore, above all, advocating transparency, transparency and reasonable spending. One important factor in promoting transparency and transparency would be that Parliament's building policy would not be financed by oversized costs from other sites. At times, it seems that money is being budgeted for the various budget lines quite deliberately over and then, at the end of the year, it is transferred to buildings. If money is to be spent on buildings, I believe that it must be done transparently within the framework of the normal budgetary process. Then there is the second point, the increase in personnel costs. It is almost 6% on this budget line, on a budget line. I received a reply that the increase is due to statutory expenditure, such as index increases and promotions. That is a lot of this 6%, if that is the reason for it, but apparently it also includes a few dozen new posts, which parliament does not actually decide on, at least not openly. Finally, I would like to thank my colleague, Mr Manka. It has been very pleasant to work with him, as well as with other rapporteurs. I would also like to say that, for my part, this is probably also the last speech. This has then been done by representatives who are no longer running. But I would like to say that savings and transparency – otherwise the European Parliament will not be able to cope with future challenges.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to start with Mrs Jäätteenmäki and continue to do so: transparency and the will to save are also important for us when it comes to Parliament's budget. In general, of course, we believe that we also need a budget with which Parliament can work well. We want to do a good job, and we must have the resources to do so. Until now, Parliament has always tried to stick to having only two per cent, only to be able to say – and do so – that we want to spend most of the money on European citizens and on good programmes and, of course, not just on their own interests. In principle, this is also a correct idea, but we must all be able to work properly here, and that also means – and I will stress this once again – there must also be an internal balance between the interests of the groups, us MEPs, but also of the administration. If you have too much tension in this system, it just makes you annoyed, so you have to find a good balance there as well.  However, in all the ambitions that Parliament can formulate on what we need in terms of money, I also believe that, for example, in the case of translation services – and this is not directed against the translators – we do not need certain languages, we do not have to register them, and we can save money on this. The same applies to travel. We have already become accustomed, for good reasons, not to take with us all those who might be interested, but to concentrate our delegation trips on certain colleagues and then to be very efficient. And business flights on short distances don't always have to be. That is why we have been campaigning for years. Therefore, there are certainly opportunities for savings. And yet hopefully we will have enough money to do a good job.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that democracy rightly has costs. The problem is not the costs of democracy, but the waste that democracy generates from time to time, and in this Parliament, in these five years, I have highlighted a great deal of waste, starting with the funds that are given every year to European foundations and parties: a budget of almost EUR 63 million is planned for next year. Throughout this parliamentary term, we are talking about EUR 370 million that has been given to the parties. In total, the budget has increased from 1 737 000 000 in 2014 to over two billion, or 2 050 000 000. You understand that it is difficult to succeed in campaigning against the citizens, saying that they are saving money, when the budget has increased in recent years and even for next year, in the event of Brexit, so with around 50 fewer MPs, this Parliament continues to increase spending and waste. Unfortunately, there is no future for this Parliament in this direction.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, today we are talking about the european Parliament's estimate of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2020. In total, Parliament has budgeted over EUR 2 billion, almost an additional EUR 4% or tens of millions more. This enormous sum is needed, among other things, to further indoctrinate European citizens with talk of so-called European political awareness and European values, in short, talk. To this end, various "Europe Experience" centres and mobile installations are being set up in the Member States: expensive offices from which EU brainwashers can spread their questionable propaganda.  Of course, there is no mention of the greatest threat to European values. For Mr President, the arrival of millions of fortune seekers from Islamic countries has disastrous consequences. Intolerant Islam is incompatible with our free Western values. The fight against Islamisation should be high on the agenda in every European country.  I return to the budget plans. Once again, there is a missed opportunity to cut Parliament's expenditure substantially. Why are MEPs' salaries not being reduced by 15%? And why is the general expenses allowance not being abolished and replaced by a more real, less fraud-prone system? And what will happen to the generous pension scheme for former MEPs, which will cost a lot of extra money? Parliament takes good care of itself, so well so that additional staff have to be hired. Employees sent to new far-flung corners in Africa and Asia. The madness at its best.  Mr President, the elections are imminent. It is time for citizens in Europe to punish the world's foreign EU elite. It's time for a change. It's time for the big cleanup.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, I would like to greet you, and I would also like to congratulate the rapporteur on the work he has done in this Parliament. Making parliament's budget is never easy, much less easy in an election year where amendments that should not even be voted on, and because they are even illegal, always appear, and therefore the redoubled congratulations to the rapporteur Vladimír Manka and also to all and all the shadow rapporteurs who participated and participated in this project. The European People's Party has always advocated rigour and transparency, but at the same time the necessary means, sufficient, for the purpose of legislative excellence. Having bad legislation means a huge cost to the citizens of the European Union. And we have done a great job in this Parliament, a job that also requires quality of services and also of the employees and fortunately we have these high quality services and employees, too, of excellence. Our goal of reducing expenditure as much as possible cannot therefore collide with principles that we have such as multilingualism. It is necessary that everyone continues to speak his language in this space. There is also a need for translation. It is clear that savings can be made in this area, as we have done, but without achieving this principle it is the principle of multilingualism. And then, of course, that we have a Parlamentarium, have a House of Europe or representations of Parliament in each Member State, that has costs, but it is a way for us to help spread not only the work we do, also the history of the European Union and our values. We will continue to seek a balance between strict transparency and the means necessary, but minimal, for the purpose of legislative excellence.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President thank you and thank you to Vladimír Maňka for his work as rapporteur on this file, but also Vladimír for being a brilliant colleague and great neighbour in the Committee on Budgets for me for the last two years. One of the issues I wanted to raise in this report is paragraph 31, which looks at the issue of accredited parliamentary assistants who are just a few more months or days, a few days in fact, short of ten years’ service because of the way the electoral cycles of this Parliament have worked. I hope that can be addressed and I hope they will have their pension rights addressed in future. Trainees should not work for nothing, and I’m glad we have started to address that and also everyone should be able to work free from sexual harassment, and I’m glad we’re making progress on that also. We are told by the Europhobes that this Parliament is an expensive place but it compares well to other similar Parliaments, such as the US House of Representatives. This is a big continent of 508 million people in the European Union and democracy has a value. And if that value is not worth EUR 4 per citizen per year then we really are in trouble, and we need to defend that. Of course we could make other progress. We could scrap the second seat and if Mr Macron is serious about reform he can help us, because he’s the only real person who can help us address that. We have to, as a Parliament, have priorities and I believe that one thing is absolutely key and that is that a multilingual Parliament continues. I think the priority of a Parliament should be the ability of Members to address everyone in this Union, which is why I’m afraid I am opposed to the notion of removing translation from any element of this Parliament. I hope that that will be properly addressed because when we have the cart before the horse, looking at finances rather than the actual operation of Parliament, then we risk running into trouble. Thank you for tolerating that last little bit.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Madam President, despite the quality of the work provided by our rapporteur, Mr Maeka, whom I would like to congratulate, and our shadow rapporteurs, and in particular our colleague, Anneli Jetteenmaki, I do not hide my perplexity at the agreement reached between the Committee on Budgets and the Office.  Of course, I take note of the reduction of EUR 18 million obtained by the Committee on Budgets compared to the Secretary-General's original proposal endorsed by the Office. Personally, I find this reduction insufficient.  The percentage increase in Parliament's budget should, in my view, not take into account the weighting of wages, new needs, exceptional circumstances, to be in line with the rate of inflation. When I see that the appropriations for staff compensation will increase by almost 6% next year, I wonder, either about the quality of the inflation forecast or what is hidden from us in this increase. I am particularly concerned about two other points. I am concerned about Parliament's intentions to increase its activities and diplomatic presence in a number of countries, including Indonesia and Ethiopia. More fundamentally, even though there are embassies of the Member States of the European Union in these countries and an often costly representation of the European External Action Service, I find it hard to imagine the added value of such settlements for Parliament.  On the other hand, I am not enthusiastic, unlike my colleague Mr Maeka, about the proliferation of European experience centres, the species of mini-Parlamentariums that we want to set up in all the countries of the European Union.  It is certainly imperative, and I recognise this, to put in place effective mechanisms to inform citizens about parliament's work and the priorities it defends, but I would rather invest in people than in stone, brick or concrete. Let's invest in journalists and the performance will be much better than the multiplication of bricks.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, as usual in the Committee on Budgets, I always agree with what has been said by Mr Deprez. Nevertheless, I have just one extra point to make after thanking Mr Maňka for his report, because I know first-hand how difficult it is to have a compromise between the Bureau,  the Committee on Budgets, the political groups and public demand, etc. So thank you for a great job, Mr Maňka. There is only one issue, and it is more jobs for political groups. This is exactly what happened when I was a rapporteur and we wanted 76 more political jobs for political groups. In a well-calculated, camouflaged and calibrated manoeuvre, they got their way. However, this is exactly what triggers and enflames all sorts of Brexiters, Orbanists, gilets jaunes and other frustrated people. So, colleagues, let’s tackle the diktat and curb the appetites of party managers. Otherwise, we will not be meeting the high standards of the free mandate of MEPs, but will be described by history as mediocre party hacks.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, this debate should be absolutely none of my beeswax because of Brexit, but sadly it is. It is likely, one way or the other, that the UK will end up contributing to a budget for the European Parliament alone of over EUR 2 billion. It’s great to see paragraph 25 calling for the end of the travelling circus between Brussels and Strasbourg, but, like the film ‘Groundhog Day’, this Parliament votes to end the travelling circus in different reports from different committees, month in, month out, year in, year out. Time and time again, it doesn’t get the change enacted because this place doesn’t actually have the power to decide where it sits. That’s the difference between this place and, say, the House of Representatives, which was mentioned earlier in this debate. At least this report does question the latest EU expansionism. It questions suggestions for bigger offices in Indonesia, Ethiopia and New York, which, last time I consulted a map, weren’t in Europe. But what I can’t support in this report is millions more being spent on propaganda by setting up Europe experience centres and mobile installations across Europe and hiring an army of 50 new press officers and media managers. I can’t support even more money being spent refurbishing MEP’s offices, which, last time I checked, were perfectly serviceable. Then we come to Brexit, and this report contemplates various options. Why wouldn’t it? Even as I’m speaking here, politicians in Westminster are still unable to decide whether or not they’re going to implement the referendum result. British MEPs were elected on a Brexit mandate in 2014, the general election in 2015 mandated a referendum, and the 2016 referendum mandated leave. Then 85% of votes at the general election in 2017 went to parties pledging leave. I’m going to blame the European Union for a lot of things, but I’ll tell you what, I’m not going to blame the European Union for politicians in Westminster ignoring the mandates and being unable to decide what to do. That much is certainly their fault, not yours.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I believe that the question of the seat of the European Parliament is, of course, a legitimate question, and we all know that the Lisbon Treaty and also the Treaty of Rome have always provided for unanimity on the question of seats. And our seat is Strasbourg. So I do not understand the criticism of why the seat of Strasbourg is being questioned here: we are sitting here, we are deciding here, and I think that makes perfect sense.  On The other hand, with Brexit, we do not know at all what will happen next. Will that lead to a hard Brexit, chaos, within a few hours? Westminster has not yet made a decision here and we will be very interested in how this will affect our costs.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – It’s difficult to respond to a question that doesn’t come with a question mark. Certainly I agree that there is chaos in Westminster at the moment, we expect our politicians in Westminster to actually take some decisions and to take a lead on the Brexit that people voted for. As far as the travelling circus between Brussels and Strasbourg is concerned, I suppose my point is simply to say that the system is broken when a parliament does not even have the basic democratic power to decide where it meets.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, parliamentary democracy is priceless, but it has a cost. And we, the members of the Committee on Budgets, have a duty, which is to ensure the rigorous use of the euros made available to us. I would like to pay tribute to Vladimir Maika, who prepared the analysis of this draft budget for Parliament. He did it rigorously, he did it with the shadow rapporteurs, I want to salute their commitment and the excellence of their work. I would like to say that the rigour with which Parliament manages its budget determines its authority when it enters into negotiations with the Council, in the period following the vote on the Union budget. The vote we are putting on here is provisional and will have to be confirmed in October. Having said this, I would like to share with you my impression that we must remove an ambiguity: every year for the last five years that I have chaired the Committee on Budgets, we have the same difficulty, we have before us a draft budget which is a reflection of a policy decided by the Office. We have sometimes expressed questions, doubts about the evolution of the workforce, about job openings, about diplomatic representations in a particular country outside the European Union. The answers we received did not always raise our questions, but since these were decisions of the Bureau and group decisions, we had virtually no opportunity to question those choices. So I think that in the next term of office, we will have to remove this ambiguity on the collection, for example: a number of lines of credit are overvalued and at the end of the year we find that there are unused credits, which are used to finance real estate investments. Well, again, I would like to see a forward-looking view of real estate policy and that our budget be marked with the seal of budget sincerity. However, I want to pay tribute to all those who have successively been rapporteurs for Parliament's draft budget, and to express my gratitude and admiration to them and to the shadow rapporteurs.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to point out that, unfortunately, it seems to me rather inappropriate, not to say undignified, to see a further increase in the budget for next year, particularly in a year like this, the year of possible Brexit, in which this institution could lose as many as 46 representatives. In spite of this, unfortunately, we see an expected increase in expenditure. As a member of the Bureau, I have spoken out against a number of initiatives on several occasions which I consider to be excessive. I am talking about the opening of new buildings representing the European Parliament that are excessively expensive or other exosus solutions, including with regard to the renovation of the PHS building. We must also remember the enormous costs associated with our triple seat, which continue to be a symbol of a lack of respect for those countries that are always asked for more austerity, rigour and sacrifice. A billion for the next five years, it will cost us the triple location. I want to close with regard to the most unacceptable expenditure: the EUR 370 million in this mandate for parties and foundations, astronomical and unjustified figures that all European citizens will soon ask you to account for, they will ask us to do.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 28 March 2019.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Michel Dantin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food safety, on the quality of water intended for human consumption (COM(2017)0753 – C8—0019/2018 – 2017/0332(COD)) (A8—0288/2018).

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the shadow rapporteurs, ladies and gentlemen, it has been almost forty years since the European Union has adopted legislation on drinking water. We have made considerable progress in all countries. This legislation was first revised just 20 years ago and the time has come for a new revision, if only to act on the scientific advances reflected in the new WHO standards. But we must also, as the Commission proposes, integrate the advance of knowledge in risk management, as set out in the Water Framework Directive, and take into account the expectations of citizens in terms of access to water and transparency.  Last October, we voted in plenary on the report on the revision of the directive. This directive, which mainly reviews the parameters, proposes a new method of risk assessment to prevent pollution risks as early as possible.  This report therefore presents several strong challenges: public accountability, risk-based approach, quality parameters and finally access to water. We must promote access to quality water for all European citizens at an affordable and transparent price to the consumer. With a clear timetable, despite the work that this represented, Parliament lived up to the expectations of the citizens, ready to negotiate the text as early as November to reach an inter-institutional agreement before the end of the mandate. Unfortunately, the delay of the text in the Council does not allow us to find ourselves in a satisfactory situation today. On the contrary, it is a very delicate situation since we have not been able to come up with a text negotiated in trilogue and voted on. Despite all the efforts of the Romanian Presidency, which I would like to welcome, in order to make up for the delay in the Council, the presentation of a general approach at the Council of Ministers on 5 March 2019 is too late. Parliament no longer has sufficient room to initiate inter-institutional negotiations before the European elections.  This report, which is the subject of both technical and political issues important to European citizens, is Parliament's official position for inter-institutional negotiations after its vote tomorrow at first reading. It will now be up to the Finnish Presidency to negotiate this revision with Parliament. I would like once again to thank the entire team of shadow rapporteurs who have accompanied me in this process and I also want to pay tribute to our colleagues and the services of Parliament.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to warmly thank the rapporteur, Mr Dantin, and the shadow rapporteurs for the hard work done on the proposal for a revised Drinking Water Directive. The Commission welcomes the efforts and the fact that Parliament’s amendments are aligned with the main elements of our proposal. At the same time, I regret that due to the slow progress in Council, it was not possible to reach an interinstitutional agreement before the European elections. I would like to recall that the main objective of our proposal is to ensure the safety of drinking water in the European Union for the 21st Century. We should be proud that today most people living in the European Union enjoy drinking water of the highest standard worldwide. With our proposal we will be able to maintain, and even improve, the situation with stricter and more appropriate limit values. Last week, on 22 March, we commemorated World Water Day with the theme ‘leaving no one behind’. Our vision of Europe is that of an inclusive society, which leaves no one behind. The obligation in the revised Drinking Water Directive to provide the most vulnerable amongst us with access to clean water pursues this vision. It is the result of the first ever successful European citizens’ initiative – the right to water initiative – supported by over 1.8 million people and as such a tangible example of how the Commission does listen to European Union citizens’ concerns. The proposal would improve the situation of about two million people in the European Union. The Commission proposal on access to water is also an important step towards achieving Sustainable Development Goal 6. I warmly welcome the strong support from Parliament to ensure access for all. This support is important in view of the future discussions between the two co-legislators. As you are aware, the Environment Council agreed on a general approach on 5 March. In their compromise text, a fragile equilibrium was found, with very limited requirements on access to water. Some Member States indeed were opposed to access to water being regulated at European level. On the contrary, I know that the majority of the European Parliament, which is the House of the European citizens, wants it to be regulated. Furthermore, the Council proposal for an Article 10A, on materials in contact with water, raises several concerns for the Commission.  Therefore, while reserving its position for the interinstitutional negotiations, the Commission states that it intends to further analyse and assess the concerns on this article and will make the results known to the co-legislators in due time.  I can assure you that the Commission is committed and will do its utmost to support the next European Parliament as well as the incoming Finnish and Croatian Presidencies, so that they can start negotiations as soon as possible.  Let me also underline that, as an honest broker in the negotiations, the Commission will uphold the important objectives of this proposal, which I believe we all share. Finally let me recall that safe drinking water is crucial for European citizens. The solutions we propose will bring positive change to their daily lives. I therefore call on Parliament to support the Commission’s ambition to protect even better the health of our citizens, by proposing strict health standards and by ensuring that they have better access to water.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Drinking water is the best controlled food in the whole of the European Union. This is also an obligation for us to keep following the latest scientific state, and the European Commission's proposal makes drinking water even safer. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats support this effort, but we have always pointed out in the procedure that the whole thing must also be manageable, especially for small waterworks, and that, in the end, it should not be the profiteers of the proposal that should be the companies that bring analytical methods to the market, but that this is also financially viable for the consumers who end up having to pay for it. That is why we need a sensible approach that improves safety, but which keeps costs within limits, especially for small waterworks. The big issue is access to water. Personally, I think it is a very good idea that we have free access to drinking water in as many places as possible in Europe – in public facilities, in public places – and I also think it is good that we have free drinking water in cafes and restaurants. This is good for the citizens, and we would therefore also take account of the citizens' initiative. This saves resources. We have mineral water, which is often carved over many hundreds of kilometers through the area. This costs fuel, which causes other environmental problems. And as a doctor, I have to say: it is not necessarily advisable to drink mineral water all day long. Tap water is also recommended from a medical point of view. But not everything that we personally like, and not everything that is somehow a good idea, should be centrally prescribed by the European Union in every corner of the European Union. There is also the issue of subsidiarity. That is why we, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, believe that the compromise that the Council has reached is very sensible and that we should also approach this in the trialogue negotiations. Incentives, raising awareness – this is a way of perhaps achieving the objective better than by telling hosts throughout the European Union what to do. This could also strengthen anti-European tendencies. That is why we should support the idea here, but not adopt too rigid legislation. Finally, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Michel Dantin. Unfortunately, he will no longer stand for the European Parliament. He has done a great job in many of the dossiers and also in this dossier. Dear Michel, thank you very much for your work and all the best for your future!

name: Rory PALMER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, firstly, can I add my thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Dantin, for his coordination and endeavours on this file, and also add my thanks to the shadow rapporteurs from the fellow political groups as well. I would also want to thank our staff and our assistants as well who have worked for many, many months across the complex range of issues covered in this legislation.  Many different organisations and stakeholders have made contact with us throughout our work on this, and I would like to thank them for their engagement and interest. The range of stakeholders interested in these issues again reflects the breadth and complexity of issues in the file. I recognise specifically those organisations concerned with the right to water, who rightly campaigned and continue to pressure us to secure that right in a meaningful way. I’m pleased that the text before us now is stronger in that regard than it could have been and that wording proposed by my Group last year was supported on that basis.  It is regrettable, as has been said, that the Council has taken so long to reach a position on this, meaning that we have not been able to enter into trilogue discussions. That will now happen in the next mandate, and when it does I hope that that Parliament, whatever its political composition, will reflect that commitment that this Parliament has made on a right to water.  Could this Parliament have gone further on that? Yes, we could have done so, but I think we need to see what has been achieved through this report as important work in progress and an important step forward. It would not be acceptable for the Council, or indeed the new Parliament, to water that down. This file is concerned with science, with technology and all those practical measures to ensure that our drinking water is safe and of high quality, but it also addresses, at its heart, a fundamental question of equality and social justice. It cannot be right that today, in 2019, there are people in the European Union who do not have access to clean, safe, affordable drinking water. This goes to the very heart of this Parliament’s commitment to upholding fundamental human rights, and that has been the approach of the S&D Group through our work on this file.  Colleagues, this might well be the final piece of legislation that I work on in this Parliament. If it is indeed the last piece of legislation I’m able to work on in this place, I’m pleased that it is this legislation – a directive which will affect every citizen in the European Union every single day. None of us should take it for granted, when we turn on our taps, that that drinking water is clean and safe. This is not just about pipes and taps; this is about equality and social justice. This Parliament should continue to push for a meaningful right to water for all. There is more to do on that, but this report represents an important step forward in that regard.  When people, as they will in the coming weeks, months and indeed years, say: what does the EU do, what is the EU for? This is what the EU does. It ensures that, whether you are in London, or Berlin, or Paris, or Strasbourg, or Brussels, when you turn your tap on there is a consistency in the safety and the quality of the drinking water we all enjoy.

name: Czesław HOC
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Water is a substance necessary for the life and preservation of homeostasis of the body. Water is our common heritage, which we should respect and safeguard for future generations. Due to its limited resources, we should rationally manage it and pay attention to the need to conserve water on a daily basis.  Between 250 and 500 million cubic metres of water are wasted every year in big cities. This amount would be enough for 10-20 million people per year. According to the calculations of some environmental organizations, turning the tap when brushing teeth in a four-person household saves 900 liters of water per month. If the tap leaks and the water drips at a rate of one drop per second, we lose almost 12,000 liters of water per year.  Thus, the directive aims to further increase the quality of tap water by tightening the maximum limits on the content of certain pollutants, e.g. lead, pathogens or substances that negatively affect the endocrine system. Microplastic levels will also be monitored. The new rules also guarantee better access to information.  If we reduced the consumption of bottled water, european households would save around EUR 600 million a year and, just as importantly, reduce plastic waste and greenhouse gas emissions. Tap water is cheap and environmentally friendly, but it must be super-good quality water and must be constantly controlled. Free water distributors should be allowed to be installed in public places, including restaurants. Thus, circular economy measures, support for sustainable management of drinking water in a resource-efficient way, which will help reduce bottled water consumption – in turn, reduce greenhouse gas emissions and marine litter. Let's remember – water is life!  Finally, the search for life in space begins with the question of the presence of water as a determining element of biological life. Let us treat this information as a civilisational warning.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which The Commission has presented the proposal to revise the Drinking Water Directive in response to the first successful European citizens' initiative Right2Water.  My party, the Free Voters, has traditionally advocated more citizen participation. It is therefore of particular concern to me that we take the motions of the citizens' initiatives seriously and that we respond to them quickly and comprehensively. I think that we, as a Parliament, have also acted accordingly. Despite the technical and political complexity, we presented our report back in October. We were ready for negotiations with the Council in the trialogue. Unfortunately, however, the Council has taken so much time that we can no longer adopt the directive in time for the end of the parliamentary term. This is a wasted opportunity. We must therefore conclude our report at first reading tomorrow. In doing so, we are sending a signal to the citizens that for us, citizen participation is not just a sham, but is being practiced.  With our report, however, we are also making good proposals in terms of content. For example, I am proud to offer a solution for how we can deal with microplastics and other new pollutants in drinking water in the future. In this way, we create confidence in water quality. We are also making proposals to ensure that the new risk-based approach does not become a burden on tried-and-tested structures, such as municipally organised water suppliers in Germany or micro-suppliers in the Alpine region and other regions.  I hope that we will be able to record these successes tomorrow for the negotiations of the next Parliament. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Michel Dantin, for the good cooperation and the shadow rapporteurs. Drinking water is the best-studied food and can be safely drunk from the tap in the EU, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Healthy drinking water is a fundamental right that cannot be denied to any European citizen. This is what the European Citizens' Initiative on the Right to Water, which was the first successful citizens' initiative in the EU, made this claim, and as a result of which we can stand here today, and the Commission has put forward a proposal that the European Parliament will hopefully support at first reading tomorrow.  Nevertheless, there are many citizens in the EU who, despite this, do not have access to adequate drinking water. Either because, as members of minority, marginalised groups, they simply do not have access to drinking water and we are talking about hundreds of thousands of people in the European Union, or because their governments, and this is the case in Hungary, are not able to ensure that the quality of drinking water is such that it meets EU standards and meets the expectations we have for healthy drinking water. They cannot ensure this, despite the fact that the European Union is providing millions of euros to Member States to implement the improvements that would enable this to be made. Unfortunately, these resources are not being used properly either. The use of EU funds is often a hotbed of corruption and does not reach the objectives that would result in quality drinking water.  Yet good quality drinking water is not just a health or drinking water issue.
