As has already been said, if we have succeeded in restoring trust in piped water in the minds of European citizens, we will be able to radically reduce the need for bottled water, thereby also radically reducing waste production. The proposal that we must adopt here tomorrow could contribute to restoring this trust. Unfortunately, the Council has not done the work that makes this possible, and in the future, not only the Council, but also the governments of the Member States must do their u uts to ensure healthy drinking water for all European citizens in the implementation of the proposal.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, those of us who have worked with the Right to Water movement for years are disappointed that the Commission chose this vehicle to address the human right to water. Because either we enshrine a human right to water or we fail to uphold it. There is no halfway house when it comes to human rights. So why is it that the human right to water is so special that it deserves this mediocre outcome? We are supposed to be the direct representatives of the people of Europe and yet we are doing a complete injustice to the Right to Water petition, which received nearly two million signatures, and also an injustice to the 2015 Parliament position. We in the left cannot endorse this report. To do so would be to accept the outcome of lenient, à la carte obligations as a response to a Europe-wide petition that sought to effect systemic change. The petition looked to address the serious problem of water poverty, which affects two million people in the EU. The demand that universal access to water would also include affordability. That demanded an end to the EU’s water liberalisation agenda and this is the response that we give the citizens: arguments of cost-effectiveness or what have. This is a clear dismissal of socio-economic rights. What we have is not good enough, and the Right To Water movements across the EU share that view. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to thank Mrs Boylan, because it is, of course, important that water is provided free of charge. Water is a common good, that is a matter of course. We must also take this approach vehemently. But it is about the infrastructure that provides water, and of course the infrastructure has to be paid for. Do you think that it is a good way to put this infrastructure out to public tender in the future, so that consumers can get the infrastructure at the best price?

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: blue-card answer. – No, we accept that the way Member States manage their water infrastructure is a competence for the Member States, and in fact in Ireland we have huge issues with the Commission interfering in how the Irish actually manage their water system, because in Ireland we have zero water poverty. And do you know why we have zero water poverty? Because we pay for our water through general taxation instead of punitively punishing citizens who can’t afford to pay their water taxes. So no, we don’t want it to go out to public tender. We don’t want liberalisation of water infrastructure.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while water as a common good in Italy is back at the centre of the political debate thanks to the 5-Star Movement, which is bringing the public water bill to the Chamber of Deputies eight years after the referendum in 2011, Europe is not live up to citizens' expectations on the issue of drinking water. Indeed, through the fault of the governments of half of Europe, which for months have been obstructing any reference to access to water in the new drinking water directive in the Council, we are about to re-vote on the text already approved by this Parliament last October, to hand it over to the next parliamentary term as a suggestion for the negotiations to come. In our opinion, however, this is a bad suggestion, because colleagues from the vast conservative majority in this House have blocked the way for significant improvements in access to water as everyone's right and as requested by almost two million citizens through the ' Right2Water' European Citizens' Initiative. But not only that, ladies and gentlemen: you also have a responsibility to have refused to bring to zero the thresholds for perfluoralkylic substances, PFAS, which are currently excluded from the scope of the current directive, which dates back to 1998. And, shamefully, you have introduced dangerous differentiations for the chemical compounds of this family, as if to say that some PFAS could be tolerated and therefore not regulated by the new Drinking Water Directive. But it is clear that the reality is quite different. And what happens in Veneto is there to testify, in a glaring way, that none of these toxic substances should ever be in drinking water, let alone accumulate in the blood of our children. In the interests of Italian and European citizens, However, I hope that the responses to access to water will soon arrive and that the revision of the parameters to guarantee quality at the point of consumption can take place rigorously, without giving in to pressure from industry and include an in-depth examination of the emerging pressures on the quality of drinking water. However, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, drinking water is a subject that is dear to me. It was with a team aggregation conference on the legal regime of drinking water that I began my university career 35 years ago. It is with a draft overhaul of the directive of 3 November 1998 on the quality of drinking water that I am closing my mandate as an MEP today. The overhaul was prompted by a European petition that garnered nearly two million signatures. It aims to ensure access to safe drinking water in Europe for all vulnerable groups, including Roma. The objective is generous, but I think it runs up against the principle of subsidiarity. Water regulation is the responsibility of the states, not the Union. If endocrine disruptors and various toxic products contaminate drinking water, it is up to them, in consultation with WHO, and not with the Brussels Commission. As for universal access to safe drinking water, European states are perfectly capable of ensuring it, without the need for the Union's moral lessons. Let us not be fooled, the Commission seeks to use the situation of the Roma to try to appropriate new competences in this area. The Europe of nations, which I would like to call for, must resist this kind of manoeuvre to restore their sovereignty to the States.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that the Commission has carried out a revision of the existing legislation on water for human consumption which is timely, because the current rules needed an update. The Commission has succeeded in identifying four main areas that need to be improved: parameters, risk-based approach, transparency in information and materials in contact with water.  It should also be stressed that Member States apply European Union rules in the field of drinking water quite rightly and that the current proposal is a step forward which will allow us to anticipate problems and prevent some. We currently have technical advances, improvement in laboratory controls, in new technologies; facilities have been amortized and there is greater knowledge of environmental variables. And all this can be improved by this Water Directive.  The European Parliament's text includes important elements of improvement in relation to the conditions of access to a quality water supply, with the promotion of rational water consumption, with the reduction of leaks in the supply network , which is very important, with the provision of the climate impact of water resources and with greater security of the materials used. And finally, it provides solutions to the reduction of water consumption of plastic bottles.  It also envisages the possibility that small water distributors may have more flexible conditions than large ones.  I would like to end by congratulating my colleague, Dr Dantin, who has tried to be cautious in balancing the new obligations of the Directive with the need for containment of supply tariffs and the principle of cost recovery. And I also regret the lack of agility that the Council has had in order to reach an agreement during this parliamentary term.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Everyone has the right to drink water when you are thirsty and the water should be safe to drink. This applies to all of us, whether you have a home or are without, whether you belong to a minority or a majority, whether you are in sparsely populated areas or in the big city. Today, however, there are still groups in Europe that do not have access to clean water. That is unacceptable. For me, it is especially important that the water we drink is safe. It must not contain dangerous chemicals that are harmful to our health. This requires better measurement, but also sharp limit values for chemicals. Human health must be at the forefront. This applies not least to endocrine disruptors. We know that these substances lead to more people getting diabetes, other dangerous diseases or difficulties in having children. Of course, in Europe – yes, all over the world – we should ensure that we can be sure that we do not get these dangerous substances into drinking water. Parliament has a strong negotiating position here, which we must not compromise on. I know that there are several Member States that want to soften the regulatory framework. It is important that Parliament stands up for safety, for human health, for clean water. On the other hand, however, it is important in the negotiations to also listen to the fact that things may differ in different countries in terms of geographical differences. It may therefore be a good thing that Parliament's position in these negotiations gives the individual countries some flexibility to ensure that the best, most practical solutions are developed to achieve the objectives. Clean water should be a matter of course. Everyone should be able to drink water if you're thirsty.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, thank you for the floor. Statistics show that global water consumption is six times greater than it was a century ago, and is expected to increase by another 20 to 50% by 2050, and these are huge figures. A third of the world's largest groundwater systems are at risk of drying out. The number of people living under severe water stress is expected to be as high as £3.2bn by 2050. Even in such a rich source of underground drinking water as Rye Island – such as the name of our country in Slovakia, whole villages have bacteria-infected water and are reliant on tanks with drinking water. Organisations and activists warn the European Commission that public authorities often do not act, do not do enough to protect water, but prioritise the economic interests of companies, and they do not respect the environment. The Drinking Water Directive aims to ensure access to water for every citizen, but has not been reviewed since 1999. In doing so, we know that climate change is changing living conditions and droughts are the cause of global migration, which we have had to face since 2015. That is why we must act.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, water and sanitation are a human right. Water is a common good, a public good, not a commodity. We call on the Commission, Commissioner, to implement the right to water and sanitation, as recognised by the UN and as a country like Bolivia has done, the author that water is a human right. It is necessary for States and Europe to ensure access to common water with adequate and modernised infrastructure because infrastructure is not always able to provide adequate service. Water services should be excluded from liberalisation. It is social justice and universal and equitable access must be guaranteed in every corner of Europe. For me, this report is in line with the Commission's intention to recognise the right to water. States have again boycotted and often do not comply with the right to sanitation or access to clean water, as is the case with the Spanish State and other states that boycott this right that supports a large part of European citizenship. Having clean water is good for human and animal health and water as a common good is good for all citizens. And I speak with knowledge of the cause, because in my country, which is the country of a thousand rivers, water is paid at a very high price. Moreover, another important thing is to update citizens' access to data on the quality of drinking water, which is not always guaranteed.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we shall be voting against the Dantin report. Unfortunately, this text has even got worse. The objective was simple: to bring the European institutions into line with the call for the 'Right2Water' European citizens' initiative, that is to say, as the UN has also indicated, to make access to drinking water and sanitation a universal human right, removed from the logic of the market and profit. Instead, we are faced with only a series of bland recommendations to the Member States. Furthermore, the report has not adopted sufficient parameters to contain contamination of water by dangerous substances of industrial origin, such as PFAS. I will vote against this report: I owe it to the millions of Italian citizens who voted for a referendum on public water, I owe it to the mothers 'no PFAS', I owe it to the citizens who have signed up to the 'Right2Water' initiative.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, endocrine disruptors are everywhere: in rivers, groundwater and tap water. Even in very low doses, these molecules disrupt the hormonal system and cause behavioural and, worse, reproductive physical abnormalities. The NGO Generations Futures has relied on three government studies on tap water in France and the figures are clear: endocrine disruptors account for half of the most present pesticides. Of course, the nature of the waters varies between the different states and the national scale is much more suited than the European scale in this area. However, I disagree with the rapporteur's position in the explanatory statement. This position tends to minimize risks, citing a lack of scientific consensus. The same applies to microplastic research, which is only at an early stage. I'm sorry, but the health of the French is not negotiable.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is a fact that two million citizens of our European Union do not have clean water in their homes. There are children, there are older people. I share the aim of having clean water for all people in Europe. This would make Europe a special place in the world, becoming the first continent where everyone has clean water. However, despite all the improvements that we have been able to make here in Parliament – in committee and in plenary – what has been proposed by the Commission is extra regulation and unnecessary bureaucracy where the water is already clean today. This does not achieve the objective, but increases costs – the cost to households, the cost to water users. That is why I shall be voting against this report again. The objective remains the right one. The issue must be back in the European Parliament in the next period in order to ensure that those who do not have clean water get clean water. But absurd parameters, which are not even proposed by the World Health Organisation, which would lead to the construction of new treatment plants, for example in the case of clean water sources, and so on – we do not need that. We are opposed to this. That is why I am voting against the report, but I am still working – as before – to achieve a real objective so that those who need and do not yet have clean water can get it in the future.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are called upon to confirm our vote on this important directive on the right to drinking water, which the European Commission has decided to update after more than twenty years, in order to respond better to the new challenges on climate change and for a just transition to a circular economy, in order to reduce water waste and the production of plastic waste. It is the European citizens themselves – almost 2 million – who have asked us, through their initiative, to guarantee everyone, everyone!, the right to universal access to drinking water, a primary human right which, I repeat, must be guaranteed and not just promoted. It is also essential to choose, which we support, greater transparency and easier access for consumers to precise and clear information on the water coming out of their tap. And on the subject of transparency and health, we cannot ignore the serious PFAS pollution that has taken place in Italy, in the Veneto region, and which has affected almost half a million citizens who now have a level of these endocrine disruptors in the blood hundreds of times higher than normal. There were no limits on these substances in the current directive, they have now been introduced, but they are still too high! We need to reach values close to zero, as the Citizens of Veneto are asking us to do, not only in the light of EFSA's recent opinion, which reduced the level of the tolerable daily intake in the blood. We hope that the next Parliament and the Italian Government in the Council, which will be called upon to take a final decision, will choose to set limits close to zero.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, access to quality water is an achievement that, unfortunately, we often take for granted. However, this area needs to be regulated, monitored and adapted to new challenges and circumstances on the ground.  As an MP coming from a country extremely rich in water resources, I commend the rapporteur for respecting the spirit of the principle of subsidiarity, leaving responsibility for the application of minimum quality requirements to Member States. The risk-based approach is also absolutely justified and I wholeheartedly welcome its standardisation with this proposal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, water is an indispensable human right for life and so we must protect it from privatisation, pollution, inadequate plantations such as eucalyptus, or large infrastructure. But across the european union, this is not the case. In Galicia, my country, rivers are polluted by mines, such as San Fins or Taurus, by major works, such as at high speed, by insufficient or ineffective wastewater treatment plants that dump directly into the sea or rivers, such as the River Sar.  Macro-landfills like Sogama, projects that fill the holes of polluting waste that leave behind quarries like Miramontes or Casalonga. There is also pollution caused by the slats of purifying stations that are lying on land, by industrial agriculture, such as Coren and Leyma, glyphosate or pesticides. All this is happening, favoured and funded by the Union. We must put an end to all this because it is what will allow us to have healthy water.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the debate on the Water Quality Directive for human consumption is certainly very important, and it is very important for a number of reasons. The first, because it is the only popular initiative that has managed to succeed with more than one and a half million signatures of European citizens, concerned about this issue.  It cannot be less: access to and sustainable management of water, as well as sanitation, is the number six target of the sustainable development goals and, according to Eurostat data, almost 2% of Europeans have difficulties in accessing it. Moreover, such access is an intrinsic part of the European Pillar of Social Rights, which, in point 20, establishes the right to access good quality essential services, including water.  We must also adopt this Directive because it can help us achieve an objective linked to the reduction of waste generation, since the increased consumption of tap water, encouraged by the increase in levels of its quality, can reduce the consumption of bottled water by almost a fifth, while reducing the plastic waste generated in parallel. Higher quality, better access—especially for those more vulnerable and marginalized sectors—greater transparency for consumers in their consumer bill, and lower bureaucracy in improving electronic information systems. I make my own, Mr President, the words that President Juncker uttered during the State of the Union address: "Today's Europeans and future generations deserve a Europe that protects their standards of living." We deserve a Europe that empowers us, a Europe that helps and protects us.  And I would like to congratulate Mr Dantin, in conclusion, on the great work done in the processing of this dossier. However, it is a disgrace that, despite the efforts of the Commission and this Parliament, the Member States have not considered it a priority and we must postpone the negotiations until the next term of office.  (He finished his speech in Catalan).

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, the Drinking Water Directive has been in force for more than 20 years and is one of the pillars of EU legislation in this area, providing quality supply in more than 99% of supplies. Its review, as mentioned here, follows the first successful European citizens' initiative, Right4water, which collected 1.6 million signatures in favour of improving access to drinking water for all Europeans. It is therefore a review that is timely and necessary and provides for measures to facilitate access to water in public spaces and align drinking water quality standards with the most up-to-date scientific parameters. I am sorry, however, that we have not gone any further. Some positive things can be underlined: the reduction of concentration limits for certain pollutants, such as lead, the introduction of new limits for endocrine disruptors, the start of the application of microplastic monitoring procedures, the promotion of the use of free access sources and in this case the availability of tap water. And also the transition to a circular economy, helping to reduce the use of plastic bottles.  We should, however, have gone further, in particular in accessing water and monitoring microplastics. We fell short of the ambition of the citizen petition, but it was a breakthrough that we made on a path that we must continue.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this proposal amending the Directive on the quality of water intended for human consumption is of the utmost importance. It significantly increases the direct costs of water supply, to be charged to users, and also increases indirect public burdens for supervision and control, without this being reflected in increased security, on the contrary. It hinders the provision of the public service, favours privatisation, makes economic supply solutions that can be safe and viable, particularly at local level, unviable. It passes on the margins of the recommendations of entities such as the World Health Organization, calls into question the functions of the State of supervision, supervision and control replaced by an alleged self-control of water service concessionaires, is compliant with non-compliant dealers. This proposal, in a case, means more expensive, more unsafe, worse quality water. Only the Undisguised submission of the European Commission to the interests of transnational water can explain it.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Dear Chairman, thank you very much. I am pleased that today we are discussing the quality of water used by our citizens, as according to a new survey by the European Union Environment Agency, 40%, only 40% of European rivers, lakes, estuaries and coastal waters meet the environmental standards provided for in the European Water Directive. It is therefore clear that most Member States must make further efforts to meet the directive's objectives of ensuring sufficient amounts of quality water for the environment in the future, but also for human needs.  The current Directive has been in place for 20 years without serious modifications, which is why I welcome the efforts of Rapporteur Michel Dantin and the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety Committee, for aligning drinking water quality standards with the latest health data and for adapting to the legislative framework to better address new challenges such as the increasing and prolonged droughts caused by climate change.  I would again particularly stress the importance of the first European citizens' initiative Right to water, supported by more than 1 800 000 citizens. The right to clean, drinking and quality water is the lowest standard we must ensure, and this has been confirmed by the United Nations. Water is a natural resource that, thank God, in my homeland Croatia has enough, but also water must remain a public good, we must manage it responsibly and I am happy today that in this home we strive to ensure the citizens of the European Union the right to drinking water.  Of course, I also support the Commission in its efforts to improve the health of our citizens, but I regret that we are postponing this document for the next term. What I welcome is that the principle of subsidiarity remains and, in this sense, I hope that in the second term this will be resolved.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, this is a good step forward in securing clean and good quality drinking water for all people, which is a human right and a fundamental right. It also takes into account the waste of water and calls on member states to take better measures. It will also improve the indicators by which the quality of drinking water will be assessed in the future. However, there are still quite a few challenges ahead. Firstly, according to some estimates, up to 40% of drinking water is drowning in distribution systems, and this is an unsustainable situation for both environmentally, economically and water users. Stricter standards should have been imposed on this in the future, and at least consumers should know in their water bill how much of the levy they have paid has been wasted. Secondly, the new challenges to drinking water quality that have already been mentioned here should have been better taken into account. Now we are talking about hormone disruptors, the combined effects of several different chemicals and the much-talked about microplastics and nanoplastics. We know that the pressure on the water resources from which drinking water is made will increase in the future and, at the same time, the risks of pollution will increase. This is the last moment to really take the lead and to take joint European decisions that also guarantee clean drinking water sources from the environment, efficient water use – distribution and use – and yes our European responsibility is also to take care of both new and existing risks, for example in water pipelines. This must be a matter for decision and assessment at EU level, not by the Member States alone.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the If EU citizens have more confidence in the quality of drinking water, they will also use less water from plastic bottles. That is why the Drinking Water Directive is closely linked to the vote on the reduction of plastic waste that we have carried out here today. This is not only good for the environment, but also spares the backs and wallets of EU citizens. If households drink more tap water, bottled water consumption could be drastically reduced, and households could save up to €600 million a year. It is therefore right that we have once again reduced the permitted maximum levels for certain pollutants such as lead, harmful bacteria and certain hormone-active substances such as endocrine disruptors in order to increase confidence in the quality of our drinking water. As plastic in drinking water itself is becoming an increasing problem, I also welcome the calls for monitoring of the content of microplastics. Unfortunately, the problem of microplastics has not yet been sufficiently researched, but it can have health effects. It is also regrettable that the Member States have not been able to agree more quickly on a common position on this directive and have allowed only very limited requirements for access to drinking water. It would have been important for EU citizens to launch this directive before the European elections on the occasion of World Water Day on 22 March. In any case, it was not our fault. I would like to thank my colleague Michel Dantin and his staff for their excellent work. I would also like to express my regret for those who do not go on the road and will vote against the report, because this is a first right step in the right direction.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, water, that is life. It is a strategic raw material and we need to take better care of it, because even in the European Union there are already countries, regions where water is scarce, where drinking water must be imported from a far distance.  Water is indeed becoming a strategic raw material, which is why I welcome the European directive amending our approach. Twenty years on, this amendment is certainly necessary. I therefore support all four priority areas for improvement, as the rapporteur has said here, be it risk assessment, increased transparency, access to information and the quality of water materials. Of course, tightening the values of certain indicators is necessary, but they cannot be set up for no reason to make drinking water more expensive, and it must, of course, be sufficiently subjected to scientific research. However, health comes first and that is how we need to approach it.  Implementation and responsibility for water quality remain with the Member States and the principle of subsidiarity is therefore respected. This must also be applied when ensuring access to water. I also consider it important to observe transparency and the provision of sufficient information for consumers.  Finally, I would like to call for the gentle treatment of drinking water, and I recall that, thanks to the European Union's Structural Funds, the management of waste water in particular has been significantly improved in the new Member States. Water resources and water purity must therefore be protected for the health of all of us and for the future.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to thank our rapporteur, Dantin, very warmly. Because we see that water is a very important element in our global survival strategy – only a very small part of the water is drinking water, fresh water – I am pleased that we will be able to present the UN water report at the European Parliament in Brussels on 3 April, next week, at 4.30 p.m. I believe that this is also another historical benchmark, because for us – and I am also speaking here for the Committee on Development – the sustainable development goals are of particular importance to us.  We all know that without water there is no sustainable diet: food, feed need water. And without Objective 7, namely renewable energy, we will not have enough water and not enough food. That is why the Sustainable Development Goals Nos 2, 6 and 7 are particularly important in development policy, so that new opportunities can be created for small and medium-sized enterprises, especially in rural areas, because rural areas need precisely this infrastructure.  When you see that today 50 per cent of the people admitted to hospitals are admitted because of bad water, then we have a special responsibility here. I believe that it is crucial for us to push forward this policy that we are pursuing here in Europe, even in the not well-developed countries of the world. Millions of people do not have access to clean drinking water, and I call on the Commission here to develop a concept to meet the Sustainable Development Objective 6, namely clean water, sanitation and sanitation, with new business plans, so that we can invest here worldwide so that people can benefit from this international supply.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, I greet Mr Dantin for his excellent work on this report. I would like to remind you of the European citizens' initiative Right2Water, of which I was shadow rapporteur, which reminded us that we have until 2030 to meet the objective for sustainable development number 6 with regard to universal and equitable access to water. And the truth is that we are not only interested in discussing the quality of the water we consume in Europe, but not only that, but also discussing what ways we can avoid the scarcity of drinking water, aggravated by the effect of climate change, as well as access to water as a fundamental human right. This Directive responds to the need for harmonisation of european minimum criteria that make us proud, both in quality and accessibility itself. In addition to these factors, this Directive also brings greater transparency in the Union's water exploration sector and the recognition that citizens, as consumers, have the right to be informed about the origin, quality and efficiency of distribution systems, which we all pay, directly or indirectly. Ensuring the quality of water for human consumption in Europe is not only the guarantee of our public health, but also one of the sustenances of social justice.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I very much welcome the messages from Parliament, confirming that the European Union should respond and act in the interests of our citizens and that everybody supports the Sustainable Development Goal 6 and better access to water. I am hoping to see this reflected in the first reading position so that Parliament comes to trilogues with an ambitious position when it comes to the quality of our water, health protection and access to water. I would like to reiterate that the Commission stands ready to help the co—legislators reach an agreement that will support the objectives we all share and will ensure that our citizens benefit from the highest health protection for decades to come. I wish you success for the vote, and thank you again for your commitment to this fight.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, this is indeed the last time I have presented a report in this Chamber, so I want to tell you what I have on my heart after hearing a number of untruths this evening.  When we talk about the price of water, we are not talking about the price of water, we are talking about the price of water, we are talking about the price of pipes, the price of sewage treatment plants, we are talking about the price of monitoring the analyses. I hear the two million or so citizens who have signed the contribution for water that is accessible to all. We all share that goal, but I also hear from the millions of consumers who are asking us to keep the price of water, that is, to have investments that are as wise as possible to serve the interests of the consumer, the consumer citizen and to preserve his health. We do not get along with the science. WHO regularly produces data, it is this data that we are incorporating into the European text. When we are told that a number of parameters need to be incorporated, WHO should recommend a method of assessing human health. We do not have this method of evaluation for microplastics, we do not have this method of evaluating human health for endocrine disruptors. So yes, we have to keep working. We must continue to work with determination because water is the essence of life and because access to quality water for all must be a requirement. If we succeed in improving tap water, if we guarantee to our citizens that under any circumstances they will have access to quality water, then yes, we will remove the plastic bottle.  The citizen must know that tap water costs them thousands of times less than the water they buy in bottles in which they seem to have, for some of them, absolute confidence and I question this absolute confidence. Mr President, Commissioner, you are the only two in this house who have a glass of water in front of you. So lift this glass to the health of Europe's 500 million consumers. We have to fight, we have to keep fighting for quality water. I trust those who will succeed us.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, March 28, 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Access to drinking water is a very important issue for European citizens that affects their daily lives, health and activities. This directive represents a significant step forward and is based on the objective of universal and fair access to drinking water at an affordable price for all and on the European Citizens' Initiative Right2Water, which provides good quality water in more than 99% of cases in the Union. However, the Directive has not been subject to any significant transformation for more than 20 years. It is therefore necessary to adapt drinking water quality standards to the latest scientific data and to change the legal framework to better respond to new challenges such as climate change and the transition to a circular economy. Member States' responsibility for applying these minimum quality requirements should also be maintained and appropriate powers should be given, in particular within their national drinking water authorities, to assess the risk to human health if parametric values are exceeded.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the report by Nuno Melo, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems (police and police cooperation, asylum and migration) and amending [Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [Eurodac Regulation],] Regulation (EU) 20 18/XX [Law Enforcement Regulation), Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [ECRIS-TCN Regulation] and Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [eu-LISA Regulation) (COM(2018)0480 - C8-0293/2018 - 2017/0352(COD)) (A8-0348/2018), and – Jeroen Lenaers, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs , on the amended proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems (borders and visas) and amending Council Decision 2004/512/EC, Council Regulation (EC) No 767/2008, Council Decision 2008/633/JHA, Regulation (EU) 2016/399, Regulation (EU) 2017/2226, Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [ETIAS Regulation], Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [REGULATION ON SIS in the field of border checks] and Regulation (EU) 2018/XX [EU-LISA Regulation] (COM(2018)0478 - C8-0294/2018 - 2017/0351(COD)) (A8-0347/2018)

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, with this legislation, we are taking an important step towards making Europe safer, getting available information about criminals and terrorists to the right place faster and more fully, to control our borders better and more efficiently, and to ensure that criminals or people with evil in the sense can no longer use and get away with false identities. Here in Strasbourg, just a few kilometres from this chamber in the bunker of the EU-LISA agency building, are the servers that run our European security and border management information systems. Those servers are only a few centimetres apart in that bunker, and yet they cannot and must not communicate with each other to this day. The lack of communication between these European information systems is causing blind spots in our security structure, and this proposal is finally ending them.  Through the European search portal, police officers, border guards and customs officers can immediately request from all information systems the right information they need to do their job at the touch of a button. Through the biometric matching service, we can search with our fingerprints, with facial scans. It is precisely because of this that it becomes much easier to do our work with one system instead of with all these different systems. It's cheaper, it's safer, it's clearer and it's better: don't reinvent the wheel every time, but use our energy more efficiently and efficiently.  Through the common identity register, we create a central repository for biographical and biometric data of people who are not from Europe. Existing data is stored smarter and it makes it much easier for us to do things. We can more easily check the quality of our data. We can more easily streamline law enforcement access to this information, and we can more easily monitor and identify undocumented people on the street. And finally, the last part: the detector of multiple identities. We have seen a lot in recent years that criminals with sometimes as many as 20 different identities are registered in our data systems. We saw it with Anis Amri, the terrorist who was registered under 14 different identities. With these components, we can prevent this in the future. This Parliament has said from the outset that we can only agree to a proposal like this if the fundamental rights of citizens are also properly guaranteed. Good security policy must go hand in hand with guaranteeing the fundamental rights of our citizens, and we have done so. We're not going to collect more data, we're going to use the data we already have much better. We keep the strict access requirements of the underlying systems intact. We have a new web application that helps citizens to guarantee their rights.  This new regulation is also a new way of working that we will be reaping in the coming years. And I would also like to thank Commissioners Avramopoulos and King for their efforts in this matter. I want to thank my co-rapporteur Nuno Melo. I would like to thank all colleagues, but especially the staff, consultants, who have all helped us in recent times to bring this to a successful conclusion. With interoperability – and I am convinced of this – we are really ensuring a safer Europe, and we are doing so by giving the people who are watching over our security, the policeman on the streets, the border guards at the airport, the customs officers at the border crossing – to give these people the right tools to do their job.

name: Nuno MELO
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioners, what are we talking about? We are talking about access to information, very relevant information, quickly, systematically and efficiently, but also controlled, which is essential for us to control our external borders, to fight crime, to combat terrorism. Nowadays it is still very difficult to detect cases, for example of multiple identities, various types of fraud committed using the identities of other people. Several authorities, such as SIS or ETIAS, already have information. We can't say that the information doesn't exist. The point is that this information is not shared. Each entity operates barricaded, corporately, in what is its organization, in what is its profession, and does not share them because there is nothing to do with it and, in fact, there is no system that is, at the moment, created and that is sufficiently effective. It is precisely for this purpose that we have worked for a long time here in the European Parliament - and we have worked genuinely - in a way in which everyone has made their contribution, shadow rapporteurs, certainly my co-rapporteur, whom I really thank, Mr Lenaers, commissioners, we have Commissioner King and Commissioner Avramopoulos here, one and the other have been present at our meetings and have given very decisive answers , and especially at the interinstitutional level, Parliament and the European Commission have been able to show that, when they are in any way of what is a priority, we can give the best answers to the citizens. And so it happened. In a report that was very technical, overly technical, we were all able to learn, to look at what was difficult and today we can ensure that, by the time these solutions are implemented, citizens will be safer than they have been so far. I was talking about cases of multiple identities. If we wanted to translate this into two examples in just one of the attacks committed in Germany, one of the terrorists had applied for asylum using fourteen different identities, fourteen different identities! And in another case, in France, one of the terrorists, of Tunisian nationality, was registered with seven different identities. This is very impressive and is the kind of example that, when we tell our fellow citizens, we do not understand. They do not understand, for example, that an attack may take place in France and information that existed in Belgium has not been transmitted. They do not understand that an attack could take place in Belgium and information in France had not been transmitted. Not often for lack of goodwill, but for lack of this system, this quick, expeditious resource, which allows the authorities, having doubts, safely and with respect for legality, protecting data, so they could do so. That can't happen anymore. Citizens' security, effective control of our borders, the fight against crime and terrorism really have to be a priority and if they are not a priority our lack of response is unfortunately measured later in the number of victims and in the world of crime. And we are elected exactly to, to the extent of our possibilities, make a difference. We have to be effective in this fight! I am very proud to end this mandate having been co-rapporteur of this initiative and, above all, that we achieved such a fruitful result when so many, at first, doubted. And so I re-thank you all.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I thank Commissioner King for being here tonight.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: membro della Commissione. – La ringrazio anche io, signor Presidente, grazie molte per l'ospitalità. Mr President, this debate is a landmark moment for the European Union. It is probably – I say ‘probably’ because there is another issue still waiting – the last time we are debating a security initiative in the plenary and it is also in opportunity to reflect, realising how far we have come in the last five years. From the first time we debated in plenary – it was late 2014 – we saw eye to eye on the need to change the way Member States cooperated on security. To overcome the security taboos of the past and look at internal security as a collective European issue that can only be addressed with more trust and ever-closer cooperation. In this sense our debate today is an excellent case in point in terms of our progress during these five years.  The interoperability of our information systems for borders, migration and security is an issue which concerns all of us. Interoperability is an exercise in the silo breaking, for – while it might sound technical – it is exactly the step change we need to enhance the security of our citizens in Europe, to protect and better manage our common external borders and better manage migration. For precisely these reasons, I would like to express my gratitude to the co-rapporteurs, Mr Lenaers and Mr Melo, as well as to all the shadow rapporteurs and their assistants, for realising the importance of this proposal we submitted a bit more than one year ago.  Interoperability is the most effective way to fight fragmentation of efforts, close information gaps and address the risks of terrorists and serious criminals crossing our borders undetected.  This is the European Union at its best, empowering and supporting our border guards and police officers with the right tools to do their job and protect citizens.  Interoperability is also the European Union taking a decisive step towards an effective and genuine security union, managing the parallel and interconnected challenges of migration and security in a comprehensive and holistic way. All this while making sure, throughout the process and with your great contribution, that fundamental rights will be fully respected, that interoperability is no big brother or a super database and that nothing changes in terms of the access of each official or authority to the underlying data in our information systems.  The involvement of the Fundamental Rights Agency and the European Data Protection Supervisor in the preparatory process of our proposal showed, from day one, that security and privacy are two sides of the same coin, and in the European Union both can and should be ensured. Dear colleagues, our citizens want more and a stronger Europe when it comes to security. We see this in every public survey and we hear it every time we are out there meeting our citizens. Interoperability can be the game-changer in how we use information to the best possible effect to keep our citizens safe.  In an electoral year, this could not be more important. We are delivering concrete action, responding to our citizens’ top concerns. We can all be justifiably proud of this achievement.  My sincere thanks once again therefore go out to all who made a contribution to our excellent co-rapporteurs, Mr Melo and Mr Lenaers, and of course to my good friend and colleague, Julian King, for his dedication, commitment and determination to lead us all to this successful outcome.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, well, we could have come up with a better name but interoperability is crucially important for some of the reasons that we have just heard. We started by asking those on the front line how we could help, what they needed. And they replied that there were some issues surrounding the handling, the use of information. In particular, there was a challenge surrounding picking up, identifying people who were using multiple identities. We’ve heard that that led to some horrible terrorist attacks. One of the reasons that those on the front line felt occasionally frustrated was because of the way that they used our EU-wide databases and the way our EU-wide databases – security and others – interacted or, in some cases, didn’t interact effectively. We replied that we would take steps to try and help them, to help them to do their jobs to keep us safe, to provide police officers and border guards with efficient access to accurate and complete data, making the best possible use of the information that we had in our systems and finding ways to eliminate some of the silos, some of the gaps and some of the blind spots. Indeed, that is what our citizens expected, as Commissioner Avramopoulos has underlined. Many of them, I think, assumed that we can do it already, which is why it’s so important that we’ve been able to get to this point and take this step.  But all of us who have been involved knew from the outset that there were many complex and, indeed, sensitive issues that had to be managed if we were going to make a success of this. That is why I think we can rightly recognise, as all the speakers have done so far, that we got to this point by working effectively together. The Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), indeed across Parliament, at the Council, at the European Data Protection Supervisor and Fundamental Rights Agency, from the very beginning.  For me, this is another positive from the work we’ve done around this subject. We have shown that we can integrate all of those different stakeholders from the very beginning of our work and we’ve shown that we can do effective security policy integrating the input from the Data Supervisor and the Fundamental Rights Agency from the outset. And then again, later on in the process, give them an opportunity to check that the work is effectively respecting those key fundamental rights. The work that we’ve achieved together will improve the management of the Schengen external border. It will enhance the internal security of all our Member States. Law enforcement and border guards will have easier access to the information that they are entitled to use. They will be better able to determine when someone has been registered with multiple identities, picking up those who are hiding behind multiple identities, but at the same time, facilitating travel for legitimate travellers. In doing all of this, we have been very careful to maintain purpose limitations and safeguard those fundamental rights. Data processing will be limited to what is strictly necessary and proportionate. No new kinds of information will be collected for the purpose of interoperability.  Indeed, if I may say so, the scrutiny that the European Parliament exerted around this file has further clarified the protections and safeguards, for example around the right to information. And that is something, personally, that I very much welcome. The result is a strong piece of legislation that addresses security needs of our Member States, makes use of innovative technologies, but includes safeguards needed to process data in full compliance with our fundamental rights. I very much enjoyed working – if I can say that on a personal basis – with the rapporteurs, Mr Lenaers, Mr Melo, and indeed with all of their teams. I know it’s not the usual custom here but can I just take two seconds to thank the Commission team as well who worked very, very hard on this, putting in many long hours. Together we got to this result and once the legislation is adopted it will be for all of us to make sure it’s implemented effectively, starting with eu-LISA, an agency which I know enjoys the full support of this House.  We’re going to have to make sure that all of these measures that we have now agreed are put into practice. The innovations that we’ve set out, that you have underlined, will only make a real difference to security on the ground if and when they are fully implemented, collectively at EU level and in each and every Member State. I’m sure that Parliament will want to continue to monitor closely the follow-up to this file and this question of implementation.  For our part, the Commission will provide support as well as funding and, where necessary, we will not hesitate to use our enforcement powers to make sure that the Member States live up to the commitments that they have taken. Again, this agreement is good for the EU, it’s good for the security of all of our citizens. I commend it to this House.

name: Emil RADEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Avramopulus, Commissioner King, I would first like to thank the co-rapporteurs for their successful work on the report.  Terrorist attacks in recent years have demonstrated a huge gap in European security. Different law enforcement agencies have a huge amount of information, but they don't exchange it because they don't have the necessary mechanisms. Yes, the European Union has built up a variety of systems over the years, but each of them has a specific purpose and the information in it is stored independently, without being checked against the information in other systems. This has led to a fragmented approach to security.  That's why the need to ensure that the so-called "no-fly zone" is on the agenda. interconnection of systems. In a more understandable language, how the different European databases - the visa system, the Schengen system, the entry/exit system and others, to talk to each other and a policeman or border guard, in the process of checking a person, to see if there is a signal for that person in one of the systems.  I welcome the fact that with the agreement reached, this will now be a reality. The competent authorities will now be able to carry out full checks on suspicious persons through biographical and biometric data, will be able to detect the presence of several identities for a person, be able to verify the information available and thereby better assess whether the person in front of them poses a threat to European security.  At the same time, in order not to undermine the rights of innocent people, the protection of personal data will be ensured, with only officers with access to the systems able to carry out specific in-depth data checks.  For this interconnection to succeed, it is the responsibility of The Member States to report and quality information in European databases. Only in this way will a genuine exchange of information so important for the fight against terrorism and illegal migration will be achieved.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, what we are discussing today was not an easy legislation. My colleague from S&D, Péter Niedermüller, and I worked hard to ensure that any compromise reached safeguarded our citizens’ fundamental rights and also the rights of any persons whose data will be compiled and stored. What we are dealing with is a large-scale information system, and at no point as S&D were we ready to compromise on the principles of Union law on data protection and the fundamental rights of individual citizens. For us, security was always a priority, but so is data protection. Through our negotiations we always wanted to ensure effective and efficient information exchange between the EU information systems for the professionals on the ground: police officers, border guards, migration officers and consulate staff members. That’s why as S&D we were pushing to include very strong wording on non-discrimination and fundamental rights provisions, together with specific references that will protect our citizens’ privacy and their personal data. That’s why we pushed also for the creation of a web portal that will help citizens whose data is incorrectly stored in one of the EU databases. We pushed for this because we wanted to provide the possibility to people wanting to challenge the data held about them incorrectly, by directing them to the correct authority responsible for rectifying those data. We need to ensure that in our quest to address security issues, we do not sideline rights that our citizens have worked hard for, including the right to protect fully the data. A balance can and should always be reached.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this legislative package regulates interoperability, i.e. interconnectivity of EU databases. Both existing databases, such as the widely used and newly reformed visa information system, and databases under development are eligible. A foreigner who has been granted a visa or travelled visa-free to Europe, wanted criminals, migrants, convicts, etc. will all be able to be found through a simple search. Border guards will be able to simultaneously consult multiple databases, compare fingerprints with each other and identify multiple identities of the same person. If the police cannot identify a foreigner, the police will only have to consult one database containing identity details of foreigners.  In recent years, the EU has faced an increasing number of migrants entering the EU irregularly and with a constant threat to internal security, as witnessed by the terrorist attacks. By linking the information systems to each other, Europe's borders are better monitored. This also increases our security and combats irregular migration. N-VA is satisfied with the final text, which creates a single counter for border guards and police officers to verify identity documents in various databases, and firmly favors it. It should not be forgotten that it also benefits data protection and quality now that arrangements have also been made on this subject. I therefore hope that this Parliament will adopt this legislative package by a large majority and that the Member States will then put it into practice quickly.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioners, today is a day of celebration. For one debate, we have two Commissioners who talk to each other and do not listen to anything, but finally we have the pleasure of having them. I don't want to spoil my pleasure.  If there is one issue that I wanted to see come to fruition in this Parliament, it is interoperability. We have developed and modernized a number of systems in recent years. I quote them: VIS, ECRIS, SIS, Eurodac, ETIAS and so on. But these systems currently have no connection to each other, which weakens the efficiency of the data collected and wastes valuable time for users who need to view it.  Interoperability introduces four new features that I support. I support the creation of the new European search portal whereby police officers on the ground and border guards will be able to simultaneously check all information systems related to justice, security and external border control, instead of having to consult them separately as is currently the case. I support the multiple identity detector by which the authorities of the European Union will be able to detect identity fraud and through which blind spots, in which people are registered under different names in different databases and thus escape their real identification, will be avoided. I welcome the creation of the common directory of identity data which will greatly facilitate the identification of third-country nationals present in the Territory of the Union. Finally, I welcome the creation of the shared biometric data matching service. I would also like to point out, because it is important, that no additional data on people will be collected because of interoperability and that all the data protection rules in place for each system will continue to apply. In conclusion, I would like to congratulate our two colleagues Jeroen Lenaers and Nuno Melo for the quality of their work and I assure them of the support of the ALDE Group in the vote on these two regulations. Mr President, if this were to be the last time I speak in this Chamber, I would be happy to have done so on this issue.

name: Romeo FRANZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The debate on the interoperability of European databases is not purely technical. No, this is a matter of highly political issues. The European Data Protection Supervisor has warned us that such a step marks a point where there is no going back. The European Data Protection Board also raised concerns, at the time as article 29. But why are our own experts warning against this? In data protection law, there is the principle of purpose limitation. It is intended to prevent a state that knows everything about us and brings this information together centrally. But that is exactly what we are creating when we introduce the so-called CIR with the proposed interoperability. The CIR is a central identity register to which various authorities have access. We are creating a kind of monster database here, in which not only criminals fall, but also innocent citizens. Now we often hear the argument that we have a problem with multiple identities. Especially from conservative circles the example of the assassin of the Berlin Christmas market, Anis Amri, is often mentioned. Let me be clear once and for all: Amri has been well known to the authorities for years, he has been observed, and what exactly went wrong in the vote of the authorities in the run-up to this attack is now being worked out by a committee of inquiry. But a lack of a link between his identities was certainly not the problem. Quite apart from the fact that we are at a point of no return in terms of data protection, security aspects still matter. Such a central identity register, which contains personal biometric data of a huge number of people, is a worthwhile target for hackers who could derail a large number of databases and related services with a targeted attack on the CIR, and I do not want to imagine the impact of a data leak. Unfortunately, during the negotiations, it quickly became apparent that there would be a result that we cannot agree to. It is obvious that an unnecessary and expensive new infrastructure will be created, which will primarily benefit those companies that sell the corresponding hardware and software. In addition, we accept disadvantages in data protection and approach the ideal of a surveillance state. We in the Group of the Greens/European FaEC cannot support this and will therefore vote against the interoperability package.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Let us remember the Case of Amri, where the security authorities failed miserably, not so much because of any multiple identifications and multiple identities, but because the protection of the Constitution has abandoned the observation of Amri. That was the point!  And what happened now? It is clear that instead of a European search portal – which we could somehow understand so that we can identify suspects and criminals more quickly – we have now had four databases caught the eye – in addition to the above-mentioned, the biometric comparison portal, the common identity store, the data store for multiple identities. Anyone who is still talking about technical interoperability, I have to say quite honestly, he is simply lying! This is because it is a question of effectively removing the limitation of the purpose of the connected databases. And the EDPS, like the previous speaker, says that this is a point of no return. Once the purpose is repealed, it is in the bucket, then it is gone, to put it this way – and thus also the data of the citizens an easy prey for the state, which can monitor comprehensively.  The fact is that if you add Eurodac as the next database, migration and crime will be lumped together. The bottom line is that a huge superdata system is being created with data from third-country nationals, which can be used practically without criminality for any identification. And that is the entry into biometric registration and control of people, first of third-country nationals and tomorrow of all of us. Welcome in the beautiful new world!

name: Laura FERRARA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this legislative package is of great importance: police and judicial cooperation, by improving the sharing of information, contributes to fundamentally strengthening the internal security of the European Union. Since the terrorist attacks in Paris, we have been waiting for action to fill structural gaps in current information management, making current IT systems interoperable, i.e. able to exchange data and share and integrate information. Interoperability, allowing better communication between databases, will then be a valuable support for national authorities in the areas of security, borders and visa procedures. Facilitating verification and making controls more effective in all Member States will make it easier to identify who poses a threat, to combat identity fraud, to prevent, investigate or prosecute serious crimes. An achievable goal, not only through the possession of relevant information, but also through their better management and sharing at European level. I would therefore like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Lenaers and Mr Melo, for their excellent work.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. First of all, I would like to thank the report-takers for their excellent collaborative work, especially Jeroen Lenaers, with whom I have worked most. This work has not always been easy, however, as the S&D group has accepted with many legitimate reservations the reform of justice and home affairs databases and the creation of interoperability between them. I am convinced that these databases for different purposes were built separately from each other not by accident, but by conscious data protection reasons. Of course, and I understand, of course, that, in the midst of the current security challenges, we need systems that will enable fraud of personal identity to be prevented and help individual authorities to work more efficiently. At the same time – and we all know this – the protection and proper management of personal data is a highly sensitive area and therefore the transformation of these systems requires very careful consideration.  In this context, I must refer to the reservations expressed by the Fundamental Rights Agency and the EDPS on the need to centralisation of identity management and proportionality, not to mention the huge costs involved. However, I do not think that it can be based on the fact that citizens of third countries inherently pose a security risk to the European Union. I consider this to be an exaggeration and I am concerned about the trend observed in this report, which seeks to limit fundamental rights on the grounds of security. I am convinced that we need to build a Europe in which fundamental rights and security are not competing, but complementary categories. Finally, I think that, despite all the debates, we have taken a fundamental regulation based on acceptable, eligible, responsible compromises.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I can readily admit that this database is something completely new to me when I was given this assignment. I am a migration lawyer at the bottom and have therefore been responsible for the part that deals with borders and visas.  I do of course look at the proposal with my migration law glasses. In general, I would like to say that the proposal, as I see it, is nothing more than another step in the trend to do everything we can to prevent people from entering Europe. However, more monitoring and control does not solve the problems of people being forced to leave their home countries.  On the other hand, we are putting our own values, which are based, among other things, on fundamental rights and freedoms, when we repeatedly adopt legislation that undermines respect for human rights and our own core values. Migrants continue to come, but our fear of them means that we are violating both international and own rules on human rights and data protection. We equate migrants with potential criminals. Although the purpose of regulation is completely at odds with what I believe in, we went into the discussions on interoperability with a very open mind, because in the best of worlds it could even be good. But I soon realised that the two proposals go far beyond what I can accept.  These include the so-called common identity repository that Mr Romero spoke of earlier, with biometric and biographical information – that it should be the main database for all other databases. That is going far too far: especially when the Commission was hovering on the target and, despite repeated attempts, failed to convince us that the need exists and that it is necessary and proportionate. It is not the case that the end justifies the means. We have data protection rules for the protection of privacy and fundamental rights and freedoms. I agree with the analysis carried out earlier by Mr Romero that this is a monster database and this monster database is not acceptable, as I see it.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, these proposals extend not only the collection and use of biographical and biometric data - imposing a harmonisation of information systems - but also the ease with which authorities access this set of personal data without the need for judicial authorisations. It is not a purely technical option, but a bottom policy option that opens the door to the creation of a European Union-wide supersurveillance system. Proposals that attack the right to privacy and citizens' own freedom deliberately fuel the confusion between migration, crime and terrorism. In practice, it is a question of imposing the principle of the presumption of guilt: everyone is treated as potential criminals. Today third-country nationals, tomorrow citizens of Member States.  The sovereignty of states is compromised by imposing a supranational framework that reinforces the unacceptable security drift and the xenophobic and racist response to migration. This is another example of how typical views of the far right make their way through the hand of the right and social democracy.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, well the EU is, as ever, focused on control. What better mechanism, and latest example, but the one we have before us this evening? Along with other colleagues who have already spoken, I’m going to argue that this approach is both misguided and misdirected. Even worse, it is actually cost inefficient. The projected cost of this legislation to the European Union taxpayer is projected to be EUR 460 million. Compare that to the amount spent by the United States of America, with a similar population, on protecting the internal security of its citizens. This, everybody, is a mere drop in the ocean, and if the European Union is serious, then a serious, detailed and transparent budget must be proposed. Some of you have already highlighted another concern of mine, which is the quality of the data. Establishing a European search portal to centralise biographical and biometric data is wholly dependent on the quality of the information submitted. We have numerous instances of crime perpetrators destroying their identification, removing all or any traceability, and thus any accountability for their actions. False European Union passports, we know, are on sale on the black market and they exist in various forms on a very large scale. As for data ownership, has anyone in the Commission – or even at Council level – really considered how 500 million European Union citizens feel about their personal data being collated, managed and accessed in this manner? I am hopeful that the European Union does not envisage a police state, but the question has to be posed, does it?  Finally, I will remind you that the European Union’s sacrosanct pillar of human rights is under siege here. This proposed legislation delivers nothing more than EU control where sovereign nation would suffice.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner King, Commissioner Avramopoulos, I guarantee you all the support, as a Spanish and European socialist, for any initiative , in particular this Regulation, which will ensure that terrorism and transnational crime are more effective through information technologies. What is interoperability? In order to make it possible for all border control databases to be shared: the Visa Information System, the Schengen Information System, Eurodac, but also the new technologies applied to ETIAS, the Entry and Exit System and even the exchange of information on criminal records, which we call ECRIS. But the Socialists have emphasized ensuring that this is compatible, first and for all, with three precautions. The first is not leading to an erquivocal between immigration and terrorist threat, because they are not the same thing. The second, which ensures strict compliance with the European Data Protection Regulation, of European law which protects the confidentiality of personal data. And the third, which is also in compliance with the principles of proportionality and necessity when it affects fundamental rights, because that is also compliance with European law.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you to everyone who has spoken, for your engagement on these issues. They obviously raise in some cases deeply-held feelings. We did try and address those issues, as I think has been recognised by, for example, the last speaker, Mr López Aguilar, and earlier by Mr Deprez. We did try and address some of the issues that have been raised by some of the Groups this evening. I think that the outcome, strengthened by the scrutiny and input at the European Parliament, is a good outcome. It is supported in the Council, so it isn’t against the Member States. But most importantly for me, it is strongly supported by those on the front line: the policemen, the border guards and the immigration officers, who we need to help to do their job, which is to keep us safe.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you and let me also thank the Commission, because from the beginning of this process, we’ve had many, many, many hours of discussions, within Parliament and with the Commission, on how exactly this works, what can we do, how can we improve it. I think all the work that we’ve put into this has led to a very good result. I’d also like to thank all the colleagues here who have expressed their support for this. I think most of us support this, most of us have also spoken about the balance between security and fundamental rights. Mr Niedermüller said that they are not competing with each other, but they’re complementary to each other, and I think this is a prime principle that we managed to get into this legislation.  I think it is good news. It is good news if you care about fighting identity fraud. It is good news if you care about making our security policy in the European Union more effective. It is good news if you care about giving our police officers, our border guards, our custom guards, the right instruments to do their jobs and also very helpful with the elections coming up as Mr Avramopoulos also referred to.  If you don’t care about any of these things. If you don’t care about fighting identity fraud and if you don’t care about security, you still have the possibility to vote either for the Greens or the extreme Left.

name: Nuno MELO
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, two final notes: a first word for the authorities who, in particular police officers, risk their lives every day to guarantee our freedoms – it is for these police authorities, and others, that we have to give the best answers whether europol, frontex, eu-LISA, or, as in my country, the Foreigners and Borders Service, psp or GNR. A second note of contradiction to what we have heard here from Greens and Communists. The Greens argue that with this system we find criminals, but also people who are serious. I'd say it's normal, because if we knew who the criminals were, we wouldn't have to investigate anything. Precisely because they are all mixed up we have to investigate wherever, among the honest people, who fortunately in this world are the majority, we will be able to detect criminals and, through this, avoid, inter alia, terrorist fighting and a normal flow from the external borders into the European Union.
