As for the Communists - who are so concerned about these issues of legality here - I would also like to say, even though they have gone out because it seems that the debate will not be important enough, which I guarantee, with absolute certainty, that here in the European Union we will always do everything with much more legality and respect for others and data protection than , for example, the regimes that communists defend every day, whether in Venezuela, in Cuba or in North Korea, where, yes, in an intrusive way, without respect for human rights, certainly all information is collected, arbitrary arrests are made, even for an offence of opinion, and, at the limit, people simply disappear at the hands of the State. That said, our concern as MEPs is strict compliance with legality and ensuring the safety of peoples.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place during the next part-session.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Angelika Niebler on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and the Council on preventive restructuring frameworks, the second chance and measures to increase the efficiency of restructuring, insolvency and debt relief procedures and to amend Directive 2012/30/EU (COM(2016)0723 - C8-0475/2016 - 2016/0359 (COD)) (A8-0269/2018).

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, i would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their support in advising on this dossier. The Directive on preventive restructuring and second chance for entrepreneurs is a milestone in promoting entrepreneurship in the European Union.  We have a situation in Europe where 200 000 companies have to file for insolvency every year, and 1.7 million jobs are lost as a result. And consider that 50 percent of all companies set up in Europe do not survive five years. In other words, we must promote entrepreneurship, promote entrepreneurship, and if we now facilitate the restructuring of companies that are in financial difficulties, then we are on the right track. And if we also support our start-ups, if they have perhaps not completed their first business, their first start, so successfully, then we have also done something to prevent failure from being perceived as a stigma, as is often the case here in the European Union. We need to make sure that this is part of the learning curve when companies or young people become self-employed.  The starting point for this dossier was difficult: we have very different restructuring rules in 28 Member States. We do not know Member States that are restructuring, such as Bulgaria, Hungary, Slovakia and Croatia. We have countries that allow restructuring under strict conditions, such as my own country, Germany. And we have countries where restructuring is easy going, as in France, Belgium, the UK and other countries. In addition, restructuring is based on different cultures. There are many countries in which, as in my own country, Germany, the sole interest in restructuring, insolvency, is the satisfaction of creditors, while in other countries it is important that the company can continue and that, in the end, jobs are also preserved.  What is now provided for in this directive with a view to preventive restructuring is a good balance between these two different cultures. The directive is divided into three parts: firstly, the establishment of an early warning system to be introduced by the Member States, then the second is a major part of the issue of preventive restructuring, and the third part of the directive deals with debt relief. Early warning instruments will have to be introduced in all Member States in the future. I think it is a good thing to provide companies with tools to identify at an early stage whether their business needs to be restructured. In some countries this already exists, in others it does not. In the case of preventive restructuring, it was important for us in Parliament to strike a better balance between the interests of all those involved, especially creditors and debtors.  The majority of us in Parliament had the impression that the Commission's proposal was a good proposal, but very debt-oriented, and we have now found a better balance through changes in our report. We also wanted to clarify in our report what the role of the parties involved is in the context of a preventive restructuring procedure. For example, we have defined exactly when a restructuring administrator should be mandatory or voluntarily involved in the restructuring. One issue that was also close to the hearts of many colleagues in the European Parliament was the issue of employee participation, workers' rights and employee representation.  We have succeeded in balancing, and I am very pleased about that. We have worked very well here in detail. My final point is that we have also found a proper compromise on debt relief. Now the proposal for a directive as we see in our version provides that debt can be discharged within three years if the debtor also behaves in accordance.  All in all, a good result. I hope that we can convince many and convince us to start a business here, and those who need to restructure now have a framework.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Insolvency Directive, which comes to a vote tomorrow, has two goals – to enable the rescue of viable businesses which are in financial distress, and to ensure that honest entrepreneurs who failed are given a second chance. We agree that, together, these measures will help facilitate the free movement of capital as well as the freedom of establishment for businesses by putting in place a European approach, removing the obstacles that can result from the differences in national laws and procedures on preventive restructuring insolvency and second chances. This development of a so-called rescue culture in the EU is key for encouraging entrepreneurship and economic growth. On behalf of the Commission, I’d like to thank the rapporteur, Ms Niebler, as well as the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation and hard work to conclude the file to get it to this point.  This directive puts in place minimum harmonisation provisions, ensuring firstly that viable enterprises in financial difficulties have access to effective national preventative restructuring frameworks, which will enable them to continue operating. Secondly, it also ensures that honest insolvent or over-indebted entrepreneurs have a second chance at creating a business after a full discharge of debt, following a reasonable period of time, up to a maximum of three years. Thirdly, the directive will improve the effectiveness of restructuring, insolvency and discharge procedures, in particular with a view to shortening the amount of time that they can take. This in turn will help increase investment and job opportunities across the single market, reduce unnecessary liquidations of viable companies, thereby reducing job losses, prevent the build-up of non-performing loans, and reduce costs and increase opportunities for those entrepreneurs, whom we want to support if they need a fresh start.  I look forward to this debate and the vote tomorrow. I hope there is strong support for this.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: drafts member of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. – Mr President, British Commissioner, thank you very much for coming to dignify this great piece of legislation - I believe - of Parliament, because it marks a kind of change of trend in the treatment of entrepreneurship and risk-taking in Europe, we would almost say a little more neighbourly than the American one, which has always been praised.  Some 200,000 EU companies – almost 600 a day – go bankrupt each year, and some 7 million jobs are lost each year. Why? Often by absolute rigidity in the application of standards, in an almost administrativist and accounting view of what is as vivid as an industrial or business fabric. This piece of legislation is very important because it directly influences the most active part of our society and, at European level, improves the lives of our companies and workers affected by the lives of these companies. Essentially four things.  Greater convergence of insolvency and restructuring procedures. It means a stronger and more credible single market, also in the financial world. It facilitates greater legal certainty for cross-border investors, which is a way of breaking borders, which is Europe's future. And it encourages timely restructuring of viable companies in financial difficulties. We would have liked to go further in the ECON Commission, for example, with that priority that the administrations sometimes have and that they apply the law, but it doesn't matter. There's a fourth fundamental point. And it protects workers, giving companies and workers a second chance, and betting much more on survival than having to scrap.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I congratulate my colleague Angelica Niebler on an excellent report. Preventive restructuring as such is, of course, a very important tool for European entrepreneurs.  By eliminating national differences in the rules governing preventive restructuring, we will promote the exercise of fundamental freedoms of free movement of capital or freedom of establishment. By simplifying the rules, we will also support SMEs, 99% of all businesses in the Union, which often do not have the resources for complicated cross-border management. The proposal therefore brings clear Union added value. The path of minimum harmonisation creates sufficient scope for Member States to apply the Directive according to their own needs, while at the same time fulfilling its basic objectives. The relationship between the debtor and the creditor often raises complicated questions concerning not only trade relations, but also human rights and the topic of human dignity.  This is a very sensitive issue in the Czech Republic. Based on my country's experience, I know very well that not all debtors can be seen as someone who needs to be taught a lesson for a reckless approach. However, I am equally aware of the need to allow creditors to enforce their claims effectively. In this respect, the report represents a good compromise for me, or it contains an approach that reflects both sides of the creditor-debtor relationship. I therefore fully support this report and will vote in favour of it.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, from the outset, we considered the directive that we are going to vote on tomorrow to be very timely and positive, at least in the Commission's intentions. In particular, at a time when the economic and social effects of the long crisis we are experiencing have not yet been exhausted, it is very appropriate to put in place all possible legal means that can enable companies to embark on restructuring paths, which make it possible to save economic activity first and which are then aided by formal insolvency and therefore liquidation paths. , thus trying to avoid job losses and, with it, the dramatic social consequences that it often has. The text we are going to vote on is the result of lengthy negotiations that first affected Parliament and then Parliament with the Council. But for this reason, which has enabled us to deal with even the most sensitive points, as my fellow Members mentioned earlier, we cannot regard it as negative. However, we must not hide the fact that we have missed an important opportunity, in our opinion, to ensure strong protection for the most vulnerable in this dramatic phase of corporate restructuring in some territories, involving large European companies but, very often, even the weakest medium-sized and small ones. A restructuring plan normally does not only concern financial matters, which are the most obvious in many circumstances, but restructuring inevitably extends to matters relating to the organization of the company, not only because the organization, when it is deficient, produces the difficulties but also because in order to get out of these difficulties it is necessary to change the organizational model that is the cause of the crisis. Therefore, since it is a company organization that is suffering, the process also concerns the remuneration of workers and employment conditions, meaning by conditions both the number of people involved and the extent and character, including cultural, of the work that is lost in so many circumstances. We have therefore worked to ensure that the need for preventive involvement and full information for workers, as well as for all other actors and stakeholders who are in contact with the company, is recognized and formalized. We have indeed managed, from this point of view, to make considerable progress, as has been said, and for this we must thank, and I am happy to do so, the commitment of the rapporteur, especially during the very long trialogue. However, it would have been appropriate to add a few further and particularly important steps to include the obligation to confirm workers for all those elements of the plan which relate to the organizational aspects of the company, including, of course, redundancies, economic conditions, working hours and material conditions. The absence of this point is one of those missed opportunities for good legislation and real progress for the weakest. Another point on which I think we have missed an opportunity is, again, the workers. This time, however, not as a workforce, as part of the organization of the enterprise, but, in turn, as possible creditors of a company in crisis. We believe that creditors cannot all be considered at the same level and that it would have been useful and necessary to provide greater protection for the weakest creditors, the workers. In particular, we believe that the provision of a specific class for employee credits cannot be a option for The Member States but should be compulsory. In addition, it would have been appropriate to give this class preferential rights and additional protections over all other classes. We are going to stop there. , of the company as well as of the workforce.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Once again, we see here the attitude of the so-called good Antek from someone else's bag. Because where will the money come from to save failing businesses? I am afraid that they will not be taken from parliamentary allowances, only from taxpayers, so once again you want to help at someone else's expense. The money in this way will go from the people who manage it better, who are in a good financial position, whose businesses are doing well, to those who manage it worse. And then you will be surprised where the crisis comes from. This money does not come from nowhere: somewhere they will run out, for something they will run out. In order to save jobs in one less efficient company, two jobs in other well-functioning ones need to be lost, because we still need to keep the officials who will oversee this operation. All in all, the economy is losing out. For you, it's just pressing buttons, but for a lot of people it means taking money away from them that they could use for some smarter things. It's really a senseless movement of money from one people to another with the help of a bureaucratic apparatus.

name: Emil RADEV
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Mrs Nibbler on the agreement reached on the Directive on preventive restructuring, second chance provision and measures to increase the efficiency of restructuring, insolvency and discharge procedures. It is well known that effective and efficient insolvency procedures are an element of a good business environment. They support trade and investment. They support job creation and retention and help economies overcome shocks that lead to high levels of unpaid debt and unemployment.  In practice, divergences in national insolvency proceedings can make it costly and protracted to protect the interests of companies, hampering the functioning of national economies and the common market as a whole. Uncertainty around insolvency rules and procedures is seen as a deterrent to cross-border enlargement and investment. Every year, a million and 700,000 people lose their jobs because of the bankruptcy of the company in which they work. With the new directive, we aim to support small and medium-sized enterprises. They will be very helpful in introducing key principles of preventive restructuring and second chance for businesses in the Member States, as well as the introduction of shorter and more effective insolvency procedures.  In addition, we aim to give entrepreneurs a second chance by repaying their debts. This will eliminate perpetual debtors and reduce the amount of non-performing loans on banks' balance sheets and prevent the accumulation of such loans in the future. However, in order to achieve this, it is essential that the discharge rules also apply to consumers. I therefore hope that Member States will take into account the recommendation in the text, namely to combat consumer over-indebtedness by introducing binding rules on discharge as soon as possible. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – My question is: how do you want to drive the economic downturn with money taken from this economy? In order to pump this money into the economy, it needs to be pumped out of it first, so if it could work, it would be perpetuum mobile. Do you not think that rescuing entrepreneurs who are close to bankruptcy encourages people to take risks and be on the brink of bankruptcy?

name: Emil RADEV
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Where there are procedures clearly described, with clear rules that will help us, even with partial debt relief, to keep small and medium-sized enterprises working, to keep jobs, it is in the interest of the whole economy, both creditors and debtors.

name: Emil RADEV
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you for this debate. Thank you in particular for the work that’s gone into this dossier and into getting us to the point we’ve now reached. Again, on behalf of the Commission, I encourage you all to vote tomorrow in favour of the political agreement on the Insolvency Directive reached in December. As far as we’re concerned, we will work to ensure that, once the Council completes the procedural steps, the Directive will be swiftly and effectively implemented by Member States.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the Commission again, Commissioner King, and to the members who have been very committed to the dossier. I would like to stress once again that I believe that we have reached a very, very good compromise and that, above all, we have taken an important step forward in promoting entrepreneurship in Europe.  We have so many talented people in all the Member States, so many talented people, and I think we need to motivate young people to take the risk of starting a business. And that is precisely what this directive is used for, which is intended to make it easier to restructure or to get a second chance in the event of difficulties.  A colleague came forward twice and claimed that money is being pushed back and forth: this is nonsense, of course. This is not state money at all that flows into this restructuring. No, it is about: either you allow companies to file for bankruptcy, or you simply try to help, by intelligent help, by restructuring debt and the like, by helping a company that is sometimes in trouble – this can also have a cyclical impact. And that is precisely the purpose of this directive. In this respect, I am really pleased that we have set in motion a good deal to strengthen the entrepreneurial side here in the European Union. That is what we need!  Not only do we want state intervention, but we need entrepreneurs who create jobs, who also invest, who take a certain risk, and if we create a framework for helping these very companies, then I believe we have done a good job.  I very much hope that the report will be adopted tomorrow by a large majority. I also believe that we have a great deal in the report in order to strengthen the workers' side accordingly.  We have always had the discussion beforehand, Mr Cofferati: do we need to give workers even better support? However, we have given you many opportunities for information and consultation, including within the framework of this proposal for a directive. And they have the same rights as any creditor, but we just haven't accepted preferential rights. I also think that is the right approach.  With this in mind, I would ask for your support in tomorrow's vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 28 March 2019.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on The report by Pavel Svoboda on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the exercise of copyright and related rights in relation to certain online transmissions by broadcasters and retransmission. OF television and radio programmes (COM(2016)0594 - C8-0384/2016 - 2016/0284 (COD)) (A8-0378/2017).

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all, I am glad that tomorrow we will have the opportunity to vote on the outcome of the negotiations, which has not been easy. Here I would therefore like to thank all those who took part in the negotiations for their patience and will to reach a basic agreement, especially Mrs Niebler.  The implementation of the Digital Single Market is a priority not only for the European Commission, but also for the European Parliament. The Position of the European Parliament differed from that of the Commission on some matters and it was our duty to act in accordance with this decision by most of our colleagues. The European Parliament felt that there was a need to support those who create the works and to provide them with sufficient legal certainty and support for the realisation of long-term projects. We have long said that everything needs to be done to ensure the diversity of European culture and to ensure that The European creators who ensure this pluralism have adequate conditions for their business to be implemented.  The conditions for the existence of many different broadcasters should be encouraged. We are aware of the potential offered by new digital technologies. However, we also want to ensure a stable environment for business. Therefore, the question of the scope of application of the country of origin principle was crucial for the European Parliament. The agreed scope, where the country-of-origin principle applies only in cases of balancing rights for radio programmes, news and own production, is acceptable to the European Parliament. We believe that this is a balanced compromise that will improve the opportunities for broadcasters and consumers who watch programmes over the Internet and, as a result, ensure a wider range of offers. Consumers will be able to watch more programmes throughout the European Union. The European Parliament's request was also, at least to a fundamental extent, to touch on the direct delivery technique that broadcasters are now increasingly using. Although the implementation of this requirement meant changing the instrument from a regulation to a directive, we have also managed to meet this challenge, which is why tomorrow we will vote on the directive, not on the regulation.  Here I would like to stress the need for the implementation of these rules in the Member States to be guided by efforts to ensure respect for copyright, which alone are able to support creators and thus ensure quality and varied broadcasting for European citizens. I believe that the agreement reached is a balanced compromise that reflects the current conditions and possibilities and which, at the same time, does nothing to prevent a possible further step forward if the conditions change further. I therefore appeal to all colleagues to support the outcome of the negotiations in tomorrow's vote.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, I welcome the move by the Commission to facilitate the availability of culture across Member States. It is important that, as online services expand, the barriers to broadcasting are reduced, whilst maintaining the contractual rights of producers and broadcasters over their work. It is important for the health of the cultural sector that they maintain reasonable levels of control over the material they produce.  This legislation does mark some improvements for consumers, and will increase the availability of certain programmes across Europe. This is positive for both producers and citizens engaging with European culture. Information and current affairs will in particular become more accessible. This will allow citizens to access quality news and media across the continent, which I believe will enhance our media sector. It can only be a good thing that we support more trusted information being provided on a European level, and I hope this has the capacity to develop a shared European perspective on current affairs. Fully financed works by online broadcasters will also be included in this Directive. This is also a positive move for consumers online and should increase accessibility for all.  I hope that this legislation will enable progressive forces in Europe to push for improved availability of culture across borders, whilst maintaining a balance with the preservation of contractual freedoms. Culture plays a vital role in forming strong relationships across the continent and breaking down barriers between people. The broadcasts that we share form part of a common experience. We must facilitate a healthy broadcasting sector that can reach out to citizens everywhere.  As with any copyright legislation, the authors and producers must not be forgotten. Those who work to create content must not be vulnerable to exploitation and must receive equitable remuneration for their work. Authors, content creators, writers and other rights holders need adequate protection in the law to ensure they receive just reward for their work. It can never be right for broadcasters to profit disproportionately from the work of others. The protection of creators’ income relates directly to the health of the sector. Those who author information or cultural work must have their incomes protected. They must be able to live from their work, otherwise we risk damaging the diversity of the sector.  Finally, I’d like to look to the future. The Commission, I believe, will continue to reduce the barriers to broadcasting across Europe, and this will contribute to improving the programmes and information that are available. However, we cannot facilitate improved broadcasting without offering support to independent and emerging producers of culture. We must not only look to protect, but also to enhance the diversity of broadcasting and culture across Europe. We must also be careful not to allow broadcasting in Europe to be dominated by a small number of organisations from certain regions.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I’m pleased that we’re discussing this evening the political agreement reached on this proposal. On behalf of the Commission, we agree that this represents an important part of the Digital Single Market Strategy. Allow me to thank, on behalf of colleagues, the rapporteurs and all the Members who have been involved in getting the file to this point. The Directive will help enable our citizens to benefit more fully from the diversity of content offered by European broadcasters, as we’ve heard, by making copyright licensing easier for broadcasters and retransmission operators that are willing to make more programmes available to more people across the EU. It will also benefit those living abroad, as they will be able to stay connected to their home countries, as well as Europe’s numerous linguistic minorities.  At the same time, the Directive protects rights holders with a number of safeguards. In particular, the new Directive makes it easier for broadcasters to provide access to their radio and television programmes via their online services, makes it easier for retransmission operators to obtain the necessary rights to retransmit broadcasts from other Member States, and includes new rules on the direct injection technique relevant for the remuneration of rights holders. While the Commission supports the text resulting from the interinstitutional discussions, which you’re going to be voting on tomorrow, I have to say that we regret that the original legal basis proposed, Article 114, was replaced with Articles 53(1) and 62. The Commission intends to issue a declaration in this regard.  Commission statement in writing The Commission takes note that the text adopted by the European Parliament and the Council of the Directive laying down rules on the exercise of copyright and related rights applicable to certain online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes and amending Council Directive 93/83/EEC replaces the legal basis retained in its proposal (Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, TFEU) with the combined legal basis of Articles 53(1) and 62 TFEU. The Commission considers that Articles 53(1) and 62 TFEU provide a specific legal basis, and can thus be considered ‘lex specialis’, for directives concerning access to activities of self-employed persons. Legislation exceeding that scope should more properly be based on the general legal basis related to the achievement of the internal market (Article 114 TFEU). The two legal bases (Article 114, and Articles 53(1) and 62 TFEU) could also have been used in conjunction, if necessary. In a spirit of compromise and with a view to the immediate adoption of the proposal by the Union, the Commission supports the final text. However, it regrets the removal of Article 114 TFEU as the legal basis of the Directive and reaffirms that that provision of the TFEU shall be used in future internal market legislation concerning issues other than access to activities of self-employed persons.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank my colleagues, and in particular Mrs Niebler, for the excellent work done in committee and in inter-institutional negotiations. The text put to the vote tomorrow will allow better access to television and radio programmes across Europe, for the benefit of our citizens, and will facilitate the acquisition of copyright by the operators concerned. The original proposal for a regulation has been transformed into a directive, giving Member States a margin of appreciation. The application of the country of origin principle is limited to news and current affairs programmes, as well as to internal productions fully funded by a broadcaster. The territoriality of rights, which is the basis of cultural creation and its funding, remains the principle. Cultural and linguistic diversity will thus be preserved. Finally, the direct injection provisions resolve a problematic situation by clarifying the responsibility of operators. This will give rights holders greater legal certainty. This proposed directive is important for our citizens, rights holders and the preservation of a quality culture.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to express my sincere thanks to our rapporteur and our committee chairman, who has guided us through the deliberations with patience and excellence in many, many trialogue rounds. Without Mr. Svoboda, we would never have come to Potte if there had never been a result – so thank you very much for that! That is why I have come forward in the first place.  Otherwise, I think that the directive is really also a milestone: we are simplifying the distribution of TV and radio programmes on the Internet by making rights clearing easier. Content will be more readily available throughout Europe in the future, but – and this is my most important point – on fair terms. I believe that the directive strikes a good balance between the protection of European filmmakers on the one hand and the interests of broadcasters and consumers. I have worked to ensure that co-productions are excluded from the country-of-origin principle enshrined in this rights clearing directive; I believe that this is important in order to ensure that the films are financed in the future as well.  Europe is not only a market, but thrives on the diversity of its cultures, and I believe that through the directive we are looking at diversity throughout the European ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I hope no one mistakes the conciseness of tonight’s debate with the importance of this subject. This is an important proposal. It will contribute to improving access to online radio and television content across our European Union, and it is a significant step forward in the completion of the digital single market. It’s not an abstract endeavour. It will make a practical difference. It will ensure more and better access to radio and television content across borders.  From our side, we believe that this needs to become a reality as soon as possible, and we will follow up. I look forward to a positive outcome in the voting tomorrow.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the debate has not shown any major differences of opinion on this proposal. I am glad that tomorrow perhaps this contribution to the digital market will be accepted. To be sure, the Commission's expectations at the beginning of this process were greater than the result. But, after all, Jean Monnet had already written in robert schuman's pen in 1950 that Europe would be created not at once, but by gradual steps, and this can very well be applied to this proposal. Let us try this to this extent and the future will show whether it is possible to extend the scope of this regulation in kind or not. In any case, I am happy to work with both the Commission and Mrs Niebler, and I believe that tomorrow's vote will end successfully.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 28 March 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. The agreement reached in the trialogue represents a small improvement on the status quo. In this respect, it should be noted that more could and should have been done, leading to a much more ambitious compromise. The Internet and the change it has brought about are not to be seen with mistrust, but rather as an opportunity to be seized. The completion of the single digital market was indeed one of the political priorities of the Juncker Commission, which considered it a key element in reviving the European economy and that of its Member States.  With this text, the step taken in this direction is very small and therefore there will be a lot of work to be done in the future. Only when the completion of the single digital market is complete will citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, be able to benefit concretely from such a market. In other words, a market in which consumers and businesses are free to make their choices without discrimination on the basis of nationality and irrespective of the Member State of residence and connection and where the free play of competition is able to unfold freely. More ambition was needed: the directive is therefore to be seen as a small first step in the right direction. However, there is still a long way to go.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Hilde Vautmans on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council and the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the proposal by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, with the support of the Commission, to the Council for a Council decision establishing a European Peace Facility (2018/2237(INI)) (A8-0157/2019).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, tomorrow the European Parliament will vote on an important recommendation on the European Peace Facility, a new budget fund outside the European budget worth EUR 10.5 billion for the period 2021-2027. The European Peace Facility is a new financing instrument that will enable the European Union to finance military or defence-related activities in a more efficient and flexible way. How then? By combining the various existing instruments of our external policy under a single budgetary instrument and by filling a number of existing gaps.  So far, only a limited part of the common cost of EU military operations has been funded, we have only been able to provide limited assistance to military activities, only if it was linked to strict development objectives, and support for partner military peace support operations was limited to African-led operations through the African peace facilities. The European Peace Facility will change all this.  Firstly, we will ensure great solidarity among the Member States through better burden-sharing. The European Peace Facility will replace the Athena mechanism and finance a greater share of common costs of operations, up to 45%. This will, of course, make Member States more inclined to participate in operations. Because of course, if you can share more common costs, there are less own costs left. Secondly, it will also contribute to peace-supporting operations of international organisations or third countries, no longer limited to Africa. We will have a much broader base of support. Thirdly – and this is a very important point – we will also be able to contribute to the building up of military and defence capabilities of third countries, just think of their equipment. Let me give you one concrete example: for example, we are doing EU training missions in Somalia, where we can train the military very well. But if they have no footwear, no material, no body armor, what is our training? From now on, the peace fund will be able to intervene in the purchase of, for example, bulletproof vests and footwear, so that the well-trained military can also be deployed.  Finally, there is also a flexibility clause to finance other union operational action in the framework of the common foreign and security policy, with military or defence implications. The European Peace Facility is an additional fiscal fund, which of course means to me that participation and control by this House are important. That is why we also ask for sufficient and timely information and consultation, so that we can take every position into account. That is why we are also calling for assurances that no activities are being financed that violate or are used to violate the fundamental principles laid down in Article 21 of the EU Treaty to violate international law and human rights. And, of course, we must ensure that the instrument is complementary to other external policy instruments. We whine so often, we hear it so often here, that Europe is unable to act, or act too late, that europe lacks decisiveness.  Well, our security environment is becoming more complex, more volatile, more unpredictable and ambiguous than ever. The European Union must then have the necessary tools to promote peace, to prevent conflicts and to strengthen international security, and of course to fulfil its role as a global player in the field of security. The European security facility is a missing link in this. I would therefore like to ask you with conviction to approve that recommendation. I would also like to thank all my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the hard work. This was a not-so-obvious debate, but I think we have brought it to a successful conclusion and, of course, I hope that it will be widely supported tomorrow.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me first welcome, on behalf of the High Representative, your broad support for her proposal to establish a European Peace Facility. This reflects the need, repeatedly emphasised by this House, for funding in this area that is more flexible and efficient and which better embodies solidarity. Let me extend, on behalf of the High Representative and other colleagues, our thanks to the rapporteur, Ms Vautmans, as well as the co-rapporteurs, for their engagement and their constructive and pragmatic approach.  As you rightly recall in your report, the Union’s ambition is to be a global security provider, something which is obviously in our collective strategic interest. Given the growing and evolving threat picture which we face, we need to have the capacity to respond to a variety of security challenges. That was clearly acknowledged in the global strategy in 2016.  The idea of the Peace Facility was born out of our experience, as the rapporteur was just setting out. The EU is active on the ground, but there are strong limitations to what we can achieve currently. For example, we’ve had difficulties in financing the training of soldiers in Somalia and we have not always been able to provide the Central African Republic with the equipment it needs, as was recalled, to complete its transformation from civil war to a functioning modern democracy. The cost of EU military operations fall too much on the countries which are contributing troops, and that acts as a deterrent to others when it comes to participation and deployments.  This new facility, when adopted by the Council, will make a real difference. It will provide the Union with the ability to finance all operational actions under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) with military or defence implications in a flexible, responsive manner. In particular there are three main strands of action that the Peace Facility will support. First, it will cover the common costs of EU military missions and operations. Indeed, more costs should be funded in common to better meet operational needs and to facilitate deployments. Second, it will enable the EU to contribute to military peace operations led by other international actors. And third, it will allow the EU to support the armed forces of our partner countries with infrastructure, equipment or military assistance when the Council so decides. The nature, scope and limits of these actions will be defined by the Council, but the proposal makes very clear that any support to our partners would be subject to strict controls such as respect for democratic principles and fundamental rights.  The High Representative’s proposal benefits from the support of the Commission, in accordance with Article 31. This support will help to facilitate synergies with our other financial instruments and to underpin sound financial management.  In conclusion, let me underline that this is a key part of the work that we’re doing collectively to make our citizens more secure, to better support our partners around the world and to contribute to our most precious common good, which is, of course, peace and security. So let me thank you again for your support for this important initiative. I look forward to our discussion and support tomorrow.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the instrument for financing European military operations is a further step towards ever closer cooperation between the Member States in the field of the common security and defence policy, as well as a mechanism for rationalising existing mechanisms. As a Parliament, we make a significant contribution to the High Representative's proposal, first and most of all, the clear demand that military actions financed through this instrument be in accordance with the principles and values enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and international law. We are also calling for strict control by Parliament itself, which must be kept constantly informed and have access to all acts relating to operations financed by the instrument. Furthermore, the sale or sale of military equipment or equipment to third countries must comply with the EU common position on the control of arms exports and with the control regime on dual-use products, while a detailed list of the materials supplied must also be made available, safeguards necessary because security and defence policy cannot disregard consistency with the values of peace and respect for human rights. , which are the basis of the European project. I am also particularly pleased that, on my proposal, the text includes the reference to non-proliferation and disarmament and the European Union's leading role in the fight for a ban on nuclear weapons. In increasingly uncertain times, when only a few civil society organisations seem to be really committed to these objectives, the nuclear threat is no longer a ghost of the past but a real danger, to be actively combated through international law and multilateralism, of which the Union is a leader in the world.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – (2) Mr President, the European peace-support mechanism proposed by the Commission, which this Parliament is preparing to approve, is another example of how the European Union masks its policies. Out the ideal of peace is sold, an ideal used to justify the mobilization of substantial funds for defense and armament. In practice, what this mechanism will finance is not only the military missions of the European Union, but the strengthening of the military and defence capabilities of third countries. We reject the path that the right and social democracy seek to impose by feeding the interventionist warmongering nature of the European Union. Whoever promotes war cannot defend peace. The defence of peace, as the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic advocates, involves the dissolution of NATO or military structures in the context of the European Union and the promotion of a disarmament policy, including nuclear, and conflict resolution mediated with full respect for international law and the Charter of the United Nations.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, I’d like to remind Members, and also the Commissioner, that the EU is first and foremost a peace project. I’d also like to recall the Brussels Pledge to Peace, which resulted from a conference called  ‘Peace and Prosperity, founding values of the European Union’, held on 28 November 2011 here in the European Parliament.  This declaration of intent was meant to encourage projects and actions aimed at promoting peace in its most universal meaning, inspired by the universal ideals of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity enshrined in the preamble of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, and also confirmed by the Lisbon Treaty in 2009. The Nobel Prize for Peace awarded to the European Union seals and underlines the importance of actions like the Pledge, and also this current proposal for a peace facility.  The Pledge to Peace was intended to create the necessary conditions to initiate a broad set of actions aimed at building a world of peace and prosperity. I suggest that all new MEPs in the next legislature sign the Pledge and renew this action.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, even George Orwell would have been surprised at the way this organisation has been named. You’ve allocated EUR 10.5 billion over six years. It sounds very interesting, but this fund has the potential to supply arms to African countries with histories of political unrest and human rights abuses, as well as supporting these countries with military and technical assistance. I strongly reject this proposed facility based on this fact. If it is to go ahead, maybe you should have a name change. More appropriately, call it the European arms facilitation agencies. Some of the countries singled out by Federica Mogherini that may avail themselves of this fund are Mali and Somalia. Look at what happened this week in Mali with the Government—backed militia. Look at the fact that we joined – Ireland – this union to work together with European nations, but to preserve our neutrality. We in Ireland are not preserving our neutrality if we back projects like this. This was meant to be a peace project. It’s not now, is it?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the European Union is setting up the European Peace Mechanism with the blessings of the European Parliament. Brecht has long said to you: "When those who are high speak of peace, the ordinary people know that war is coming"; because this new reactive mechanism has as its mission the direct financing without delay of the military corps for imperialist interventions of the European Union and its governments where land; yearly; because, provocatively indeed, in the name of equality, it makes an invitation to war, especially to women, in order to participate in these missions which are dangerous to the people. Seventy years since NATO was founded, twenty years since the European Union's Common Security and Defence Policy, 20 years since NATO's murderous bombing of Yugoslavia, a mechanism is being set up to systematise imperialist interventions. The peoples with their joint struggle to mark the real adversary: monopolies, their system, imperialist associations and their governments.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I wish to thank the honourable Members who’ve intervened for their comments and suggestions.  I would just say to Mr Pimenta Lopes that, far from hiding anything, this is an exercise in transparency. It’s very clear what the purposes are, as the report I think recognises. It’s very clear what the decision—making procedures will be, and that will be open to scrutiny by all.  Indeed, work is already ongoing in some of the areas highlighted in the report – for example, ensuring that future transfers of sensitive equipment take place in compliance with international law, as well as with the relevant EU rules. This is something to which, I assure you, we will attach the highest priority. We also fully agree that the European Parliament needs to be kept fully informed on a regular basis about the use of this facility. That is a commitment that we happily make.  So, thank you again for all those who’ve engaged on this subject. I know some of those views are strongly held. Thank you for this report. I hope it will be supported tomorrow.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I have heard the word peace, peace and security here many times. Unfortunately, these are notions that a lot of people in the world don't know today. Of course, we know war situations in all corners. That is why this peace facility is so important, that flexible instrument that allows us to make our external action more efficient, to support our partners in operations, with which we can bear common costs. I have heard many arguments here which were not really relevant. I think that this instrument is really what Europe needs if we are to be more efficient. That is what the citizens are asking of us. Until now, our policy has often been external in nature. We can bark, but we can't bite. We can train, but those people can't be deployed. With this instrument, I believe that we can change the realities of the field and bring about more peace. I hope that this will be voted on tomorrow.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 28 March 2019.
